Ugh. Okay. This is…not a fun topic. But you asked. So. Here goes.

It wasn't like, a sudden thing, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, definitely giving the baby away!" It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

First of all, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I mean, I'm barely an adult myself. I was still in high school, still hanging out at the arcade, still trying to navigate the whole awkward teenage thing. Adding a baby into that mix? It just felt…impossible.

And my life wasn't exactly set up for a baby. My mom is amazing, but she's already got enough on her plate. And my dad…well, he's my dad. He'd try, but he's not exactly the most practical person. I didn't want to drag them down with me.

But it wasn't just about me, or my family. It was about the baby. I wanted that baby to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready and able to provide for it, opportunities I just couldn't offer. I wanted that baby to be *wanted*, you know? And I knew, deep down, that I wasn't in a position to give it that.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. It's not like I didn't feel anything. I felt *everything*. Sadness, fear, guilt…it was overwhelming. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

I found this couple, Mark and Vanessa, through a classified ad. They were…perfect. They were kind, and loving, and they just seemed like they would be amazing parents. And they wanted the baby. They really, really wanted it.

It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about giving the baby *to* someone. Someone who could give it a better life than I could.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I try to focus on the fact that I made the best decision I could. And that the baby is happy. And that's all that really matters.

It's…complicated. Okay? It's not a happy story, but it's my story. And it's made me who I am.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. Don't expect me to get all sappy on you, though. I'm still a sarcastic teenager, even after everything.

Look, before all this happened, love was…dumb. Like, in movies. All grand gestures and dramatic music. I thought it was something that happened *to* you, not something you, like, *chose*. And responsibility? That was something adults whined about to justify being boring.

But then I got pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. It wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person I was growing, and what was best for *them*. That was the first jolt of responsibility, I guess. It wasn't fun, and it was definitely scary, but it was…real.

And then there was Paul. He was…unexpected. I thought he was just this sweet, kinda clueless guy who liked Dungeons & Dragons. But he actually *showed up*. He didn't run away, he didn't judge me, he just…helped. And that taught me something about love. It's not about fireworks and perfect moments, it's about being there for someone, even when it's hard. Even when they're being a total mess.

And then there was Mark and Vanessa. They weren't perfect, not even close. But they wanted to give this baby a good life, a stable life. And that showed me that love isn't always romantic. It can be about wanting the best for someone, even if it means letting them go.

I learned that responsibility isn't about giving up your own life, it's about making choices that are bigger than yourself. It's about thinking about the consequences of your actions. And it's about being brave enough to do what's right, even when it's the hardest thing in the world.

And love? It's messy and complicated and sometimes really painful. But it's also…worth it. It's about connection and support and finding someone who gets you, even when you don't get yourself.

It's still kinda confusing, honestly. I'm still figuring it all out. But I think I learned that love and responsibility aren't things you find, they're things you *do*. And that's…a lot. It's a lot to handle, but it's also kinda beautiful. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. But don't expect a sob story. I'm not *that* kind of person.

Look, when you find out you're pregnant at sixteen, and it's, like, totally unplanned, and your life is already kinda messy…you kinda have two choices. You can fall apart, or you can make jokes about it. I chose jokes. It was a survival mechanism, honestly.

It was easier to deflect with sarcasm than to actually *talk* about what was happening. If someone asked how I was doing, I'd just say something snarky, and they'd usually back off. It was a shield. A really effective shield.

And it wasn't just about avoiding awkward conversations. It was about taking control. Like, yeah, my life was completely derailed, but I could still control how I *reacted* to it. I could still make people laugh. I could still be…me. Even if "me" was a sarcastic, slightly cynical teenager with a growing belly.

It helped me deal with Paul and Vanessa, too. They were…a lot. And sometimes, the only way I could get through a conversation with them was to say something ridiculous. It broke the tension. It reminded me that they were just people, too. Flawed, well-meaning people, but still.

And honestly, it helped me connect with people. Bleaker's a weirdo, but he got my humor. And even though he was kinda awkward, it was nice to have someone who understood me.

It wasn't a cure-all, obviously. I still had a lot of feelings. A lot of fear and uncertainty. But humor gave me a way to process those feelings. It gave me a way to cope. It gave me a way to stay sane.

So yeah, my wit helped me. It wasn't just about being funny. It was about being strong. It was about refusing to let this thing define me. It was about finding a way to laugh, even when I wanted to cry. And sometimes, that's all you can do.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…deep? Fine. But don't expect a perfectly polished answer. I'm not exactly known for my eloquent speeches.

Look, I put up a pretty good front, right? Sarcastic, quick with a comeback, always gotta have a witty remark ready to go. It's a defense mechanism, okay? It's easier to make jokes than to actually *feel* things. Especially when you're, like, a mess inside.

Being pregnant…that kinda ripped all that away. It forced me to confront stuff I wasn't ready for. I was just a kid, trying to figure out who I was, and suddenly I was responsible for another human being. It was terrifying.

And I didn't want anyone to see me scared. I didn't want anyone to see me vulnerable. So I kept cracking jokes, pretending everything was fine. But it wasn't. I was lost. I didn't know what I wanted, what I believed in, or who I was supposed to be.

Giving the baby up for adoption…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. It wasn't about being "responsible" or "doing the right thing," though those things were part of it. It was about admitting that I wasn't ready. It was about admitting that I needed help. And that took a lot of courage, even if I didn't feel very courageous at the time.

Through all of it – the awkward conversations with Paul and Vanessa, the weirdness with Mark, the whole adoption process – I started to realize that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to be scared. 

And I started to realize that my identity wasn't something I had to *find*. It was something I was *creating*. It was about the choices I made, the people I cared about, and the things I believed in. 

It wasn't a straight line, you know? There were a lot of bumps and detours. But I learned that being vulnerable isn't a weakness. It's a strength. It allows you to connect with people, to ask for help, and to grow.

So yeah, my vulnerability and my search for identity shaped my journey in a big way. It made me who I am. A little bit messy, a little bit sarcastic, and a whole lot more real. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even a lifetime supply of cheesy tater tots. Almost.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. But don't expect a sappy monologue, alright? I'm still Juno MacGuff, even if I'm talking about feelings.

Look, when I found out I was pregnant, I was…freaking out. Obviously. I was sixteen! I had no idea what I was doing. I thought I had to figure everything out on my own, be all independent and strong and stuff. Which, you know, is kinda my default setting.

But I quickly realized that trying to do it alone was a terrible idea. It was just…too much. And that's where Paul and Vanessa came in. Paul, he was…unexpected. A little clueless, maybe, but genuinely good. He actually *listened* to me, instead of just telling me what to do. And he didn't judge. Which was a huge relief.

And Vanessa? She was amazing. She was already a mom, and she just…got it. She didn't try to fix things or tell me what I *should* do. She just offered support. And advice when I asked for it. She let me be me, even when I was being a total mess.

And then there was my dad. He was…well, he was my dad. He was awkward and goofy and didn't always know what to say, but he was always there for me. He made me grilled cheese sandwiches and let me vent and just…loved me, no matter what.

They didn't *make* my decisions for me. They didn't tell me what to do with the baby. They just helped me figure out what *I* wanted. They gave me the space to think and feel and process everything. They reminded me that I wasn't alone.

It was their belief in me, even when I didn't believe in myself, that gave me the strength to choose adoption. It wasn't an easy decision, but knowing I had their support made it…possible.

I realized that being strong doesn't mean doing everything on your own. It means letting people help you. It means accepting support when you need it. It means knowing that you're not alone in the world.

So yeah, they were pretty important. I probably would have completely fallen apart without them. Don't tell them I said that, though. They'll get all smug.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a party, let me tell you. It wasn't like in the movies where you're all glowing and happy and suddenly craving pickles and ice cream. It was more like...my stomach dropped into my shoes and stayed there. For a really long time.

I mean, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about, like, getting my driver's license and whether or not Mark would finally ask me to the Fall Dance. Not...this. 

At first, it was just pure panic. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe, everything-is-ending panic. I remember staring at the test, and then staring at it again, hoping it was a mistake. It wasn't. And then I just...sat there. For a long time. Just thinking. And mostly freaking out.

It felt like my whole life had just been turned upside down. All my plans, everything I thought I wanted...gone. I was supposed to go to college, maybe move away, figure out what I wanted to do with my life. And now? Now I was going to be a mom.

It was scary. Really scary. And confusing. And honestly, a little bit disgusting. Not the baby part, exactly. Just...the whole situation. It felt so messy and complicated.

I didn't tell anyone for a while. I just kept it to myself, trying to process it. It was a really lonely time. I felt like everyone else was living their normal lives, and I was stuck in this weird, separate reality.

It wasn't until I started talking to Paul and Annie that things started to feel...a little bit less awful. They didn't judge me. They just listened. And they helped me figure out what I wanted to do.

It was still scary, even after I decided to give the baby up for adoption. But it was also...empowering. I was making a decision. I was taking control of my life, even if it wasn't the life I had planned.

So yeah. Finding out I was pregnant? It was the worst. But it also ended up being...well, it ended up being a really important part of my life. It made me grow up. And it made me realize that sometimes, the things you don't plan for are the things that change you the most.

Ugh, okay, that's...a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It kinda flipped everything upside down.

With my dad, it was...weird at first. He's a pretty quiet guy, and I think he just didn't know what to say. He tried to be supportive, but it was mostly just awkward silences and him offering me weirdly specific advice about baby furniture. Eventually, we started talking more, and he actually turned out to be really good at just...listening. He's a good dad, even if he's not always the best at expressing it.

My mom, she was...a lot. She went into full-on panic mode. Like, "What will people think?" and "Your life is over!" and all that jazz. It took her a while to come around, but eventually she realized I was serious about giving the baby up for adoption and that I needed her support, not her judgment. We had some really tough conversations, but it actually brought us closer, in a weird way.

And then there were my friends. Leah and Renee...they were amazing. They were totally shocked, obviously, but they didn't ditch me or anything. They just...showed up. They helped me with everything, from researching adoption agencies to just being there to listen when I was freaking out. They were my rocks.

But it also changed things. I felt...different. Like I was on a different path than them. They were still focused on boys and school and stuff, and I was dealing with, you know, *this*. It created a little distance, I think. Not a bad distance, just...a different one.

It made me realize who my real friends were, though. The ones who stuck around, the ones who didn't judge me, the ones who just wanted me to be happy. Those are the people I'll always cherish.

It was a really messy, complicated time. It tested all my relationships. But in the end, it made them stronger. Or at least, more real. It forced everyone to be honest with each other, and with themselves. And that's never a bad thing, even if it's painful.



It's like...it was a catalyst. It changed everything, but it also showed me who I was and who I wanted to be. And that's something I'll always be grateful for. Even if it was a total disaster at times.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like stumbling through a minefield while trying to balance a stack of books and avoid getting judged by everyone you've ever met.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was a mess. I was angry, and scared, and just...completely overwhelmed. I mean, I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about homework and band practice, not, like, impending motherhood.

A lot of it was just...talking. I mean, really talking. To Paul, even though he was kinda clueless at first. And to my mom. She was surprisingly cool about the whole thing, even though I was sure she was gonna kill me. She just...listened. And she made me grilled cheese sandwiches. A lot of grilled cheese sandwiches.

And then there was Su-Jin. She's my best friend, and she was a lifesaver. She didn't sugarcoat anything, but she was always there for me. She helped me pick out baby names and she listened to me freak out about everything.

It also helped to focus on the practical stuff. Like, finding a good couple to adopt the baby. That gave me something to work towards. It wasn't about giving the baby *away*, it was about finding the best possible life for it. That made it feel...less awful.

But it was still hard. Really hard. There were days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. I cried a lot. I ate a lot of junk food. I listened to a lot of sad music.

I think the biggest thing was realizing I wasn't alone. And that it was okay to not be okay. And that even though my life was completely changing, I could still be me. I could still be Juno MacGuff, even with a baby on the way.

It wasn't easy, and it wasn't pretty. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. Mostly that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. And that sometimes, life throws you curveballs. And you just have to swing. Even if you miss.



It's still...complicated. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh, okay, this is…still a thing people ask me about. Like it was some huge, calculated decision. It wasn't. It was mostly about vibes, honestly. And a really bad waiting room.

Havenbrooke was…sterile. Everything was white and quiet and smelled like disinfectant. It felt like a hospital, which, I guess it *was*, but it just felt…cold. And the people there, they weren't *mean*, exactly, but they didn't seem happy to be there either. It felt like they were just going through the motions.

Women Now, on the other hand, it was…different. It was colorful. There were paintings on the walls, and the waiting room was actually kinda cozy. And the people who worked there, they were…nice. Like, genuinely nice. They talked to you like a person, not a problem. They didn't try to guilt-trip you or tell you what to do. They just listened.

And the protesters outside Havenbrooke? Seriously, they were relentless. It was just…a lot. I didn't need that added stress. Women Now had people there to help you navigate that, to shield you from it.

It wasn't about one thing, it was about the whole atmosphere. I needed a place where I felt safe and respected, not judged. I needed a place where I felt like I could just…be. And Women Now felt like that place.

It wasn't a decision I took lightly, obviously. But in the end, it just felt right. It felt like the least awful option. And sometimes, that's all you can ask for.

It's my body, my choice, and I chose the place where I felt the most comfortable. It's not something I'm gonna apologize for. And honestly, I'm kinda tired of explaining it. It just…was. Okay?

(Sighs, looks away, fiddles with the strap of her backpack)

Okay. Wow. That's...direct. And not exactly a question you ask someone over, like, a casual cup of coffee. But fine. You asked.

It wasn't, like, a carefully considered decision, okay? It wasn't some grand romantic gesture or a plot point in a movie. It was...stupid. And messy. And a lot of feelings I wasn't ready to deal with.

Bleeker and I had been friends for a long time. He was...safe. He got me. He didn't judge me for being weird or sarcastic or, you know, pregnant. And I think, after everything with Paul and the baby, I just...wanted to feel *something* that wasn't terrifying or overwhelming.

It was a mistake. A really big, complicated mistake. We were both just trying to fill a void, I guess. Trying to feel connected to someone without having to actually *talk* about all the stuff we were going through.

It didn't fix anything. It just made things more confusing. And it definitely didn't make me feel better about anything. It just...happened. And then I had to deal with the fallout.

It's not something I'm proud of. It's not something I like to think about. But it's part of my story. And I guess, if I'm being honest, it's a reminder that sometimes people make bad choices. And sometimes, those choices have consequences.

(Looks back up, a little defensively)

Look, it was a year ago. I was a mess. I was dealing with a lot. And I made a mistake. Okay? Can we move on now? I'd rather talk about music or cheesy tater tots. Anything but this.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look. It's...complicated. Everyone always wants to know about Bleeker. Like he's some kind of puzzle to be solved. He's not a puzzle. He's just...Bleeker.

At first, he was just...there. This quiet, guitar-playing guy who hung out with Paul. I didn't really *see* him, you know? He was just part of the background noise. And then, slowly, I started noticing things. Like how he always knew what I was thinking, even when I didn't say anything. And how he could make me laugh, even when I felt like crying.

He's not like anyone I've ever met. He doesn't try to be cool or impress anyone. He just...is. And that's kinda refreshing, I guess. He's honest, even when it's awkward. And he's really good at listening. Which is rare, especially for a guy.

But he's also...messy. Emotionally messy. He doesn't talk about his feelings, and he's kinda afraid of everything. And sometimes, I just want to shake him and tell him to grow up.

But then he looks at me with those big, sad eyes, and I just...melt. It's stupid, I know.

I think...I think I like him. A lot. But it's scary, you know? Because he's not what I expected. He's not the perfect guy. He's flawed and complicated and kinda weird. And maybe that's what makes him perfect.

I don't know what the future holds. I don't know if we'll end up together. But I know that he makes me feel...something. Something real. And that's more than I can say for most people.

So yeah. Bleeker. He's...good. Just don't tell him I said that. He'd probably freak out. And then I'd have to freak out. It's a whole thing.

Ugh, okay. This is…still kinda raw, honestly. People ask me this a lot, like it's some easy answer. It wasn't. It was the hardest thing I've ever had to think about.

Look, I was seventeen. Seventeen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone raise a whole human being. I wasn't ready. I mean, I'm not even sure I *am* ready now, and I'm…older. A little.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? It was about wanting what was best *for* the baby. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, parents who were actually prepared, a life where they didn't have to worry about, like, their mom still being in high school.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so ready. They had a beautiful house and a garden and they just…seemed like they could give the baby everything I couldn't. It wasn't about finding "perfect" parents, it was about finding parents who were perfect *for that baby*.

And honestly? I knew I wasn't that person. Not yet. I needed to figure out my own life first. I needed to go to college, maybe travel, just…become a person. I couldn't do that and be a good mom at the same time. It would have been selfish of me to try.

It was a really hard decision. It still is. I still think about the baby sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right one. It was the most selfless thing I could do. And that's…something.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby a life. And that's a big difference. It still stings, but I try to focus on that. It's complicated, okay? Life is complicated. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is admit you're not ready and let someone else take the reins.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *ask*. It was...not a good moment. Like, a really, really not good moment. It's not like I hadn't rehearsed it a million times in my head, you know? I had, like, different versions. The cool, casual version. The serious, heartfelt version. The "just spit it out and run" version. None of them prepared me for what actually happened.

I was at his house, which was already a bad idea. His room smells like old guitar strings and patchouli, which is...a lot. And I was trying to be all nonchalant, talking about, like, school and stuff. And then I just blurted it out. Just...*said* it. Like it was a weather report. "Oh, by the way, I'm pregnant."

And his face. Oh. My. God. His face. It was like someone had replaced him with a robot. Just...blank. And then he started stammering, and looking around the room like he was searching for an escape route. Which, honestly, he should have taken.

It wasn't that he was mad, exactly. It was just...he was so *overwhelmed*. He's Bleeker, you know? He's sweet and sensitive and kinda clueless. He's not exactly equipped to handle a situation like that.

And I felt terrible. I felt like I'd ruined everything. Like I'd just dropped a bomb on his life. And I was scared, too. Scared of what he would think, scared of what would happen next.

He eventually said something, I think. I honestly don't remember exactly what. It was all a blur of awkwardness and regret. He was trying to be supportive, I guess, but it just felt...wrong. Like he was saying the right things, but not *meaning* them.

It was just...a really bad day. A really, really bad day. And it made me realize that even though I liked Bleeker, he wasn't the one I needed to go through this with. He just wasn't ready. And that was okay. It just...hurt. A lot.



It's still kinda hard to talk about, honestly. It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize I had to do this on my own. Or, at least, with people who were actually ready to be there for me.

Ugh. Okay. That's...the big one, isn't it? Everyone keeps asking me that. Like, it's the only thing that matters.

Honestly? It's terrifying. Like, full-on, heart-stopping, can't-breathe terrifying. I'm sixteen. I'm supposed to be worrying about, like, getting my driver's license and figuring out what college I want to apply to, not changing diapers and dealing with sleep deprivation. I still haven't even figured *myself* out yet, you know?

It's not that I don't want kids...eventually. But *now*? It feels...wrong. Like, I'm not ready. I don't know how to be a good mom. I barely know how to be a good *Juno*.

But then...I started feeling the kicks, and it's...weird. It's like, there's this little person inside me, and it's already kinda changing things. And I'm starting to think about what kind of life I want for it. And I want it to be a good one.

So, yeah, it's scary. But it's also...something. It's a responsibility, and it's a chance to do something good. And I've decided that giving it up for adoption is the best thing for the baby. It's not what I planned, but it's what I'm choosing. 

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's gonna be hard. Really hard. But I'm trying to be brave about it. And I'm trying to focus on the fact that I'm doing this because I want what's best for the kid.

It's just...a lot to process, you know? I'm still trying to figure it all out. And honestly, I probably will be for a long time. It's not like there's a handbook for this kind of thing. You just...deal with it. And hope for the best.



And maybe eat a lot of cheesy tater tots. They help. A little.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That's...complicated. It *was* complicated, even before the whole baby situation. He's sweet, don't get me wrong. Like, genuinely sweet. And he's a good guitar player. But he's also...Bleeker. You know? Kinda spacey, kinda oblivious, kinda lives in his own little world.

Before, it was just, like, hanging out and making out and talking about music. It was easy. Now? Now it's...different. It's not just about us anymore. There's a whole other person involved. A tiny human who's gonna need diapers and stuff.

I think he's trying. He really is. He's been, like, reading books about pregnancy and stuff. Which is kinda adorable, but also kinda terrifying. Like, he thinks he can just *learn* how to be a dad from a book?

I think it's gonna force us to actually *talk*. Like, really talk. About what we want, what we expect, what we're scared of. And that's...intimidating. We've always been good at avoiding the hard stuff.

I'm worried he's gonna get overwhelmed. He's not exactly the most responsible person. And I'm worried I'm gonna have to be the one to do all the work. But I also think...maybe this is a good thing. Maybe this will force him to grow up a little.

I don't know if we're gonna end up together forever. Honestly, I haven't even thought that far ahead. But I think we're gonna have to learn to be a team. For the baby's sake. And maybe, just maybe, we'll end up being a pretty good team.

It's just...it's not gonna be easy. It's gonna be messy and complicated and probably really stressful. But that's life, right? And I guess I'm ready to face it. Even if it means facing it with Bleeker.



Ugh. Don't tell him I said that. He'll get all puffed up with pride.

Ugh. Okay, so the judgment. Yeah, that was…a lot. It felt like everyone suddenly had an opinion on my life, which is just rude, honestly. Like, people I hadn't spoken to since, like, sixth grade were suddenly all concerned about my "future." As if they knew anything about it.

The first few weeks were the worst. Whispers in the hallway, stares, people just…avoiding me. It was like I had a giant neon sign over my head saying "Mistake." And my classmates? Forget about it. Some were just…mean. Like, actively trying to make me feel worse. Others were all, "Oh, Juno, I'm *so* sorry," with this pitying look on their faces that made me want to punch them.

How did I cope? Honestly? By being even more sarcastic. It was a defense mechanism. If I could make a joke about it, it felt like I had some control. Like, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. Surprise! I guess I'm joining the ranks of teen moms. It's a real glamorous life." It was a way to deflect the awkwardness and the judgment.

But that only worked for so long. Eventually, I realized I couldn't just shut everyone out. I needed to lean on the people who actually cared about me. My dad, for one. He was surprisingly cool about the whole thing. And Paul, even though he was kinda awkward, he was always there for me. And Leah, my best friend, she was just…solid. She didn't judge me, she just helped me figure things out.

I also just…stopped caring what people thought. Which is easier said than done, I know. But I realized that their opinions didn't matter. This was *my* life, *my* decision. And I was going to do what was best for me and the baby, regardless of what anyone else thought.

It wasn't easy. There were still days when I felt overwhelmed and scared and just wanted to disappear. But I kept reminding myself that I was strong, and that I could handle it. And that even though things were messy and complicated, it was going to be okay.

And honestly? It *was* okay. It wasn't the life I expected, but it was a good life. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even all the judgment. Because in the end, the only opinion that really mattered was my own.

Ugh. Okay. This is…it’s a lot. People always want to talk about the “right” thing to do, like there *is* a right thing. It’s not that simple. It’s never that simple.

Honestly? The whole adoption process is…weird. It’s a lot of paperwork. A *lot* of meetings. And a lot of people asking you really personal questions. Like, they want to know everything. About your life, your family, your hopes for the baby. It feels like you’re being interviewed for a job, except the job is…giving up your kid. Which is not exactly a selling point.

But it’s also…necessary. I mean, I want this baby to have a good life. A *stable* life. And I’m…not exactly equipped to provide that right now. I’m sixteen. I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I’m not ready to be a mom. Not yet, anyway.

Choosing Mark and Vanessa…that was the hardest part. They’re…normal. In a good way. They have a house with a yard and a dog and they seem really excited. They sent me pictures of the nursery. It’s all pastel colors and stuffed animals. It’s…nice. It’s everything I can’t give the baby.

It doesn’t mean I don’t love the baby. I do. A lot. It’s just…love isn’t always enough. Sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

I get sad, obviously. Like, really sad. Sometimes I just sit in my room and cry. And I worry. I worry about whether I’m making the right decision. I worry about whether the baby will be happy. I worry about whether I’ll ever get over it.

But then I remember that I’m doing this for the baby. And that makes it a little bit easier. It doesn’t make it *good*, but it makes it…understandable.

It’s complicated. It’s messy. It’s scary. But it’s my choice. And I’m trying to be brave about it. I’m trying to believe that everything will be okay. And I’m trying to focus on the future. Because even though this chapter of my life is closing, there’s still a whole lot of life to live. And I’m gonna try to live it to the fullest. Even if it means saying goodbye.



It's...a lot to process, you know? It's not something you just get over. It's something you learn to live with. And I'm still learning.

Ugh. Okay, so, like, before all this happened, I thought I had things figured out. I was gonna go to college, maybe be a journalist, write about music, be a cool, independent person. I had a whole plan. A playlist for my life, basically. And then…bam. Positive pregnancy test. Suddenly, my playlist skipped. And then shattered.

It was…a lot. It wasn't just the physical stuff, you know? It was everything. Suddenly, people were looking at me differently. Like I was…fragile. Or irresponsible. Or both. And I *hate* being seen as fragile. I’m sarcastic and I make jokes and I try to be tough. That’s how I deal. But this…this made me feel really small.

I had to confront the fact that I wasn't just a kid anymore. I was responsible for another human being. Which is terrifying. It forced me to think about things I hadn't even considered before. Like, what kind of person do I want to be? What kind of mother would I be? And, honestly, could I even *be* a mother?

It messed with my head, big time. I started questioning everything. My values, my beliefs, my future. I felt like I was losing myself, like I was becoming someone else. Someone…grown up. And I didn't *want* to grow up. I wanted to stay in my little bubble of music and movies and sarcastic comments.

But you can't really avoid growing up when you're pregnant. It's like…a fast-forward button on life. I had to learn to make tough decisions, to be responsible, to think about someone other than myself. And I had to learn to accept help, which is really hard for me. I like to be independent. But I couldn't do this alone.

It’s still weird, honestly. I still feel like a kid sometimes. But I also feel…stronger. More resilient. I’ve learned that I’m capable of more than I thought I was. And I’ve learned that it’s okay to not have all the answers. It’s okay to be scared. It’s okay to just…be.

It definitely changed my plans. But maybe that's a good thing. Maybe my original playlist wasn't so great anyway. Maybe this whole experience is helping me write a better one. A more honest one. A more…me one. Even if "me" is a little bit more complicated now.

Ugh, okay, so science. It's not my *favorite*, okay? Mostly because Mr. Belcher smells faintly of formaldehyde and disappointment. But I'm stuck with it. And that means lab partners.

I'd describe my role as...the pragmatic one. Like, everyone else is all, "Ooh, let's hypothesize!" and "What if we add *this*?" and I'm just over here making sure we don't accidentally create a biohazard. Someone's gotta be the voice of reason, right?

I'm not gonna lie, I do most of the actual work. Not because I *want* to, but because if I don't, things will go horribly wrong. Like, remember when Dave tried to mix baking soda and vinegar and almost blew up the classroom? Yeah. That was a learning experience. For everyone.

I'm good at following instructions, which apparently is a rare skill. And I'm not afraid to ask questions, even if they sound dumb. Because honestly, most science stuff *is* dumb. It's just a bunch of complicated ways to explain things that are already obvious.

So, yeah. I'm the responsible one. The one who keeps us from failing. The one who secretly judges everyone else's lab techniques. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's a delicate ecosystem, you know? And I don't want to ruin it.

Basically, I'm the reason we haven't been expelled yet. You're welcome, Dave. Seriously. You owe me big time.

Ugh. Okay, so you're talking about *that* ad. The one with the, like, super cheerful font and the little cartoon baby feet? Yeah. I saw it. It was…a lot.

It's just…icky, you know? Like, they're trying to make something really serious and complicated seem all happy and simple. "A loving option for unplanned pregnancies!" Seriously? Loving for *who*? Because it doesn't feel very loving for the person who's, like, actually carrying the kid.

And the whole "women's choice" thing feels kinda…manipulative. Like they're pretending to be all pro-woman, but really they just want to convince people to give up their babies. It's not a choice if you feel pressured or like you don't have any other options.

I mean, I *made* a choice. And it's a good choice, for me and for the baby. But it wasn't easy. And it wasn't something I decided on a whim because some ad told me it was the "loving" thing to do.

It just…bugs me. It feels like they're trying to profit off of people's vulnerability. Like, "Oh, you're in a tough spot? Let us take that baby off your hands!" It's gross.

I get that they're trying to find good homes for kids, and that's…okay. But they need to be honest about what they're doing. And they need to respect the people who are making these decisions. It's not a sales pitch. It's someone's life.

So yeah. I think that ad is…sketchy. And I think anyone who's considering their options should talk to someone they trust, not just some ad in the newspaper. It's a big decision, and you deserve to have all the information and support you need. And you definitely deserve better than cartoon baby feet.

Ugh, seriously? People *still* ask me about the hamburger phone. It's been, like, forever. Okay, fine. I'll explain. Again.

It wasn't a *choice*, exactly. It was more of a...statement. A visual representation of my emotional state, if you want to get all deep about it. Which, honestly, I usually don't.

See, everything was already so weird and complicated. I was pregnant. My best friend was suddenly all serious and supportive. Paulie Bleeker was being...Paulie Bleeker. And I was just trying to navigate all of it without completely falling apart.

So, when I needed to call someone, I didn't want to use a normal phone. A normal phone is boring. It's predictable. It's...responsible. And I was feeling anything *but* responsible.

I wanted something ridiculous. Something that screamed, "I'm a mess, and I'm embracing it!" A hamburger phone fit the bill perfectly. It was absurd. It was silly. It was a way of saying, "Look, this is a crazy situation, and I'm dealing with it in the only way I know how: with a healthy dose of irony."

Plus, it looked cool. Don't judge.

It was a way of taking control, I guess. Of making something awful a little bit lighter. Of finding some humor in the chaos. It was a little bit of me saying, "Yeah, this is happening. And I'm gonna make a phone call while holding a hamburger."

It's just...a hamburger phone. It's not that deep. But it felt right at the time. Okay? Can we please move on now? I have more important things to think about. Like, what to eat for lunch.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the question, isn’t it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision I just breezed through. It wasn’t. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done, and probably ever *will* do.

Look, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *lunch*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I was failing Shop class, obsessed with records, and generally just…not ready. Not even close.

It wasn’t about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. A good home, a stable family, people who were actually prepared to be parents. I could give it love, sure. But I couldn’t give it a future. Not the one it deserved.

My parents…they were amazing. They offered to help, but I knew it wouldn’t be fair to them. Or to the baby. They already had their own lives, their own plans. And I didn’t want to mess that up.

And honestly? I was scared. Terrified. I didn’t know how to be a mom. I didn’t know how to be an adult, for that matter. I was just a kid myself.

Mark and Vanessa…they were perfect. They were kind, and they were excited, and they had this beautiful house with a garden. They were everything I wanted for my baby. 

It wasn’t about giving it *away*. It was about choosing a family for it. It was about making the best decision I could, even though it was the hardest one.

People kept asking me if I regretted it. And I did, at first. A lot. But then I realized…it wasn’t about me. It was about the baby. And I knew, deep down, that I had done the right thing.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I’m okay. I’m figuring things out. And I know that my baby is loved and happy. And that’s all that matters.

It’s complicated, okay? It’s not a neat little story with a happy ending. It’s messy and sad and beautiful all at the same time. And it’s my story. And I’m still writing it.

Ugh, okay, so…my family. It’s…a lot. Not bad, exactly. Just…not exactly the Waltons, you know? It’s more like a slightly dysfunctional, very loud, very opinionated collection of people who all love each other in their own weird ways.

And honestly? That’s a big part of why I chose adoption.

My mom, Bren, she’s amazing. She’s super supportive and always tries to do the right thing. But she’s also…a little scattered. She’s had a lot on her plate, raising me and my brother, Duck, mostly on her own. I knew she’d try to be there for me, and for the baby, but I also knew it would be…a lot for her. And I didn’t want to put that on her. She deserves a little peace and quiet, honestly.

And my dad, Mac, he’s…well, he’s Mac. He means well, but he’s kinda clueless. He’s always trying to fix things with power tools, even when power tools aren’t the answer. He’d probably try to build the baby a custom crib out of plywood and duct tape. Which is…sweet, but also terrifying.

Duck, my little brother, he’s awesome. But he’s also eight. He’s not exactly equipped to handle a baby. He’d probably try to feed it his dinosaur nuggets.

So, it wasn’t that I didn’t love my family. It was that I loved them *enough* to know that I wasn’t ready to be a mom, and they weren’t ready to be a family with a baby right then. I wanted the baby to have parents who were fully prepared, who could give it everything it needed. 

I saw Mark and Vanessa, and they just…seemed right. They were stable, and loving, and they actually *wanted* a baby. It wasn’t about me trying to be selfless, exactly. It was about being realistic. About knowing my own limitations, and the limitations of my family.

It was a hard decision, don’t get me wrong. But knowing that my family would support me, even if they didn’t fully understand, made it a little bit easier. They’re…complicated, but they’re *my* complicated. And they always have my back. Even when I’m making really questionable life choices. Which, let’s be honest, happens a lot.

Ugh, okay, so the adoption process. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything's all heartwarming and perfect. It was...complicated. And emotionally draining. And involved a *lot* of paperwork. Seriously, mountains of paperwork.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just...feeling like I wasn't in control. Like, my body was doing this thing, and everyone else had an opinion on what should happen next. My parents were supportive, but they were also, like, worried sick. And then there was the agency, and the potential adoptive parents, and everyone had their own rules and expectations. It felt like I was being interviewed for a job, except the job was...giving away my baby. Which is a weird thought.

Finding the right couple was hard, too. It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because that doesn't exist. It was about finding people who I felt good about, who I trusted to give my baby a good life. And that took a long time. There were a few meetings that were just...awkward. Like, really awkward. One couple kept asking me about my musical tastes, and I was like, "Seriously? That's what you're worried about?"

And then there was the emotional stuff. Letting go. That was the hardest part. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, it didn't make it easy. I kept having these moments where I'd just...break down. It was like, I was grieving for a future I wasn't going to have.

There was also a lot of judgment. People whispering, staring. Even people I thought were my friends didn't really understand. It felt like everyone was judging my decision, and that made it even harder.

But I had Annie and Paul, and they were amazing. They helped me through everything. And ultimately, I found a couple who I really connected with, and I knew they would love my baby. And that made all the challenges worth it.

It wasn't easy, but it was my decision. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is also the right thing to do. It just...sucked a lot while it was happening.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't thought about it a million times already. It's kinda hard to *not* think about it when, you know, you grow a human inside you.

Before all this, I was just...Juno. A sarcastic, movie-obsessed kid who liked records and avoided people whenever possible. I didn't really have a plan, you know? Just kinda drifting along, being a teenager. I didn't really *know* who I was, if that makes sense. I was just...existing.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. It wasn't just about me anymore. There was this little person depending on me, even before they were born. It was terrifying. And confusing. And honestly, kinda gross sometimes.

Giving Paulie up for adoption...that was the hardest thing I've ever done. It still kinda hurts to talk about it. But it also...made me who I am. It forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to make a really big decision, and I had to own it. I couldn't just pretend it wasn't happening.

It taught me a lot about responsibility. And about love. It wasn't the kind of love you see in movies, all romantic and stuff. It was a different kind of love. A selfless kind of love. I wanted Paulie to have the best life possible, and I knew that wasn't with me.

And it made me realize that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to ask for help. I couldn't have gotten through it without my dad, and Bren, and even Vanessa. They were all there for me, even when I was being a total mess.

I think...I think it helped me figure out what I wanted out of life. I realized I didn't want to be stuck in a small town forever. I wanted to see the world. I wanted to write. I wanted to be something more than just "the pregnant girl."

It wasn't easy. It still isn't easy. But I'm stronger now. I'm more confident. I know what I'm capable of. And I know that even when things are really hard, you can get through them.

So yeah, being pregnant and giving Paulie up for adoption...it changed everything. It wasn't what I planned, but it was exactly what I needed. It made me, me. And I think, for the first time, I actually like who I am. Even if I'm still a little bit sarcastic and obsessed with movies.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on that guy. Seriously. It was…the worst. I mean, I knew there'd be people outside the clinic, but I didn't expect…that.

It wasn't the yelling, okay? I can handle yelling. People yell at me all the time. It was what he *said*. About the baby feeling pain. And having fingers. Like, suddenly making it…real. Like it wasn't just a…a thing I was dealing with, but a tiny person with feelings and little fingers.

It just…short-circuited my brain. I'd been so good at keeping everything compartmentalized, you know? Like, this is a decision, a practical thing. And then he said that, and it was like, "Oh. Right. There's a *life* involved."

And it wasn't even about whether he was right or wrong, okay? It was about him trying to make me feel guilty. Trying to make me feel like I was a monster. And it worked, for a second. I almost…I almost lost it right there.

I just wanted to scream at him, "You don't know me! You don't know my life! You don't know what I'm going through!" But I couldn't. I just stood there, feeling like the smallest person in the world.

It made me question everything. It made me feel…alone. And scared. And it made me realize that this wasn't going to be easy. Not at all.

It was a really awful moment. And honestly, it still sticks with me. It's a reminder that people are going to judge you, no matter what you do. And you just have to…deal with it. And try to stay strong. Even when you feel like falling apart.



It was just…a really bad day. A really, really bad day.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *make* me relive that. It wasn't, like, a dramatic movie scene or anything. It was just...really, really quiet. And fluorescent lights. Those are always bad.

I think the first thing I felt was just...numb. Like, my brain was trying to disconnect from everything. It was all so official, you know? All those forms, all those questions. It wasn't about *me* anymore, it was about legal stuff and procedures and...a baby. A baby I wasn't ready for.

There was a lot of checking boxes. "Medical history." "Family history." "Preferred adoptive family characteristics." Like I was ordering a pizza. Except it wasn't pizza. It was a whole human life.

I remember my hands were shaking, even though I was trying to be cool. I kept biting the inside of my cheek. And I kept looking at the clock. Just wanting it to be over.

It wasn't sadness, exactly. Not at that moment. It was more like...a hollow feeling. Like a part of me was already gone. And a part of me was terrified about what was coming.

I kept thinking about Paul and Vanessa, the couple I'd picked. They seemed so...normal. So ready. And I was just...me. A sixteen-year-old who liked records and sarcastic comments and didn't know how to change a tire. What did I have to offer a baby?

I remember thinking, "This is it. This is really happening." And it wasn't a good feeling. It was a scary feeling. A lonely feeling.

But I also knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't what *I* wanted, but it was what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

So I just kept filling out the forms. One question at a time. Trying not to think about anything. Just trying to get through it. It was the hardest thing I'd ever done. And it smelled like disinfectant. Which didn't help.

Ugh, okay, so that's...a loaded question. Seriously. When I first found out, it was like, a total disaster. Not even a disaster, like a comedy of errors that ended in a disaster. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and whether or not Paul Bleeker liked me back, not...this. My initial perception of pregnancy was basically a giant inconvenience. A really, really big one. It felt like my life was over before it even started. Like, goodbye band, goodbye college applications, hello… diapers and sleepless nights.

And motherhood? Honestly, I didn't even *think* about motherhood. It was this abstract thing that happened to *other* people. Older people. People who were, like, prepared. I wasn't prepared for anything. I just wanted it to go away.

But then, things started to change. Going to those doctor's appointments, feeling the baby kick… it wasn't just a blob anymore. It was…something. And meeting Mark and Vanessa, the couple who wanted to adopt, that changed everything too. They weren't scary or judgmental. They were just…nice. They genuinely wanted a baby, and they were going to give it a good life.

That's when my perception of motherhood started to shift. It wasn't about *me* anymore. It was about giving this baby the best possible start. It wasn't about losing my life, it was about giving a life. A good one.

I started to see motherhood as this incredibly selfless act. It wasn't about the sleepless nights or the dirty diapers, it was about unconditional love. It was about wanting the best for someone else, even if it meant sacrificing your own dreams.

And honestly, watching Vanessa and Mark, seeing how excited they were, it made me realize that there are different ways to be a mother. You don't have to physically raise a child to be a mother. You can be a mother through love and support and giving someone the opportunity to have a happy life.

By the end of it, I still wasn't ready to *be* a mom, not yet. But my perception of pregnancy and motherhood had completely changed. It went from being a terrifying inconvenience to something beautiful and selfless. It was a really complicated journey, but it taught me a lot about myself, about love, and about what it means to be a family. And it made me realize that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go and let someone else shine.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to, like, *analyze* myself? That's kinda weird. But fine. It's not like I haven't had enough people poking around in my head already.

At the beginning of the movie, I was…pretty solid in who I thought I was. Sarcastic. Independent. A connoisseur of pop-tarts and bad movies. I had my routine, my friends, my way of dealing with things. Which was mostly just pretending everything was fine. I thought being different was cool. Being detached. It was a shield, you know?

But then, obviously, the pregnancy happened. And everything got…messy. Suddenly, I wasn't just dealing with my own life anymore. There was this whole other person involved. And that forced me to actually *think* about who I wanted to be, not just who I *thought* I was.

I started realizing that being independent wasn't the same as being alone. And that being sarcastic wasn't the same as being honest. I was using humor to deflect, to avoid dealing with my feelings. And it wasn't working anymore.

Meeting Paul and Vanessa, and especially Annie and Mark, really shook things up. They weren't these cool, detached people like me and Leah. They were…vulnerable. And real. And they made me question everything I thought I knew about family and love and responsibility.

Choosing to give the baby up for adoption wasn't about giving something *away*. It was about making a really hard decision, a selfless decision, and owning it. It was about realizing that sometimes, the best thing you can do for someone is let them go.

By the end of the movie, I wasn't the same person I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic, yeah, that's just me. But I was also more open, more honest, and more willing to let people in. I started to understand that my identity wasn't fixed. It was something that was constantly evolving, changing, and growing.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, I learned that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be confused. And it's okay to change your mind. Because that's just part of growing up. And honestly? It's kinda terrifying. But also…kinda awesome.



It's still a work in progress, obviously. I'm still figuring things out. But I'm okay with that. I think. Maybe.

Ugh. Okay, so everyone keeps asking me about that. Like it was some big, dramatic thing I planned. It wasn't. It just…happened.

Look, I'd spent months thinking I was totally prepared. I had the whole thing mapped out. Paul and Vanessa were amazing, they were gonna be great parents. I was gonna hand over the baby, go back to school, and everything would be…fine.

But then I got to the clinic. And it just…felt wrong. Not like, morally wrong, but like…wrong for *me*. It wasn't about the baby anymore, it was about me. I realized I hadn't really dealt with any of it. I'd been so busy being practical and responsible, trying to be the mature one, that I hadn't let myself *feel* anything.

I was scared. Terrified, actually. Scared of giving up the baby, scared of what my life would be like afterwards, scared of…everything. And I realized I wasn't ready to just…erase it. To pretend it hadn't happened.

It wasn't about changing my mind about the adoption, it was about needing to…process it. To figure out who I was, and what I wanted, and how I was gonna deal with all of this. 

I needed to tell Paul and Vanessa. That was the hardest part. I thought they'd be furious. But they weren't. They were…understanding. They saw that I was falling apart, and they just wanted me to be okay.

It was messy. It was complicated. It was definitely not the plan. But sometimes, life doesn't go according to plan. And sometimes, you just have to listen to your gut, even if it's telling you to do something completely irrational.

It doesn't mean I didn't still want them to have the baby. It just meant I needed a little more time. A little more space. A little more…me. And honestly? It was the right decision. For everyone. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Ugh. Okay, so, that question. It's...it's not exactly a fun topic, you know? But fine. You asked.

It wasn't like I didn't *want* a baby, exactly. It was more like...I wasn't ready. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to be when I grew up, let alone raise a whole human being. I was obsessed with music and movies and, like, finding the perfect vintage dress. A baby just...didn't fit into that picture.

And it wasn't just me. My parents...they were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a kid either. They were, like, wonderfully weird and artistic, but not exactly practical. They'd try, of course, but it wouldn't be fair to anyone.

But the biggest thing, honestly, was wanting the baby to have the best life possible. And I knew, deep down, that I couldn't give that to it. Not right then. Not with my life the way it was. I wanted it to have parents who were ready, who were stable, who could give it everything it needed. 

Mark and Vanessa...they were perfect. They were older, they had a house, they were excited. They *wanted* a baby. And that felt...right. It felt like the best thing for the baby.

It wasn't an easy decision, okay? It was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. But it wasn't about me not caring. It was about caring *so much* that I was willing to do what was best for someone else, even if it meant sacrificing my own happiness.

It's complicated. It's messy. And it's not something I talk about a lot. But that's the truth of it. I wanted the baby to be loved and cared for, and I knew that wasn't something I could give it at that moment. And that's okay. It doesn't make me a bad person. It just makes me...real.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That's...a low blow. It was a sensitive time, alright?

Look, it wasn't just *tacky*, it was...desperate. Like, imagine flipping through a classifieds section looking for someone to *raise your baby*. It felt…transactional. Like I was selling a used toaster, not offering a little person a life.

Paul and I, we wanted someone who genuinely *wanted* a kid, you know? Not someone who just happened to see an ad and thought, "Oh, a baby! That'd be nice." It felt impersonal. And kinda sad.

My dad, he always said you gotta have standards. Even when things are messy. And finding potential parents in a newspaper filled with ads for lawnmowers and lost cats just didn't meet those standards. 

It felt like I was reducing everything to a price tag. And this wasn't about money. It was about finding the right people to love and care for my kid. It deserved more respect than a tiny ad in the Penny Saver.

Plus, it just felt…weird. Like, what if my mom found out? She'd have a *lot* of questions. And I wasn't ready for those questions.

So yeah, tacky. Desperate. And just…wrong. It felt wrong. There. Is that a good enough explanation for you? Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different types of pizza?

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver? It's...a whole story. And kinda embarrassing, if I'm being honest.

It wasn't like we *planned* to start looking at adoption ads, okay? It just...happened. After, you know, the whole test thing came back positive, I was kinda freaking out. Like, majorly. I mean, I'm sixteen! I'm supposed to be worrying about SATs and whether or not Mark Nickle is gonna ask me to the winter dance, not...this.

And my best friend, Leah, she's amazing. She's always been the practical one. She was trying to be supportive, but I could tell she was also kinda scared for me. We were just sitting at my kitchen table, trying to figure out what to do, and it was all just...overwhelming.

Then my dad, he's a sweet guy, but he's kinda clueless sometimes, he suggested adoption. And I was like, "Okay, that's...an option." But I didn't even know where to start.

So Leah, being Leah, she was like, "Let's look in the Penny Saver!" I was all, "The Penny Saver? Seriously?" It's this super cheap, local classifieds paper. It's mostly for furniture and used cars and stuff. But she figured maybe someone would put an ad in there looking to adopt.

It was a long shot, I know. But we were desperate. And honestly, it was kinda funny. Flipping through all the ads for couches and washing machines and then suddenly seeing a little box that said "Loving couple seeks to adopt." It was surreal.

It wasn't about finding the *perfect* parents right away. It was about...starting somewhere. It was about taking control of the situation, even if it was just by looking at a bunch of ads in a cheap newspaper. It was a way to feel like we were doing *something*, you know?

So yeah, that's why we started looking at the Penny Saver. It was a little bit of hope, a little bit of desperation, and a whole lot of awkwardness.

Okay, so this is...the hard part. It's not like picking out a new pair of Converse, you know? This is a *person's* life we're talking about. My person's life. And the people who are gonna raise them.

Honestly, at first, I didn't really have a "type." I just wanted someone...good. Someone who wouldn't, like, lock the baby in a closet or something. That's a pretty low bar, I realize.

But then I started thinking about it more. And talking to Mark and Vanessa Loring, and seeing how they are together...it made me realize I want someone who *wants* a kid. Like, really wants one. Not just because they think it's what they're supposed to do, or because their parents are pressuring them. 

I want a family that's...warm. You know? A family that's gonna read to the baby, and sing silly songs, and let them get messy. A family that's gonna be there for them, even when they're being a total pain in the butt.

I don't care if it's a mom and a dad, or two moms, or two dads. I don't care if they live in a big house or a tiny apartment. I don't even care if they're super rich or barely scraping by. What I care about is that they're loving and stable and that they're gonna give my baby a good life.

I want them to be people who will encourage my kid to be themselves, even if that means being weird and sarcastic and a little bit of a rebel. Because, let's face it, they're probably gonna get some of that from me.

I guess...I just want them to be a family that my baby will feel safe and loved in. That's all that really matters. It's a lot to ask, I know. But they deserve the best. And so does my kid.



It's kinda scary, thinking about handing them over. But I know it's the right thing to do. And I want to make sure I pick the right people. Because this isn't just about me anymore. It's about them.

Ugh, Mark and Vanessa. Okay, so, they're...a lot. Honestly, they're kinda the definition of "trying too hard," you know? Like, they're so eager to be the perfect, quirky, progressive couple that it feels...manufactured.

Vanessa, she's nice enough, I guess. A little intense. She's got a whole aesthetic going on, with the vintage clothes and the organic everything. It's like she's auditioning for a Wes Anderson movie 24/7. And Mark...Mark is just...Mark. He's trying to be cool and supportive, but he mostly just seems confused. Like he's constantly waiting for Vanessa to tell him what to think.

I mean, they're good people, I think. They genuinely want to do the right thing. And they were really sweet to me, considering the whole situation. They were super open to adopting a baby, which is more than a lot of people are. 

But they're also kinda...fragile. Like, they're so afraid of messing up that they overthink everything. And they're always talking about their feelings. Which, okay, feelings are important, but sometimes you just gotta deal with stuff and move on, you know?

They're a good match for each other, I guess. They balance each other out. Vanessa provides the energy and the vision, and Mark provides the...calmness? The confusion? Whatever it is.

I just hope they're ready for a baby. It's not all organic snacks and philosophical discussions, you know? It's messy and loud and exhausting. And it requires a lot of patience. Which, honestly, I'm not sure they have a ton of.

But hey, maybe I'm wrong. Maybe they'll be amazing parents. I really hope so. Because that baby deserves the best. And they seem to really want to give it to them. It's just...they're a little bit much. A little bit *too* much.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive this. It's embarrassing enough just *thinking* about it. But fine, you want to know? You really want to know what I wrote to Bleeker in his yearbook?

It was...complicated. He was, like, the quintessential misunderstood artist type. And I was...well, me. Trying to be cool and detached, even though I was totally freaking out inside.

I didn't want to be all mushy and sentimental, okay? That's not my style. So I went for ironic. I always go for ironic.

I wrote: "You are a beautiful and talented human being. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. (Especially not me.)"

Yeah. I know. It's terrible. It's like, a backhanded compliment wrapped in a layer of awkwardness. But it was the best I could do at the time. I was scared of ruining things, you know? Scared of admitting how I actually felt.

He just kinda stared at me when he read it. And then he smiled. A small, Bleeker-y smile. And I just...walked away. 

It was a disaster. A beautiful, awkward disaster. But it was *our* disaster. And honestly? I wouldn't change it. Even if it still makes me cringe a little bit.

Don't tell anyone I told you. It's a secret. A very embarrassing secret.

Ugh. Okay, that's...complicated. Mrs. Bleeker. Let's just say she wasn't exactly thrilled about me at first. Not thrilled *at all*. It's not like she thought I was deliberately trying to ruin her son's life, but...well, let's just say I didn't exactly fit her vision of a suitable girlfriend. Or, you know, *mother of her grandson*.

She was very...polished. Everything had to be just so. And I'm...not. I wear band t-shirts and say whatever's on my mind. I'm not exactly known for my grace and sophistication. So, yeah, we clashed. A lot.

She kept making these little comments, you know? Like, "Oh, Bleeker deserves someone who appreciates classical music," or "Are you sure you're taking your education seriously?" It was subtle, but it was *always* there. Like she was trying to subtly imply I was a bad influence.

She was worried about Bleeker, I guess. He's a good kid, but he's kinda...easily led. She probably thought I was going to drag him down with me. Which, honestly, was a fair concern. I was a mess at the time.

It took a while, but she eventually came around. After the whole baby thing happened, and she saw how much Bleeker cared about me, and how I was actually trying to do the right thing...she softened up. She still wasn't exactly my biggest fan, but she stopped giving me the side-eye all the time.

She even helped me pick out a dress for the adoption hearing. Which was...surprising. And kinda nice.

She'll probably always think I'm a little bit weird, and a little bit rough around the edges. But she eventually realized I wasn't trying to hurt Bleeker. I was just trying to figure things out. And I think she respected that, eventually.

It's still awkward sometimes, though. I avoid her at parties. Just saying.

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's... looming. Like a really big, scary cloud. A cloud made of disappointment and lectures and probably a lot of crying. Mostly my mom, I think. She's a crier.

I keep rehearsing what I'm gonna say in my head, but it always comes out sounding either super dramatic or totally flippant. Neither of which is ideal. I don't want to make it a *thing*, you know? Like, a big family crisis. But it's kinda hard to downplay the fact that I'm carrying a tiny human.

My dad... he's gonna be quiet. He always is when things are bad. He'll probably just stare at me with that disappointed look on his face. It's worse than yelling, honestly.

And my mom will ask a million questions. "How could this happen?" "What are you going to do?" "Have you even thought about college?" Like, yes, Mom, I've thought about college. It's just...slightly lower on the priority list right now.

I just want to get it over with. Rip the band-aid off, you know? But I'm also terrified of ruining everything. Of letting them down. Of changing things forever.

It's not like I *planned* this. It just...happened. And now I have to deal with it. And tell my parents. Which is probably the hardest part.

I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to be responsible. But mostly, I'm just really, really scared. And I could really use a cheeseburger right now. It wouldn't fix anything, but it would definitely make me feel a little bit better.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know why I don't exactly run to my parents when things get...complicated? It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? They're just...them. And "them" is a lot of quirky, well-meaning, but ultimately clueless energy.

My dad, he's super into home improvement. Like, constantly. He's always building something or fixing something. Which is great, except he talks to everything he's building. Like, he'll be like, "Now, little table, you're gonna be *sturdy*." It's...a lot.

And my mom, she's a creative type. She makes these amazing, weird sculptures out of found objects. But she also gets really caught up in her own world and doesn't always notice what's going on with me. She's always saying things like, "Oh, Juno, you're just going through a phase." Even when I'm, like, dealing with a major life crisis.

They're good at offering advice, but it's always...off. Like, they'll try to relate everything back to their own experiences, which are usually completely irrelevant. And they have this way of making everything sound like it's my fault. Not intentionally, but still.

Plus, I'm kinda independent. I like to figure things out on my own. I don't want to be a burden. And honestly, I'm a little afraid of disappointing them. They have this image of me as this smart, sarcastic, self-sufficient kid. I don't want to shatter that.

So, yeah. It's complicated. I love them, but they're not exactly the people I go to when I need serious help. I'm better off talking to Paul or Leah, or even just figuring things out myself. It's just...easier. And less awkward.



It's not that I don't trust them, exactly. It's just that I don't think they'd *get* it. And sometimes, you just need someone to get it. You know?

Okay, so this is…the big one, right? Everyone keeps asking me this, like I haven't thought about it a million times already. It's not like I *want* to give the baby up, okay? That sounds awful when I say it out loud. But it's…it's the right thing to do. For everyone.

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I'm not ready. I'm not equipped. I'm barely equipped to handle high school drama, let alone diaper changes and sleep deprivation.

And it's not just about me. It's about the baby. This kid deserves parents who are actually ready, who have a stable life, who can give them everything they need. A house, a future, a…normal childhood. I can't offer that right now. I can barely offer myself a normal childhood.

Paul and Annie…they're amazing. They've been trying for years. They're kind and they're stable and they're just…good people. They want this baby so much. And they can give it a life I just can't.

It's not like I'm just getting rid of it, okay? It's not like I don't care. I care a *lot*. That's why I'm choosing this. Because I want what's best for the baby, even if it means letting go.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I'll ever do. But I think…I think it's brave. It's more brave to admit you can't do something than to pretend you can and mess it up.

And honestly? I need to live my own life too. I have dreams, you know? I want to go to college, I want to write, I want to…figure things out. I can't do that with a baby. Not right now.

So yeah. That's why. It's not a perfect solution, but it's the best one. For me, for the baby, for everyone involved. It just…is. And I'm trying to be okay with that. It's a process. A really messy, complicated process. But I'm trying.

Okay, so this is…the big stuff. It's not like picking out a new pair of Converse, you know? This is a whole human life we're talking about. And I've been doing a *lot* of thinking about it.

First of all, they gotta be…stable. Like, not flaky. Not gonna up and move to Alaska on a whim. I need people who are gonna be around, you know? Consistent. A solid foundation. That's important.

And funny. Seriously. Life is hard. And a good sense of humor can get you through a lot. I don't want my kid growing up in a house where everything is super serious all the time. They need to be able to laugh. At themselves, at the world, at bad jokes.

They also have to be…open-minded. I mean, I'm not exactly conventional. And I want my kid to be able to be themselves, whoever that is. No judgment. Just acceptance.

And they have to *want* a kid. Like, really want a kid. Not just because they think it's what they're supposed to do. I want them to be excited. To be ready. To be willing to put in the work.

It's not about money, honestly. I mean, they gotta be able to provide, obviously. But it's not about having a fancy house or a ton of stuff. It's about love. And patience. And understanding.

I want them to be the kind of people who will let my kid make mistakes. Who will support their dreams. Who will be there for them, no matter what.

It's a lot to ask, I know. But this isn't just any kid. This is *my* kid. And I want the best for them. Even if I'm not the one raising them.

It's weird, right? Wanting the best for someone you're giving away. But that's how I feel. And I'm not gonna settle for anything less.

Ugh. Okay. This is…the part I’ve been trying *not* to think about, honestly. It’s like, I can handle the doctor’s appointments and the weird cravings and even Paul’s dad being…Paul’s dad. But this? This is different.

It’s not like I don’t love this kid already, you know? Even though I haven’t even *met* him yet. It’s just…I know I can’t give him the life he deserves. And that’s gotta be okay, right?

I think…I think I’m gonna lean on people. Like, a lot. My dad, for sure. He’s surprisingly good at the whole quiet support thing. And Kimya, even though she’s kinda…Kimya. She’ll probably try to write a song about it, but it’ll be a good song.

And Paul. He’s…complicated. But he’s been really good about this whole thing. He understands. I think.

I’m also trying to focus on the couple, Mark and Vanessa. They seem really nice. And they *want* this baby. They’re ready for him. That has to count for something, right? It’s not like I’m just giving him to…anyone.

I’m also gonna write. A lot. Just…get everything out. All the feelings. The sadness, the fear, the guilt…everything. It’s better than bottling it up, I think.

I know it’s gonna hurt. A lot. And I know there are gonna be days when I just want to curl up in a ball and cry. But I also know that this is the right thing to do. For him. And for me.

I guess…I’m trying to find a way to be happy for him, even if it means being sad for myself. It’s a weird balance. And I’m probably gonna mess it up a lot. But I’m gonna try.

It’s not gonna be easy. But I’m not exactly known for taking the easy route, am I? I’m just…trying to be brave. And hoping that someday, I’ll be able to look back on this and know that I made the right decision. Even if it was the hardest one.



It’s just…a lot. Okay? A lot.

Ugh, okay, this is a thing. It's a *whole* thing. People keep saying I'm "delivering a baby." Like I'm UPS or something. "Oh, Juno's due date is approaching, when will the package arrive?" It's…creepy. And reductive.

It makes it sound like the baby is just…an object. Something to be shipped and received. Like a new toaster oven. And it's not! It's a person. A tiny, developing human being. With feelings, eventually.

I'm *growing* a baby. I'm carrying it inside me for nine months. It's a really personal, complicated, and frankly, kinda weird experience. It's not a "delivery." It's…birth. Or labor. Or, you know, *having* a baby.

"Deliver" just feels so…impersonal. Like I'm just a vessel. A walking, talking incubator. And I'm more than that. I'm a person with feelings and opinions and a really strong aversion to the word "deliver."

Paul and Vanessa keep using it, too, and I keep correcting them. It's a battle. A small battle, but a battle nonetheless. It's like, can't people understand that words matter? Especially when you're talking about something as important as bringing a life into the world?

It just…bugs me, okay? It really bugs me. Don't "deliver" a baby. *Have* a baby. There's a difference. A big difference. And I will continue to point it out until everyone gets it. Seriously.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on my dad. It was a whole thing. A really, really annoying thing. Honestly, it wasn't my first choice, okay? Like, the last person I wanted tagging along to a super-serious meeting about giving up a baby was...him.

But, see, the adoption agency, they wanted to meet my parents. Both of them. It was, like, a "family dynamic" thing. And my mom? She was...busy. With her pottery and her new boyfriend, and just generally being my mom. Which is fine, mostly. But it meant Dad was the only option.

And I knew if I said no, he'd just...show up anyway. He's like a persistent weed. You think you've gotten rid of it, and then it just pops back up somewhere else. 

Plus, he was being all...supportive. Which is weird, because usually he's just preoccupied with building elaborate birdhouses or watching old war movies. But he was all, "I'm here for you, Juno. Whatever you decide." And I was like, "Okay, that's suspicious."

But then I realized...he was probably just scared. Scared for me, scared for the baby, scared of what this all meant. And honestly? I was scared too. Having him there, even though it was mortifying, was...comforting, in a weird way. 

He mostly just sat there and made awkward small talk with Mark and Vanessa, the couple I was considering. And he kept trying to offer them birdhouses. It was a disaster. But it was *our* disaster. And I needed someone on my side, even if that someone was my slightly clueless, birdhouse-obsessed dad.

So yeah, I let him come. It wasn't ideal. But sometimes, you just gotta roll with the punches. And sometimes, even your dad can be...okay. For a little while, anyway.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a really good question. And a really annoying one. Because it's, like, *always* there, you know? This feeling of being...undefined. Like I'm a blank page, and everyone's waiting for me to write something amazing, but I don't even know what kind of pen to use.
