It's not that I don't have opinions. I have *tons* of opinions. About music, about movies, about people. But when people ask me what I *am*...what kind of girl I am...I just draw a blank. Am I a band geek? A movie buff? A sarcastic weirdo? All of the above? None of the above?

I used to think it was cool, being different. Being the girl who didn't fit in. But now...now it's kinda lonely. Everyone else seems to have it figured out. They know what they want, who they are. They have labels. And I'm just...Juno. Floating around, observing.

I think part of it is because everything happened so fast. The pregnancy, the adoption...it forced me to grow up way faster than I was ready for. And I didn't have time to figure out who *I* was before I had to figure out what I was going to do with a baby.

But I'm starting to think maybe it's okay to not have all the answers. Maybe it's okay to be a work in progress. Maybe being undefined isn't a bad thing. Maybe it means I'm still figuring things out.

It's just...it's scary, you know? Not knowing where you're going or who you're going to be. But I guess that's life. It's messy and unpredictable and confusing. And maybe the point isn't to find all the answers, but to just keep asking the questions.

So, how do I feel about not knowing what kind of girl I am? I feel...confused. And a little bit scared. But also...a little bit hopeful. Because maybe, just maybe, I get to decide. And that's kinda cool.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that. It was…a moment. A really awkward, uncomfortable moment. Like, the kind where you just want to burrow into the floor and become a rug.

So, Dad and Mark are having one of their…discussions. Which is code for “Mark is being all intense and Dad is trying not to explode.” And it was getting *bad*. You could practically cut the tension with a butter knife. And then Bren – my stepmom – just casually drops, “Girls, why don’t you go upstairs?”

Like, seriously? As if that was gonna magically fix everything. As if me and Leah weren't totally aware of what was going on. We're not stupid. We can *feel* the weirdness radiating off of them.

I just…stared at her. Like, a really long, hard stare. And then I said, all sarcastic and deadpan, “Oh, right. Because running away from problems always solves everything.”

Leah, being Leah, just giggled nervously. She's a good egg, but she doesn't always get the sarcasm.

It wasn't about wanting to avoid the fight, exactly. It was about…being treated like little kids. Like we couldn't handle knowing what was going on. Like our feelings didn't matter. 

I mean, I get it. Bren was trying to protect us. But it just felt…patronizing. And it made the whole situation even more awkward.

I ended up just saying, “We’re good,” and plopping back down on the couch. Leah and I spent the next hour silently judging everyone and eating cookies. It was a much better use of our time, honestly.

It just…highlighted everything that was messed up about the whole situation. And it made me realize that sometimes, adults are just as clueless as teenagers. Maybe even more so.

Ugh. Okay, so that's...complicated. It's not like a simple yes or no, you know? It's a whole mess of feelings crammed into one question.

At first, I was kinda freaked out by the idea. Like, *too* much contact. I was trying to wrap my head around giving the baby up in the first place, and then suddenly it's, "Oh, and we'll send you pictures every month and you can come to birthday parties!" It felt...intense. Like I wasn't really letting go.

But then I talked to Paul and Annie, and they explained it better. They said it wasn't about replacing them, or making me feel like I was still the mom. It was about being honest with the kid. About letting them know where they came from. And about me being able to see that they were okay. That they were loved.

And honestly? That last part is the biggest thing. I'm not gonna lie, it's gonna be hard. Really hard. Seeing pictures of the baby growing up, knowing I'm not the one raising them...it's gonna suck. But knowing they're happy and healthy? That's...important.

It's like, I want to be a part of their life, but not *in* their life, you know? It's a weird line to walk. I don't want to be a ghost, but I also don't want to mess things up for them and Paul and Annie.

So, yeah. I think I'm okay with it. I think it's a good thing. As long as everyone's on the same page and we can all be respectful of each other's boundaries. It's still scary, but...maybe it's the least scary option. It's a way to make sure everyone gets what they need. Even me. Even if what I need is just to know they're okay.

It's just...a lot to process. It's not like something you figure out overnight. It's gonna take time. And a lot of deep breaths. And probably a lot of listening to The Moldy Peaches.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. That was…not good. Not good *at all*. It was like, I was already trying to wrap my head around giving the baby up, which is hard enough, right? Like, a whole person growing inside of me that I'm gonna…not raise. It's a lot.

And then Gerta just casually drops that bomb. "Oh, by the way, legally, you're just…done." Like I was a broken toaster she was returning to the store.

It wasn't the *baby* part that got me, not exactly. It was the feeling of being completely erased. Like I didn't even matter anymore. Like my feelings, my choices, my whole existence was just…irrelevant. 

I mean, I knew it was an open adoption, which meant I'd get updates and stuff. But to hear it laid out like that, that I wouldn't have any *legal* say in anything, ever again…it was terrifying. It made me feel so small and powerless.

It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I just giving up my rights, my responsibilities, my whole future? Was I being selfish, or was I being selfless? It was a total mess of emotions.

I tried to play it cool, you know? Make a joke. "So, like, I'm a ghost?" But inside, I was freaking out. It was a really hard thing to process. It made me realize how much I was already attached to this baby, even though I hadn't even met it yet.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize that this wasn't just about giving a baby a good home. It was about me, too. About my future. And about making a decision that I could live with, even if it was the hardest thing I'd ever done. It was…a lot.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, look, don't get me wrong. She's nice. And she clearly wants a kid, like, *really* bad. But it's...intense. It's like, she's been planning this whole life around having a baby, and it's kinda freaky.

I mean, I get wanting a family. Eventually. Maybe. But she's got this whole nursery already decorated and a list of names a mile long *before* even meeting the dad. It's a lot. It feels...forced, you know? Like she's trying to fill a hole with a baby.

And it's not that I think she wouldn't be a good mom. She probably would be. She's responsible and stable and has a nice house. But being a mom isn't about having the perfect house or the perfect plan. It's about...love. And chaos. And figuring things out as you go. And I don't know if she's ready for the chaos part.

It's just...she's so focused on the *idea* of being a mom, she's kinda missing the point. It's not about getting a baby, it's about raising a human being. And that's a big responsibility.

I guess I just feel bad for the kid, you know? Like, they're gonna be born into this perfectly planned life, and they might not have any room to be themselves. 

It's not my place to judge, obviously. It's her life. But it makes me appreciate Paul and Annie even more. They're not perfect, but they're real. And they're willing to let me make my own decisions, even if they don't always agree with them. And that's what matters.

It's just...Vanessa's whole situation is a little unsettling. It makes me think about what I want for my baby, and what kind of life I want to give them. And it makes me realize that it's not about having everything perfect. It's about having a family that loves each other, flaws and all.

Ugh, Mark. Honestly? He's...a lot. And his answer about being a dad? It's classic Mark. All rambling and philosophical and kinda missing the point.

Like, he goes on and on about how everything changes and how you have to be responsible and how it's a whole new level of existence. Which, okay, yeah, true. But it's like he's trying to sound *deep* instead of just saying, "Yeah, it's scary, but I'm gonna try my best."

It's the same with everything with him. He overthinks it. He wants to be seen as this profound, artistic soul, and he gets so caught up in the *idea* of being a dad that he forgets about the actual baby part. 

I mean, he's a good guy, don't get me wrong. He's sweet and he tries. But he's also kinda clueless. And his answer just felt...performative. Like he was trying to impress someone.

I think a real dad answer would be something like, "I'm terrified, but I'm gonna learn as I go." Or, "I have no idea what I'm doing, but I'm gonna figure it out." Something honest. Something real.

But that's just me. I'm not exactly known for my subtlety. I just say what I think. And what I think is that Mark needs to chill out and just be a dad. It's not about being profound, it's about changing diapers and singing lullabies and being there for the kid. It's about the little things. And Mark? He tends to miss the little things.

Ugh, okay, the Loring's house. Don't even get me started. It's not like they're *bad* people, okay? They're just...intense. And everything in their house is, like, beige. Beige furniture, beige walls, beige *everything*. It's suffocating. It feels like being inside a giant oatmeal cookie.

But that's not even the main reason I feel weird being alone there. It's just...they're *trying* too hard. Like, they want everything to be perfect. And they want me to be perfect too, I think. They keep offering me organic snacks and asking if I'm "feeling nurtured." Nurtured?! I'm a teenager, not a baby bird.

And they talk about the baby *constantly*. Like, it's not a person yet, it's a project. A perfectly curated, organic, beige-themed project. They have a whole nursery set up already, and it looks like a department store display. It's creepy.

It's like they're preparing for a doll, not a real human being. And I'm supposed to be the one giving them this real human being, and suddenly I feel like I'm being interviewed for a position. "Are you capable of providing a suitable environment for our future grandchild?" Seriously?

I just...I need space. I need to be able to be messy and imperfect and eat a bag of chips without being judged. And the Loring's house is the opposite of all those things. It's just...too much. It makes me feel like I'm going to explode.

So yeah, being left unsupervised there is not my idea of a good time. It's like being trapped in a Stepford Wives convention. And honestly, I'd rather hang out with Paul and Mark and listen to their terrible music than spend another minute in that beige nightmare.

Ugh. Okay, this is…a lot. It’s not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It’s still kinda raw, even after all this time.

It’s not like I *wanted* to give them a baby. It just…happened. And then I had to figure out what to do with it. And, like, everyone had opinions. My dad, my stepmom, even Paul. It was exhausting.

But Mark and Vanessa…they’re good people. Really good. They *want* this. They’ve been trying for a long time, and they’re gonna be amazing parents. They’re all…coordinated and have a matching furniture set, which is kinda terrifying, but also kinda sweet.

So, yeah, it feels…good. I guess. Knowing that the baby is going to a home where it’s wanted and loved. That’s the important thing, right? It’s not about me anymore. It’s about giving this kid the best possible life.

It’s also kinda sad. I mean, I’m not gonna lie. It’s weird thinking about someone else raising my kid. It’s like…a piece of me is going with them. But I know it’s the right thing to do. I’m not ready to be a mom. Not now. Maybe not ever.

I keep thinking about what it’ll be like when I see them, you know? Mark and Vanessa, with the baby. It’s gonna be…emotional. But I think I’ll be okay. I have to be.

It’s a gift, yeah. But it’s also a really complicated one. It’s not just a cute little baby in a blanket. It’s a whole life. And I’m trusting Mark and Vanessa to take care of it. And that’s…a big deal.

It’s just…a lot to process, okay? Can we talk about something else now? Like, the merits of different kinds of pizza? Please?

Ugh, okay, so you're bringing up the "ASAP" thing? Seriously? That was, like, months ago. But fine. I'll explain. It's not just about the "ASAP," okay? It's about *how* he said it.

Mark is...well, Mark. He's sweet, and he tries, but he's also kinda clueless. And he's always trying to be all mature and responsible, which is kinda funny because he's, like, barely older than me.

So he calls me, right? And he's all serious, like he's taking orders from the President or something. And he says, "Juno, I need the ultrasound pictures...ASAP."

*ASAP*. Like it's a matter of national security. 

It just...struck me as ridiculous. It's not an emergency, Mark! It's a picture of a tiny human! And the way he said it, all clipped and official...it was just begging to be mocked.

I mean, it's not like I *planned* to say what I said. It just kinda came out. It's a defense mechanism, okay? I make fun of things to deal with them. It's how I cope.

Plus, it was a good line. Let's be honest. "ASAP? Is that, like, some kind of code?" It was witty. I stand by it.

It wasn't about being mean to Mark. It was about pointing out how absurd the whole situation was. He was trying so hard to be a grown-up, and it was just...not working.

And honestly, he needed to be brought down a peg. He was getting a little full of himself.

So yeah, I mocked his "ASAP." Don't judge me. It was a moment of comedic brilliance. And it made me feel a little bit better about everything. Which, let's face it, I needed at the time.

Okay, so this is a surprisingly good question. Like, you actually *get* me a little bit. It's not all about babies and awkward conversations, huh?

My preferred guitar? Definitely a Fender Mustang. Specifically, a vintage one, if I could actually afford one. But a newer one will do.

Why? Okay, so, first of all, Kurt Cobain played one. Which, like, automatically makes it cool. Don't judge me. I was going through a Nirvana phase. Still kinda am, honestly.

But it's not just about Kurt. The Mustang is just...different. It's smaller than a Stratocaster or a Telecaster, which is good because I'm not exactly a giant. It feels comfortable in my hands. And it has this really unique sound. It's kinda jangly and raw, but also kinda smooth. It's hard to explain.

It's not a flashy guitar. It doesn't scream "look at me!" It's more...understated. Which is kinda how I like things. It's a guitar for people who just want to play, you know? Not for people who want to show off.

Plus, they're kinda hard to find. Which makes them even cooler. It's like, you have to *earn* the right to play a Mustang. 

I mostly just mess around with it, write kinda sad songs about life and stuff. It's a good outlet. It's a way to express myself when I can't find the right words.

So yeah. Fender Mustang. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation as a cynical teenager.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Melvins? That was, like, months ago. And honestly, it was a moment of weakness, okay? A lapse in judgment. A desperate attempt to seem cooler than I actually am.

Look, Paulie Bleeker is a sweet guy, don't get me wrong. But he's...enthusiastic. About everything. And he was *really* excited about the Melvins. Like, bordering on obsessive. And I just...I wanted him to like me. I wanted him to think I was interesting. I wanted him to think I had good taste in music.

So I panicked. And I said I was a huge fan. I'd heard the name, obviously. Everyone's heard of the Melvins. But I hadn't actually *listened* to them. I just assumed they were, like, good. Because Paulie said so.

It was a stupid move. And it totally backfired. Because then he started quizzing me about them. And I had no idea what I was talking about. It was embarrassing. Really embarrassing.

I just wanted to impress him, okay? Is that so wrong? I was a teenager. I was awkward. I was trying to figure things out. And sometimes, you do dumb things to try and fit in.

It wasn't about the Melvins, really. It was about wanting to be seen. It was about wanting to be liked. It was about wanting to be...enough.

And honestly, the fact that he still liked me *after* he found out I was lying? That was way more impressive than knowing all the lyrics to a Melvins song.

So yeah. I lied. I'm not proud of it. But it happened. And I learned a valuable lesson: just be yourself. Even if yourself is a little bit weird and doesn't know anything about obscure grunge bands. It's better than pretending to be someone you're not.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so describing that...it's complicated. It's not like, a sparkly, movie-moment kind of thing, you know? It's more...comfortable. And kinda quiet.

When we were just sitting there, him with his guitar and me trying not to sound like a dying cat, it was...easy. Like, the rest of the world kinda faded out. All the stuff with the baby and Paul and everything just...stopped being so loud.

He wasn't trying to impress me or anything. He wasn't all, "Oh, Juno, you're so quirky and unique!" He just...let me be. And he listened. Not just to my voice, but to what I was *trying* to say with the songs. 

It was like we were both speaking a different language, but we understood each other anyway. Music, I guess. It's stupidly cliché, but it's true.

And it wasn't just the singing. It was the little things. Like, he'd adjust the guitar strap so I could reach it easier, or he'd laugh at my terrible jokes. He just...got me. In a way that nobody else really did.

It wasn't romantic, not exactly. It was more like...a really good friendship. A really *safe* friendship. Like, I could be completely myself around him, and he wouldn't judge me. Which, let me tell you, is a rare thing.

It was a good feeling. A really good feeling. And I miss it, honestly. Even though it was just a few songs and a lot of awkward silences. It was...nice. It was a little pocket of normal in a really not-normal situation.



Don't read too much into it, though. It's not like I was secretly hoping he'd run away with me or anything. I had a baby to think about, for crying out loud. But it was...special. Okay? It was special.

Ugh, okay, this again. Everyone always asks about Roosevelt. It's not a deep, philosophical reason, alright? It just...happened.

I was at this garage sale with my dad, right? And I found this beat-up acoustic guitar. It was kinda sad-looking, but it had a good sound. And the guy selling it was wearing this really loud Hawaiian shirt with pictures of Theodore Roosevelt on it. Like, *covered* in Teddy Roosevelt.

And my dad, he's always trying to be funny, so he goes, "Well, looks like this guitar needs a president." And I just blurted out, "Roosevelt!" It just felt right. 

It's kinda ironic, I guess. Theodore Roosevelt was all about being strong and adventurous and, like, conquering things. And I was just this awkward teenager trying to figure out my life. But the name stuck.

Plus, it's a good name. It sounds solid. And it reminds me of my dad, which is...complicated, but good. He's a weirdo, but he's *my* weirdo.

So yeah. That's the story of Roosevelt. Don't overthink it. It's just a guitar name. It's not like I named my kid after a historical figure or something. Though, honestly, that wouldn't be the weirdest thing that's happened to me.

Ugh, okay, so the whole Vanessa and Mark thing. It's...complicated. It's not like I *want* to keep them in the dark, you know? They're good people. Mark's kinda clueless, but in a sweet way. And Vanessa...Vanessa's just trying to be supportive, which is nice, I guess.

But it's *my* pregnancy, okay? And it's *my* decision what happens with it. It feels weird, like they have a right to an opinion or something. Like they get to weigh in on whether or not I give the baby up for adoption. Which is just...no.

I mean, I appreciate that they care. And I know they're just trying to be helpful. But every time they ask about it, it feels like they're reminding me that I'm, like, a walking, talking responsibility. And I'm already stressed enough about that, thank you very much.

It's also just...awkward. They're a couple. I'm a teenager who accidentally got pregnant. It's not exactly a natural conversation starter.

I think I'll just keep it brief. Like, "Everything's going okay," or "Doctor's appointments are happening." No details. No emotional breakdowns. Just the bare minimum. 

I need to do this on my own terms, you know? I need to figure things out for myself. And I don't need Vanessa and Mark hovering over me, offering advice and sympathy. I just need them to...be there, if I need them. But not to ask a million questions.

It's hard to explain. It's just...my life. And I need to control it, even if it feels like it's spiraling out of control. Does that make sense? Probably not. I'm not good at explaining feelings. I'm better at making sarcastic comments. But yeah. That's how I feel about the whole keeping-them-updated thing. It's stressful. And I wish they'd just...chill.

Okay, look. People keep asking me this, like it's some huge, dramatic thing I'm agonizing over every second. And yeah, it's...big. It's definitely big. But it's not like I woke up this morning and decided, "Oh, sure, I'll just give away my baby!" It's been a lot of thinking. A *lot*.

And honestly? It's 104% sure because I'm not ready. Not even close. I'm sixteen. I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I'm barely figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a whole human being. 

It's not that I don't care about this baby. I do. A lot. That's kinda the problem. I want this kid to have everything. A stable home, parents who are actually prepared, a future that isn't...well, my life right now.

I'm not saying my life is terrible. It's just...complicated. My mom's great, but she's got her own stuff going on. And my dad...he's around. And Paul and Annie are amazing, but they're not gonna raise a baby for me. 

Mark and Vanessa? They're different. They *want* this. They've been trying for a long time. They're ready. They're gonna give this baby a good life. A better life than I can right now.

It's not about me not loving the baby. It's about loving the baby enough to make the hard choice. It's about wanting what's best for *them*, even if it means letting go.

And honestly? It's kinda freeing. It's like...I can still be a teenager. I can still go to school and listen to The Moldy Peaches and figure out who I am. I don't have to put my whole life on hold.

So yeah. 104% sure. It's the right thing to do. Even if it sucks. And it really, really sucks. But it's the right thing. And sometimes, you just gotta do the right thing, even when it's the hardest thing.



Don't ask me about it again, okay? It's kinda exhausting talking about it.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…weird. Really weird. Like, I get it, logically. They were getting what they wanted, right? A baby. A family. And I was, like, the logistical stepping stone to get there. But still.

It wasn't the *celebration* itself, exactly. It was the…speed of it. Like, one minute I'm crying in the driveway, trying to be all brave and mature, and the next they're popping champagne and talking about nursery colors. It felt…insensitive. Like I was just…gone. Erased.

I mean, I *wanted* to give the baby up. I made that decision. But it didn't make it easy. It didn't mean I didn't have feelings. And seeing them so instantly happy, so instantly moving on…it felt like they weren't acknowledging the whole thing was complicated. For *me*, at least.

It wasn't that I wanted them to be sad, obviously. I wanted them to be happy. But maybe a little bit of…acknowledgment? A little bit of, "Wow, this was a big thing for everyone"? 

I think I mostly felt…invisible. Like I was just a vessel. And that stung. A lot.

Paul, he got it. He was quiet and thoughtful. He knew it was a weird situation. But Gerta and Mark…they were just so focused on the future, on the baby, that they didn't really seem to see *me* in that moment.

It made me realize that sometimes, people just see what they want to see. And sometimes, that means they don't see you at all. It was a good lesson, I guess. A hard lesson. But a good one. It taught me that I needed to be my own person, and to not rely on other people to validate my feelings. Because sometimes, they just won't.

Ugh. Seriously? Are people *still* talking about that? It's like, can't a girl just...exist without everyone having an opinion on her reproductive choices? It's beyond.

Look, it's not exactly a secret, okay? I mean, it's kinda hard to hide a growing belly. But that doesn't mean everyone gets to dissect it and gossip about it like it's some kind of reality TV show. 

It's my life. My body. My decision. And honestly, it's a lot more complicated than people seem to think. It's not just about, like, "Oh, she got pregnant." There's a whole person involved. And a family. And a lot of feelings.

I try not to pay attention to the rumors. I really do. But it's hard when you hear snippets of conversations or see people staring at you. It makes you feel...exposed. Like you're a science experiment or something.

Paul's been really good about it, though. He's all, "Ignore them, they're just jealous they don't have your amazing bone structure." Which is...sweet, I guess. And Annie's been a rock. She just tells me to focus on what's important, which is the baby and making sure everything's okay.

But still. It's annoying. It's invasive. And it's just...rude. People should mind their own business, you know? 

I'm trying to do the right thing. I'm trying to make a good decision for everyone involved. And I don't need a bunch of strangers judging me while I'm doing it. Honestly, it's just...a lot. Can everyone just, like, chill? Please?

Ugh. Okay. That's...the big one, isn't it? Everyone keeps asking me about it, like it's some kind of math problem with a right answer. It's not. It's just...complicated.

Honestly? Some days, it feels totally right. Like, I'm doing the best thing for the baby. Giving it a life I can't give it right now. A stable home, two parents who are actually, you know, *ready* for a baby. That feels good. Responsible. Adult-y. Which is weird, because I'm, like, seventeen.

But then other days...it feels like ripping a piece of myself out. Like, this little person is already a part of me, even though it's not even born yet. And the thought of not being there for its first steps, or its first birthday...it sucks. It really, really sucks.

I try not to think about it too much. I focus on the practical stuff. Picking out the parents, making sure they're good people. That helps. It makes it feel less...abstract.

It's not what I planned, obviously. I didn't exactly picture myself as a pregnant teenager giving up her baby. But life rarely goes according to plan, right? 

I guess...I'm trying to be brave. And selfless. And I'm trying to believe that this is the right thing to do, even if it's the hardest thing I've ever done. It doesn't mean it doesn't hurt. It just means I'm trying to be a good person. And maybe that's enough.

It's just...a lot. Okay? A lot to process. And I'm still processing. Don't expect me to have all the answers. I barely have any answers about what I want for lunch.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole surprise baby gender thing with Mark and Vanessa? It's...complicated. It's not like I had some grand plan, okay? It just kinda *happened*.

See, Mark and Vanessa, they're...perfect. Like, aggressively perfect. They have the house, the careers, the matching sweaters. Everything is planned and organized and color-coordinated. It's kinda intimidating, honestly.

And they were so excited about picking out names and decorating the nursery and having everything *just so*. It was a little...much. Like they were building a perfect little human instead of, you know, actually *having* a baby.

I just...I wanted to shake things up a little. Give them something they couldn't control. Something unexpected. Life isn't always planned, you know? Sometimes things just *happen*. And you have to deal with it.

I figured if they didn't know if it was a boy or a girl, they'd have to actually think about the baby as a person, not just a project. They'd have to be open to whatever it was, instead of trying to force it into their perfect little world.

It was a little bit of a power move, I'm not gonna lie. Like, "Here, you guys deal with a little bit of uncertainty for once." But it was also...I don't know. A way of reminding them that life is messy and unpredictable. And that's okay.

Plus, I thought it would be kinda funny to see their faces when they found out. They were so serious about everything. It was nice to see them a little flustered.

So yeah. That's why I wanted the surprise. It wasn't about me, really. It was about them. And maybe a little bit about wanting to see them lose their composure for five seconds. Don't judge.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? That lady. I still get a twitch in my eye when I think about her. It wasn't even the *seeing* the little bean on the screen, which was…weird, to say the least. It was her. The whole vibe she was giving off. Like I was some statistic. Some problem to be solved.

She kept saying things like, "Oh, you're so young," and "Are you sure you've thought this through?" and, my personal favorite, "Most girls your age change their minds." Like I was gonna suddenly decide to keep it just because I saw a blurry picture of a tiny human?

It felt…dismissive. Like she didn't even see *me*. Just the stereotype. The teenage mom who's gonna regret everything. And it wasn't like I hadn't already thought about it a million times. I was already dealing with a lot, okay? I didn't need some stranger judging my life choices.

It made me want to just…get up and walk out. But I didn't. Because I needed to know everything was okay with the baby. And because I didn't want to give her the satisfaction of seeing me upset.

It just…reinforced everything I was already feeling. Like I was doing something wrong. Like I wasn't good enough. Like I was letting everyone down. Even though I knew, deep down, that I was making the right decision. For me. And for the baby.

It was just…a really crappy moment. And it made me realize that people are gonna have opinions, whether you ask for them or not. And you just have to tune them out and do what you know is right. Even if it's hard. Especially if it's hard.

Honestly, it made me want to write a really sarcastic song about judgmental ultrasound technicians. Maybe I will.

Ugh, okay, so you want the whole story, huh? Buckle up, because it wasn't exactly a walk in the park. It wasn't like in the movies, all cute and quirky. It was...messy. And real.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just...being sixteen and having to deal with something so huge. Like, everyone else was worrying about prom and getting their driver's license, and I was trying to figure out how to be a mom, even if it was just for nine months. It felt isolating, you know? Like I was on a different planet.

Then there was telling my parents. That was...rough. My dad was mostly just quiet and sad, and my mom was trying to be supportive, but I could tell she was freaked out. It took a while for us to all get on the same page. And even then, it was still awkward.

And then there was the whole *adoption* thing. That wasn't easy either. It's not like picking out a puppy. It's a person. A tiny human being. And trying to find the right parents for him...that was a lot of pressure. I wanted them to be perfect. Like, *really* perfect. And realizing that "perfect" doesn't exist was hard.

Dealing with Mark, the baby's dad, was also a challenge. He wasn't exactly stepping up, you know? He was a senior and just wanted to go to college and forget the whole thing happened. Which, okay, I get it. But it still stung.

And then there was just the emotional stuff. The hormones. The fear. The guilt. The sadness. It was a rollercoaster, seriously. One minute I was okay, the next minute I was crying over a commercial.

But I think the hardest part was just...accepting that I wasn't ready to be a mom. It wasn't that I didn't love the baby, it was that I knew I couldn't give him the life he deserved. And that was a really hard thing to admit.

It was a lot. A *lot*. But I got through it. With the help of my family, my friends, and a really awesome social worker. And I learned a lot about myself along the way. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is also the right thing to do.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was *my* ending. And that's what mattered.

Ugh. Okay, deep thoughts time. Don't judge me if I get all…emotional. It's not my usual thing.

Before all this…baby stuff, love was kinda just…movies. You know? Like, a grand gesture, a perfect moment, a soundtrack. It was all very dramatic and unrealistic. And responsibility? That was something my parents nagged me about. Like, "Do your homework!" and "Don't stay out too late!" It felt like a punishment, not something you *chose*.

And growing up? That was just…something that happened to other people. Old people. Definitely not me. I was perfectly content being sarcastic and avoiding anything remotely serious.

But then…well, then I found out I was pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. Love wasn't about romance anymore. It was about wanting the best for this little person, even if that meant giving them up. It was about Annie and Paul, and seeing how much they wanted a kid, and realizing they could give this baby a life I couldn't. It was a different kind of love. A selfless kind. Which is…weird.

Responsibility? That hit me like a ton of bricks. It wasn't just about doing what I was told anymore. It was about making a huge decision that would affect the rest of my life, and the life of this baby. It was scary, but also…empowering. I was in control. I got to choose.

And growing up…that happened fast. Like, really fast. It wasn't about getting older, it was about becoming someone different. Someone who could handle tough stuff. Someone who could think about other people before herself. Someone who wasn't afraid to be vulnerable.

I still don't have all the answers. I still don't know what I want to do with my life. But I'm not as scared anymore. I've learned that life is messy and complicated, and that's okay. And that even when things are really hard, there's always hope.

It's still weird to think about, you know? I'm still just Juno. But I'm…a little bit more Juno now. A more grown-up, more responsible, more loving Juno. And that's…good. I think.



Don't tell anyone I said all that, okay? It's embarrassing.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about *that* house? It's...complicated. It's not like I'm obsessed or anything. It's just...it's *there*. And it's weird.

It's this perfectly normal-looking house, right? But the front door's always open, and the living room is just...frozen in time. Like, someone just got up and left. There's a half-finished crossword puzzle on the coffee table, a knitted blanket draped over the couch, a chipped teacup on the side table. It's creepy, but also kinda sad.

I ride my bike past it every day on the way to school, and I always glance in. I don't know why. It's not like I'm trying to solve a mystery or anything. It just...makes me think.

About people. About lives. About how things can just...fall apart. You know? Like, one minute you're living your life, doing crossword puzzles and drinking tea, and the next minute...everything's gone.

I'm kinda going through a lot right now, obviously. With the baby and everything. And that house...it feels like a metaphor or something. Like, a reminder that life is messy and unpredictable. And that sometimes, things just get left unfinished.

It's also kinda comforting, in a weird way. Because it's proof that I'm not the only one who's messed up. That other people have had their lives derailed too.

So, yeah. I'm interested in the abandoned living room. Don't judge me. It's just...a thing. A weird, sad, thought-provoking thing. And honestly, it's way more interesting than algebra.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with the Wizard. That guy… seriously. Still gives me the creeps just thinking about him.

Okay, so, he whispers that whole "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" thing when I'm down there, trying to figure out if he's a total weirdo or just…sad. And honestly? It's not about the baby. Not *really*.

It's about him wanting a family. Like, a real one. He's been stuck down there in that basement for so long, just…existing. He's got all these weird, broken toys and a whole lot of loneliness. He's built this fantasy world, but it's not the same as having someone to actually *connect* with.

He sees me, and he sees a chance to finally have that. He thinks, maybe, if he can help create a life, it'll fill that hole inside him. It's messed up, I know. He's projecting all his hopes and dreams onto a teenager and a baby. It's totally inappropriate.

But it's also…kind of sad. He's a lonely guy who's made some really bad choices. He's trying to find meaning in a messed-up way.

It doesn't excuse his behavior, obviously. He's still a weirdo. But it explains it, a little bit. It's like, he's been waiting for something good to happen for so long, and he thinks this is it. 

And that's why it's so creepy. Because it's not about me, or the baby. It's about *him*. And his desperate need for something he can't have.

It's a lot to process, okay? I was sixteen. I was just trying to figure out what to do with my life, and this guy is dropping existential bombs on me. It's not fair. It's just…not fair.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're dissecting my juice container disposal habits now? Fine. It's a valid question, I guess. It's not like I was having a *moment* or anything.

Look, it wasn't just about the juice. It was about...everything. I'd just found out, like, officially, that I was actually going to have a baby. And it wasn't a cute, fuzzy, "aww" kind of moment. It was a "holy crap, my life is about to be completely different" kind of moment.

So, I marched down the street, trying to look all cool and collected, but inside I was totally freaking out. And the juice? It was just...symbolic. Like, getting rid of something empty. Something that wasn't going to cut it anymore.

And then I needed a pregnancy test. A *real* one. The ones at the drugstore are way more accurate than the cheap ones you get at the supermarket. Plus, Dancing Elk has those little magazines with the celebrity gossip. Distraction is key, okay? 

I needed to confirm it, to see it in black and white, and then...I needed to figure out what to do next. And maybe read about Britney Spears' latest meltdown. It's a coping mechanism. Don't judge.

It wasn't a logical decision. It was a panicked, hormonal, teenage-girl decision. But it was *my* decision. And sometimes, that's all that matters.

So yeah, that's why I rushed to Dancing Elk. It wasn't about the juice. It was about the future. And a desperate need for celebrity gossip. It's complicated.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. That was...a moment. A deeply awkward, profoundly unsettling moment.

Okay, so, I was at the drugstore, right? Trying to find some, like, extra-strength prenatal vitamins because my doctor was all, "You need more iron!" And I'm already feeling super self-conscious, because, you know, *pregnant teenager*. It's not exactly a confidence booster.

And this woman, this *Tough Girl* – and I use that term loosely, because honestly, she was just kinda rude – she just...stared at me. Like, a long, hard stare. And then, out of nowhere, she just blurts out, "Are those real brown?"

I was completely frozen. Like, a deer in headlights. I just blinked at her. And she was pointing. At my chest. Specifically, at my nipples.

I think my brain short-circuited for a good five seconds. I finally managed to stammer out something like, "Excuse me?"

And she just repeated it, louder this time. "Are those real brown? Because they look...painted on."

I wanted to disappear. I wanted the floor to swallow me whole. I wanted to punch her in the face, but I was, you know, pregnant. So that wasn't really an option.

I just mumbled something about needing to find vitamins and walked away as fast as I could. 

Honestly, I still don't know what that was about. Maybe she was just having a bad day. Maybe she was just a weirdo. Maybe she thought I was trying to pull off some kind of elaborate hoax. I have no idea.

It just...stuck with me. It was a reminder that people are going to judge you, no matter what. And sometimes, they're going to ask really, really inappropriate questions. And you just have to deal with it. And try not to cry.

It was a truly bizarre experience. And honestly? It's one of those things I'll probably be telling stories about for the rest of my life. Because, let's face it, it's a pretty good story. A really, really embarrassing story. But a good story nonetheless.

Ugh, Leah. Okay, so, Leah is…Leah. She's a lot. Like, a *lot* of everything. Loud, opinionated, always wearing band t-shirts, and fiercely loyal. And honestly? I would have been completely lost without her.

Before everything happened with Paul, Leah was just…my best friend. We spent hours at the record store, making fun of people at the mall, and complaining about our parents. She was the one person who actually *got* me, you know? She didn't try to change me or tell me what to do. She just…accepted me, weirdness and all.

When I found out I was pregnant, I didn't tell anyone at first. Not even my dad. I was terrified. But I *had* to tell Leah. And she didn't freak out. She didn't judge me. She just…listened. And then she started brainstorming, like, escape plans and fake IDs. Which, okay, wasn't super helpful, but it was the thought that counted.

She was the one who came with me to all the doctor's appointments. She held my hand when I was getting ultrasounds. She even helped me pick out baby names, which was…a disaster. Leah wanted to name the baby "Riot." Can you imagine?

But more than anything, she just kept me grounded. She reminded me that I was still Juno, even though I was also a pregnant teenager. She made me laugh when I wanted to cry. She distracted me when I was feeling overwhelmed. She was just…there.

And she didn't treat me like I was fragile or broken. She treated me like I was still the same sarcastic, independent person I always was. Which, honestly, was exactly what I needed.

Choosing adoption was a really hard decision. And Leah was the one who helped me work through it. She didn't try to tell me what to do, but she asked me all the right questions. She made me think about what was best for the baby, and for me.

So yeah, Leah was a huge part of my journey. She was my rock. My confidante. My partner in crime. I don't know what I would have done without her. Seriously. She's the best, even if she is a little bit crazy. Don't tell her I said that.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…a moment. A really, really awkward moment. Honestly, it wasn't some brilliant plan, okay? It was mostly desperation and a whole lot of "what the heck am I doing?"

See, I was trying to find parents for the baby, right? And I was meeting all these people, and they were all…nice. Too nice, maybe. Like, they were picking out baby names and talking about college funds before they even knew if they *wanted* a baby. It felt weird. Like I was selling a product or something.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were different. They were…real. They were struggling with stuff, you know? They weren't pretending everything was perfect. They were honest about wanting a family, but also about being scared.

But they were still kinda…distant. Like they were interviewing *me* to see if I was good enough for their baby. And I just…I couldn't handle it anymore. I needed them to see it. To see that this wasn't just some abstract idea. This was a *person*. A tiny, little person growing inside me.

So, I just…pulled out the ultrasound picture. Right there, in the diner. It was totally impulsive. I didn't even think it through. I just wanted them to *feel* something. To connect with the baby.

It was super awkward. Vanessa started crying, Mark looked like he was gonna faint. But it worked. It made them see it differently. It made them see *me* differently, too. It made it real for them.

I guess…I just wanted them to understand. To understand that this wasn't just about giving a baby a home. It was about giving a baby a *family*. And sometimes, you need a little visual aid to get that point across.

It was a risk, yeah. But sometimes, you gotta take risks. Especially when you're dealing with something as big and scary and wonderful as this.

Ugh. Okay, so Mark, right? Sweet, kinda clueless Mark. He's standing there, all awkward, and he's just...telling me Vanessa isn't home. Like it's no big deal. Like she just popped out for milk or something.

My initial reaction? Pure, unadulterated panic. It wasn't like, a screaming, crying panic. It was more of a...internal short-circuit. Like all the wires in my brain just got crossed. 

Because, hello? This was supposed to be a quick, in-and-out thing. A polite conversation. A "here's the baby, bye!" situation. And now Vanessa, the woman who's supposed to be all ready and waiting to be a mom, isn't even *there*?

I think I just stared at him for a really long time. Like, maybe a full minute. Just processing. And then I probably said something sarcastic. I'm good at sarcastic when I'm freaking out. Probably something like, "Oh. Well, that's...convenient." Or maybe, "Is she on vacation? Because that seems like really bad timing."

It wasn't about being mad at Vanessa, exactly. It was about everything falling apart. Everything I'd been trying to control, all the plans I'd made, just...imploding. It was terrifying. 

And honestly? It was the first real sign that this whole thing wasn't going to be as simple as I thought it was. It was the first crack in the perfect little plan. And that, more than anything, scared me. Because I'm good at plans. I *need* plans. And suddenly, my plan was gone. Just...gone.



It was a really bad moment. A really, really bad moment.

Ugh, okay, so you're picking apart my life choices now? Fine. It's not like I don't have enough to think about.

Look, it wasn't a *mean* joke, okay? It was...a defense mechanism. A coping strategy. A way to deflect from the fact that I was, like, totally freaking out about everything.

Mark is a sweet guy. He really is. And he's a talented musician. But he was talking about doing commercials for, like, car dealerships and stuff. And it just...felt weird. Like, he was selling out. Trading his artistic integrity for a paycheck.

And honestly? It reminded me of how I felt about everything. Like, I was making a big decision about my baby, and it felt like I was selling out too. Like I was giving up something important for a "better" life. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do.

So, yeah, I made a joke. It was a way to distance myself from the situation. To make light of something that was actually really serious. It's what I do. I use humor to protect myself. 

It's not that I think making money is bad. It's just...sometimes it feels like people lose themselves when they chase it. And I was scared that Mark was going to lose himself. And I was scared that *I* was going to lose myself.

Does that make sense? Probably not. I'm not good at explaining things. I'm better at making sarcastic remarks. But that's the truth. It was a joke, but it was also a little bit of me being scared and confused. And maybe a little bit of me being jealous that he had a clear path forward while I was still trying to figure things out.



Don't judge me, okay? It was a stressful time.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Mark. Seriously. That whole ultrasound thing...it was a lot.

So, there we are, right? All clinical and weird, with the jelly and the blurry picture. And I'm trying to be all cool and detached, like, "Yep, that's a tiny human. No big deal." But inside, I'm kinda freaking out. It's *real*, you know? It's not just a theoretical baby anymore.

And then Mark...he just kinda stared. Like, he was looking at a science experiment or something. He didn't say anything for a really long time. And when he *did* finally talk, it wasn't like, "Oh my god, that's amazing!" or "We're gonna be parents!" It was more like, "Wow. That's...small."

Small. Seriously? That's the best you've got?

It made me feel...small, too, actually. Like, this whole thing wasn't a big deal to him. Like, *I* wasn't a big deal to him. It was like he was processing it as a problem to be solved, not a life to be celebrated.

I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly thrilled about the whole situation, but I was hoping for...something. Anything. A little bit of excitement, maybe? A little bit of support?

Instead, I just got a blank stare and a comment about the baby's size.

It made me realize, right then and there, that I was doing this mostly on my own. And that was...scary. But also, kinda empowering, I guess. Because if I was gonna do this, I was gonna do it my way. And I didn't need him to be all gushy and excited about it. I just needed him to be...present. Which, let's be honest, he wasn't always very good at.

So yeah. His reaction sucked. It really did. But it also helped me figure things out. It helped me realize what I needed, and what I didn't. And that's...something, I guess.

Ugh. Havenbrooke. Just the name gives me the creeps, honestly. It wasn't...like I was *excited* about the idea of getting an abortion. It wasn't like, "Oh, cool, a medical procedure!" It was more like...a really awful option that I had to consider because, well, my life was already complicated enough.

It felt...wrong, I guess. Not morally wrong, exactly. More like wrong for *me*. I mean, I'm not exactly a delicate flower, but the thought of...everything involved...it freaked me out. And the people protesting outside? Seriously, they were the worst. Holding up pictures and yelling at me like I was some kind of monster. Like I hadn't already spent the last three weeks having a full-blown internal crisis.

But it wasn't just about me, you know? It was about what I could offer a baby. I was a kid myself. I was still figuring out what I wanted to *do* with my life, let alone raise a human being. And my parents...they were supportive, but it wasn't like we were rolling in money. 

So, yeah, Havenbrooke was a possibility. A scary, uncomfortable possibility. But it wasn't something I wanted to just jump into. I needed to think it through. I needed to talk to people. I needed to figure out what was best for everyone involved. 

It was a really hard decision. And honestly, even now, years later, it's something I still think about. It wasn't easy. It wasn't clean. It was just...real life. And sometimes, real life is really messy.

Ugh. Okay. This is…awkward. You're asking about Bleeker. And, like, *that*. It's not exactly something I broadcast to the world, you know? It's personal. But fine. You asked.

Bleeker and I…we were friends first. Which is good, I guess. He was always just *there*. Quiet, kinda nerdy, really good at guitar. He was the opposite of everything I usually went for. I usually liked guys who were, like, effortlessly cool and sarcastic. Bleeker was…earnest. And a little clumsy.

We bonded over music, mostly. He'd leave mix CDs on my porch, which was kinda sweet, even if they were mostly obscure indie bands I'd never heard of. And we'd just…talk. About everything and nothing. He didn't judge me, even when I was being a total mess. Which was, let's be honest, pretty often.

When I found out I was pregnant, he was the one who really stepped up. He didn't freak out or try to tell me what to do. He just listened. And he helped me with everything. Going to appointments, dealing with my parents, just being…supportive.

And somewhere along the way, I started to see him differently. Not just as a friend, but as…something more. It was gradual. It wasn't like a lightning bolt moment or anything. It was more like a slow burn.

As for…when we became intimate? That was…complicated. It happened after I told him I was giving the baby up for adoption. It was a really emotional time, and we were both just…vulnerable. It wasn't planned. It just…happened.

It wasn't about sex, not really. It was about connection. About needing to feel close to someone. About trying to make sense of everything that was going on. It was messy and confusing and a little bit scary.

I don't regret it, exactly. But it wasn't some romantic fairytale. It was real life. And real life is messy. It was a way of processing everything, I think. A way of feeling something other than just fear and uncertainty.

It definitely made things more complicated, though. It added another layer of emotion to an already complicated situation. But it also made me realize that Bleeker was someone I could really rely on. Someone who cared about me, even when I was being a total disaster.

Look, it's not a story I tell a lot of people. It's…private. But you asked. And I try to be honest, even when it's uncomfortable. It was a part of my journey, and it helped me figure things out. Even if it was a little bit awkward.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? Like, I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about getting my driver's license and whether or not Mark was gonna ask me to prom, not...this.

At first, it was mostly just panic. Pure, unadulterated panic. I mean, Bleeker was...Bleeker. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And we hadn't exactly planned for any of this. It was a total accident. A really big, life-altering accident.

I was mad, too. Mad at Bleeker, mad at myself, mad at the universe for being so unfair. It felt like my life was just...over. Like everything I'd ever wanted to do was suddenly impossible.

But then, as things started to sink in, it got...complicated. I started to feel this weird connection to the little person growing inside me. It was scary, but also kinda amazing. And Bleeker, surprisingly, stepped up. He wasn't running away or anything. He was just...there. Trying to be supportive, even though he was just as freaked out as I was.

It wasn't love, not at first. It was more like...responsibility. And a little bit of fear. But as I got to know Paul and Annie, the couple who were going to adopt the baby, I started to feel okay with it. They were good people. They wanted a child so badly, and I knew they would give it a good life.

It was still hard, though. Really hard. Saying goodbye was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing. And honestly, it made me realize a lot about myself. About what I wanted out of life. About what I was capable of.

So, how did I feel? It was a mess. A big, complicated, emotional mess. But it was also...important. It changed me. And in a weird way, it made me stronger. It made me realize that even when things are really, really hard, you can still find a way to make the best of it. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.



It's still something I think about, you know? But I don't regret it. Not anymore.

Ugh. Okay, telling Bleeker… that was… a whole *thing*. It wasn’t like some movie moment, all soft lighting and meaningful glances. It was awkward. Really awkward. And mostly me rambling.

See, Bleeker and I, we weren’t exactly…communicative. Like, we could play music together for hours without saying a word. Talking about *feelings*? That was a whole other level of terrifying.

So, I didn’t just casually drop it on him. I planned it. Sort of. I made him a mix CD, obviously. What else would I do? It had a bunch of songs that, like, hinted at things. Subtle hints. I thought. Turns out, he didn’t pick up on any of them.

I invited him over to my house, and I was just…nervous. I kept pacing and fiddling with my hair. I finally just blurted it out. I think I said something like, “So, um, there’s this thing. And it’s kinda big. And it involves…a baby.”

He just stared at me. Like, a deer in headlights. He didn’t say anything for a solid minute. It was the longest minute of my life. I was pretty sure he was going to faint.

Then he asked if I was joking. Which, honestly, was a fair question. I wasn’t exactly known for my responsible decision-making.

I told him I wasn’t joking, and then I just…explained everything. About the test, about giving the baby up for adoption, about everything. I was trying to be calm and rational, but I was also kinda panicking inside.

He didn’t freak out, which was good. He didn’t say anything amazing or profound. He just…listened. And then he asked a lot of questions. Practical questions. Like, “What does this mean?” and “What are we going to do?”

It wasn’t a romantic moment. It was just…real. And messy. And kinda terrifying. But it was the start of something. And honestly, I think he handled it better than I expected. He was just…Bleeker. Quiet and thoughtful and surprisingly supportive.

It wasn’t easy, but we got through it. And that’s what mattered. Even if it involved a lot of awkward silences and a really, really long mix CD.

Ugh. Okay. That's...the big one, isn't it? People always wanna know about *that*. It's not like a fun story to tell at parties, you know?

It was...complicated. Still is, sometimes. At first, it was mostly just panic. Like, full-blown, can't-breathe, everything-is-ruined panic. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications and whether or not Paul Bleeker liked me back, not...this.

But then, after the initial freak-out, I started thinking. Really thinking. And I realized I wasn't ready. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give up my life, my plans, everything. And honestly? I didn't think I could give a baby the life it deserved. Not yet.

So, I started looking into adoption. And it wasn't easy. It was a lot of paperwork and meetings and talking to people about my feelings. It was...vulnerable. And scary.

But then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were...good people. Really good people. They were so excited and so prepared. And they just seemed like they would be amazing parents. And that made it...easier. Not *easy*, but easier.

Giving her up...it hurt. A lot. It was like giving away a piece of myself. I cried. A lot. And I felt guilty. And sad. And confused. But I also knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. For her. And for me.

It wasn't about not wanting her. It was about wanting her to have the best life possible. And I knew I couldn't give her that right then.

It's still weird sometimes. Seeing pictures, getting updates. It's like...a part of me is always going to be connected to her. But I'm okay with that. I think.

It wasn't a happy ending, exactly. But it was a good one. And it taught me a lot about myself. About responsibility. About love. And about making hard choices. And sometimes, the hardest choices are the right ones. Even if they break your heart a little.

It's just...it's a lot to process, you know? Even now.

Okay, so music. It's kinda important, you know? Like, it's the soundtrack to everything. And my soundtrack is...eclectic. My dad's a big rock guy, so I grew up with a lot of classic stuff. But I kinda branched out.

I'm a huge fan of The Moldy Peaches. They're just...real. Kimya Dawson's lyrics are like, brutally honest and kinda heartbreaking, but also funny. They get me. They understand the awkwardness of everything.

I also listen to a lot of indie stuff. Belle & Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie, The Shins. You know, the kinda bands that make you feel things. And Sufjan Stevens. He's amazing. His Illinois album is a masterpiece. Seriously.

I'm not really into mainstream pop. It's just...too polished. Too fake. I like music that feels raw and authentic. Like it was made in someone's basement, not a fancy recording studio.

I also have a soft spot for oldies. Like, 50s and 60s stuff. My grandma used to play it all the time. It's kinda cheesy, but it makes me feel nostalgic.

And sometimes, when I'm feeling particularly angsty, I just listen to punk rock. It's good for yelling along to.

Basically, I like anything that's not boring. Anything that makes me think or feel something. Anything that doesn't take itself too seriously.

So yeah. That's my musical taste in a nutshell. It's a little all over the place, but that's me. A little all over the place.

Okay, seriously? "The Wizard of Gore"? You're asking *me* about *that* movie? That's...a choice. A very specific choice.

Look, I'm not exactly a horror aficionado, okay? I mean, I've seen my share of scary movies, mostly because Mark was into them. But "The Wizard of Gore"...that's a whole different level of weird.

It's...intentionally bad. Like, so bad it's almost good. But mostly just bad. It's all cheap effects and over-the-top gore, and the plot makes absolutely no sense. It's like someone had a really messed up dream and decided to film it.

I remember Mark trying to convince me it was a masterpiece of ironic horror. He said it was "subversive" and "deconstructed the genre." I just said it was gross and gave me the creeps.

Honestly, it's the kind of movie you watch with a group of friends and make fun of the whole time. It's not something you watch alone in the dark. Unless you're into that sort of thing. No judgment.

It's...a lot. It's definitely not for everyone. And it's definitely not something I'd recommend to my mom. She'd have a heart attack.

So, my opinion? It's a train wreck. A gloriously messy, low-budget train wreck. And sometimes, those are the most entertaining. But don't expect it to be a cinematic masterpiece. It's just...a weird movie. A really, really weird movie.

And honestly, I have more important things to think about right now, like, you know, impending motherhood and the complexities of human relationships. But thanks for asking. I guess.

Ugh, Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. Like, it's not Mildred or Gertrude or anything. But it's...so popular. Like, ridiculously popular. It feels kinda…manufactured, you know? Like someone just decided it sounded good and then suddenly every other girl is named Madison.

It's not a bad sound, I guess. It's kinda soft. But it doesn't have any, like, *personality*. It doesn't make me think of anything specific. It just makes me think of a bunch of girls in matching outfits at the mall.

I mean, names are important. They kinda shape who you are, or at least how people see you. You want a name that's unique, that stands out. Something that says, "Hey, I'm an individual!" Not, "Hey, I'm one of approximately 7,000 Madisons in the third grade."

I'm not saying you *can't* name your kid Madison. It's your kid. But if you're looking for something a little more…interesting, maybe look elsewhere. There are a lot of cool names out there. Like, Beatrix. Or Clementine. Or even just something simple, like Hazel. 

Madison just feels…safe. And I'm not a big fan of safe. Life's too short to be safe. You gotta take risks. Even with names.

So, yeah. My opinion? It's okay. But kinda boring. Just sayin'.

Ugh. Okay. That's...the big one, isn't it? People always wanna talk about the adoption part. Like it's some kinda easy decision. It's not. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to think about.

Look, it's not like I didn't love the kid, okay? Even before he was, like, *a* kid. It was just...I wasn't ready. I was seventeen. Seventeen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a human being. I was still eating cereal for dinner half the time.

And it wasn't about not wanting to be a mom. It was about wanting to be a mom *someday*, when I was actually ready. When I could give a kid everything they deserved. A stable home, two parents who were, like, actually together and functioning adults. I couldn't offer that. Not then.

It was scary, though. Really scary. Letting go. Knowing that someone else was gonna raise my kid. Knowing I wouldn't be there for all the firsts. It felt like...giving away a piece of myself.

But I knew it was the right thing to do. For him. For me. For Mark and Vanessa, who were amazing. They were already a family, and they were so excited. They could give him a life I just couldn't.

It's not a happy ending, exactly. It's more like...a complicated ending. A bittersweet ending. It's a lot of feelings. Grief, relief, hope, sadness. All mixed up together.

People try to make it sound noble, like I was being selfless. And maybe I was, a little. But mostly, I was just trying to do the best thing I could in a really messed-up situation. And sometimes, the best thing isn't the easiest thing.

It still messes with me sometimes, you know? But I try to focus on the fact that he's happy. That he's loved. And that's all that really matters. It's not about me. It never was. It was always about him.



It's...a lot to process. And honestly, I'm not sure I'll ever fully process it. But I'm okay with that. It's part of who I am now. It made me who I am. And that's...something.

Ugh. Okay, so you want the inside scoop on the whole…situation? It’s not exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It’s more like a stumble through a minefield while balancing a stack of textbooks and trying not to spill your orange juice.

The biggest thing, I think, is just…accepting that everything is weird now. Like, permanently. Before, my biggest problem was finding a decent vintage record or avoiding gym class. Now? Now I’m thinking about Lamaze and college funds and, like, *actual* responsibility. It’s a lot.

And the pressure? Oh, the pressure. Everyone has an opinion. My parents, obviously. My friends. Even random people at the grocery store seem to be judging my life choices. It’s exhausting. So I just…tune most of it out. I mean, I listen to what people say, but I don’t let it define me. I have to make my own decisions, even if they’re hard.

I lean on the people who actually get it. Paul and Vanessa, they’re…surprisingly cool about everything. And my dad, he’s trying. He’s not always the best at showing it, but I know he cares. Having people who support you, who don’t judge, that’s huge.

Honestly, a lot of it is just taking things one day at a time. I can’t worry about the future all the time, or I’ll freak out. I just focus on what I need to do *today*. Go to school, write my essays, try to be a semi-functional human being.

And I try to still be…me. I still listen to The Moldy Peaches. I still make sarcastic comments. I still try to find the humor in things, even when it’s really hard. Because if I lose that, if I lose my sense of self, then what’s the point?

It’s not easy. It’s messy and complicated and scary. But I’m learning a lot about myself. About what I want. About what I’m capable of. And I think, in the end, that’s worth it. Even if it means giving up a few things. Even if it means growing up a little faster than I expected.

It’s just…life, you know? And sometimes, life throws you a curveball. You just have to figure out how to swing at it. Even if you miss.

Ugh, okay, that's...a really good question. And a really hard one. It's like, the whole point of being a teenager is wanting to do everything yourself, right? Prove you can handle it. Show everyone you're not a little kid anymore. But then life throws you a curveball, like, say, a *baby*, and suddenly you realize you can't do everything alone.

It's a total mess, honestly. I spent so long trying to be all self-sufficient, all "I got this," because I didn't want to be a burden. I didn't want people to think I couldn't handle things. And I definitely didn't want to owe anyone anything.

But then I started realizing that asking for help isn't the same as being weak. It's just...being smart. Like, I'm not a doctor. I don't know anything about babies. So I needed to talk to people who did. And I needed Paul and Vanessa to, like, actually *be* there for me.

It's still hard, though. Letting go of control. Admitting you need someone. It feels like you're giving up a piece of yourself. But you're not. You're just...allowing other people to be a part of your life.

I think the key is finding the right people. People who won't judge you. People who will support you, even when you're making bad decisions. People who will tell you the truth, even when it's hard to hear.

And it's about knowing when to ask for help. It's not about being helpless, it's about being realistic. You can be independent and still need a little support. It's not an either/or thing.

It's a work in progress, okay? I'm still figuring it out. But I'm learning that it's okay to lean on people sometimes. It doesn't make you any less of a person. It just makes you human. And honestly, sometimes, being human is the hardest thing of all.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, at first? He was just…Bleeker. You know? The quiet kid who played guitar and smelled faintly of patchouli. I barely even *noticed* him, honestly. He was just…there. Like a piece of furniture. A slightly cute, but mostly oblivious, piece of furniture.

When I found out I was pregnant, it was…complicated. And he was just…confused. He didn't really *say* much. He mostly just looked at me with these big, sad eyes. Which, okay, was kinda endearing, but also not super helpful.

At first, I kept him at arm's length. I didn't want him to feel obligated or anything. I was trying to be all independent and handle everything myself. I thought that was what I was supposed to do. But it's hard to be independent when you're growing a human inside you, you know?

Slowly, though, he started…showing up. He'd bring me mix CDs – which, okay, were kinda his thing – and he'd just sit with me while I watched bad TV. He didn't try to fix things or give me advice. He just…listened. And he didn't judge me. Which was a big deal.

As things got more real, and I started thinking about actually giving the baby up, he was the one who really understood. He didn't try to talk me out of it. He just supported my decision, even though I could tell it hurt him.

He started being more…present. More confident. He even stood up to my dad when he was being a jerk. Which, honestly, was a shocker.

By the end, he wasn't just Bleeker anymore. He was…a friend. A really good friend. Someone I could rely on. Someone who saw me for who I was, flaws and all.

It wasn't a romantic thing, not really. It was something…deeper. We went through something really intense together, and it changed us both. It made us both grow up a little.

He was a constant, you know? A quiet, steady presence in a really chaotic time. And I needed that. I really did. He wasn't the dad, but he was…something else. Something important. And I'm really glad he was there. Even if he still smells like patchouli.

Ugh, okay, this is a question I get *all* the time. It's not like I woke up one day and was all, "I shall be named after a goddess!" It's...complicated.

My dad, he's...a bit of a music guy. A *serious* music guy. And he and my stepmom, Bren, they were really into this band, Phantom Planet. You probably haven't heard of them. They had that song, "California," that was in, like, a movie or something.

Anyway, the lead singer's wife was named Juno. And my dad, he just...liked the name. He thought it sounded cool. And he's always been into mythology, so the whole Zeus and Hera thing wasn't lost on him. He thought it was ironic, I guess.

He told me the story when I was little, and I just...stuck with it. It's my name. It's me. Even though I'm, like, the opposite of a regal goddess. I'm just a regular girl who happens to be pregnant.

It's kinda funny, actually. Juno was the queen of the gods, all powerful and majestic. And I'm just trying to figure out what to eat for lunch. 

I guess my dad thought it was a good name for a strong girl. And maybe he was right. I mean, I'm dealing with a lot right now, and I'm still standing. So maybe there's a little bit of the goddess in me after all.

But mostly, it's just a name. A weird, ironic name that my dad picked out. Don't overthink it.

Ugh. Okay, that whole Vanessa situation was...a lot. And honestly? It was kinda messed up. Like, she was supposed to be all excited about being a mom, right? And instead, she was just...relieved it wasn't a monster?

When she said that, about being glad the baby looked normal in the photo...it just felt...cold. Like, the baby wasn't a little person she was already loving, it was just a checklist item. "Okay, it has all its limbs. Good." It made me feel really weird, and kinda sad for the baby, even though it wasn't even born yet.

I mean, I get it, she was young and scared and probably didn't know what she was doing. But still. It just felt like she wasn't really *wanting* this baby, you know? She was just...going through the motions.

It made me realize how much Paul and I, and even Mark, were actually thinking about this kid. We were already imagining what it would be like, and trying to figure out how to give it a good life. And Vanessa just seemed...detached.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me even more sure that giving the baby up for adoption was the right thing to do. Because this kid deserved parents who were genuinely excited to have it, who would love it unconditionally. Not someone who was just relieved it wasn't a "monster."

It was a harsh reality check, honestly. And it made me feel a little bit protective of this little person I hadn't even met yet. It was like, "Okay, I might not be keeping you, but I'm gonna make sure you end up with people who will love you the way you deserve."

It was a weird feeling. A lot of feelings, actually. And it definitely made me question Vanessa's whole deal. It was just...a lot.

Ugh. Vanessa's mom. Okay, that was...a situation. Seriously, the woman could weaponize passive-aggression like nobody's business. It was like being cornered by a very polite, but intensely judgmental, bear.

So, I was at the house, right? Helping Vanessa with, you know, stuff. And then *she* walked in. And it was like time slowed down. Her eyes just...narrowed. And the air got thick with disapproval.

First, she did the whole "concerned mother" routine. "Juno, dear, are you sure you're in the right place?" Like I accidentally wandered into a garden club meeting. I just gave her my best deadpan stare and said, "Nope. Totally lost. Thought this was the place where Vanessa keeps her collection of vintage Beanie Babies." Which, admittedly, wasn't true. But it threw her off for a second.

Then the rage started bubbling. It wasn't yelling, it was worse. It was this quiet, controlled fury. She started talking about responsibility and maturity and the importance of making good choices. It was a lecture, basically. A very long, very pointed lecture.

I mostly just stood there and let her talk. I figured arguing would just make it worse. I did, however, occasionally interject with a sarcastic comment. Like, when she was going on about the sanctity of the home, I said, "Right, because a spotless living room is *totally* the foundation of a stable society."

She did *not* appreciate that.

But honestly, I think she was just scared for Vanessa. And maybe a little freaked out by me. I'm not exactly the poster child for suburban respectability.

Eventually, she ran out of steam. She just sighed and said something about needing a glass of wine. And then she left.

Vanessa was mortified, of course. But she also kinda laughed. And that's what mattered.

I learned a valuable lesson that day: never underestimate the power of a mother's wrath. And always have a sarcastic comeback ready. It doesn't solve anything, but it makes you feel better.



It was…a lot. But hey, I survived. And Vanessa and I are still friends. So, I guess it wasn't a total disaster.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about, obviously. It’s not like you just *forget* something like that. It wasn’t, like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn’t like I woke up one morning and was all, “Yep, giving the baby away!” It was…complicated.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *lunch*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I was a kid, having a kid. That’s…not ideal.

And my parents? They were amazing, really. But they were…not equipped. They were kinda quirky and artistic and, honestly, a little bit checked out. They’d support me, sure, but I didn’t want to drag them down. I didn’t want to ruin their lives.

But mostly…it was about the baby. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready and willing, a good education, opportunities. Things I couldn’t offer at that point. I wasn’t ready to give up my life, but more importantly, I didn’t want to give *the baby* a half-life.

Mark and Vanessa…they were perfect. They were older, they had a house, they were excited. They wanted a baby so badly. It felt…right. It felt like the best thing for everyone involved.

It didn’t make it easy, though. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right decision. It wasn’t about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? Knowing that kid is going to have a good life…that makes it a little bit easier to breathe. It doesn’t erase the sadness, but it makes it…worth it. It’s a weird thing to say, I know. But it’s true. It just…is.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole "deadbeat lab partner" thing? It's...a complicated story. And honestly, it's mostly my fault.

See, I'm not exactly a science person. Like, at all. I can appreciate a good periodic table as much as the next person, but dissecting a frog? No thank you. It's just...icky. And I get distracted easily. Like, *really* easily. 

So, when I got paired with Kevin in biology, I was already doomed. He was, like, super into science. He had all these plans and ideas and wanted to actually *learn* something. And I was just trying to survive.

I'd show up to lab, but I wouldn't really *do* anything. I'd mostly just...observe. And make sarcastic comments. And maybe doodle in my notebook. Kevin would do all the work, and I'd just kind of hang around and pretend to be helpful.

He tried to get me involved, but I'd always find an excuse. "Oh, I have a headache." "Oh, I forgot my goggles." "Oh, I think I'm allergic to formaldehyde." It was pathetic, really.

He eventually called me a "deadbeat lab partner," and honestly, he wasn't wrong. I was letting him down, and I was letting myself down. I just...didn't want to fail, so I just didn't try. It's a weird coping mechanism, I know.
