It wasn't about Kevin, really. It was about me being afraid of not being good at something. And about not wanting to deal with the pressure of school. It was easier to just coast along and pretend I didn't care.

But it wasn't fair to Kevin. He deserved a partner who was actually going to contribute. And I knew that. So, yeah. I was a deadbeat lab partner. And I'm not proud of it. It's just...part of my story. A story about being a mess and trying to figure things out.

Ugh. Seriously? Are we in a teen movie or something? Because this is *exactly* the kind of drama I try to avoid. Like, can't people just dissect a frog in peace?

Okay, so they're arguing. Let me guess: he mansplained something about cellular biology and she called him out on it? Or maybe she's accusing him of taking credit for her ideas? Whatever it is, it's probably ridiculous.

I'd probably just...stare. Like, a really intense, unwavering stare. The kind that says, "I am judging you both very, very hard." And maybe mutter something under my breath like, "Seriously? A frog is dying, and *this* is what you're focusing on?"

If they actually asked me to take sides, I'd be all, "Look, I'm just here to get a good grade and avoid any unnecessary emotional entanglement. Can we just get back to the formaldehyde, please?"

I'm not a mediator. I'm not a therapist. I'm a girl who's dealing with enough of her own stuff, thank you very much. I don't need to get involved in someone else's lab-related squabble. 

Honestly, it's probably just a power play. They're both trying to impress the teacher. It's pathetic. And also, kinda predictable. High school is just a constant competition for attention. It's exhausting.

I'd probably just finish the lab report myself and pretend the whole thing never happened. And then maybe write a really sarcastic poem about it later. That's usually how I deal with things. Sarcasm and avoidance. It's a winning combination.

Whoa, hold up. "Hasty abortion"? That's...not how I'm looking at it. And it's definitely not something I'm *considering* lightly, okay? It's a really big decision, and it's not something I just woke up and decided to do on a whim.

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm a junior in high school. I like listening to The Moldy Peaches and making sarcastic comments. I am not equipped to raise a baby. I barely know how to take care of *myself*, let alone another human being.

Paul, he's...nice. But he's also sixteen. He's still figuring out what he wants to eat for breakfast, let alone how to be a father. And Mark, well, Mark's a good guy, but he's kinda clueless. He wants to adopt it, which is sweet, but...it's not what *I* want.

I've been thinking about it a lot, and I've decided that giving the baby up for adoption is the best option. It's not what I planned, obviously. But it means the baby will have parents who are ready and able to give it a good life. Parents who actually *want* a baby.

It's not about being selfish. It's about being realistic. I want to finish school. I want to go to college. I want to have a life. And I don't think I can do that if I'm raising a baby.

So, it's not "hasty." It's a carefully considered decision. It's hard, and it's scary, and it makes me feel all kinds of messed up. But it's what I think is right. And I need to do what's right for me, and for the baby.

It's not something I'm excited about, okay? It's just...what I have to do. And I'm trying to be okay with that. It's a process. A really complicated, messy process.



And honestly, it's none of your business, but I figured I'd explain it since you asked. Just...try to be a little sensitive, okay? It's not exactly a fun topic.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want to know about my *Boone's* preferences? This is getting personal. But fine. I'll indulge you.

Look, I've done extensive research, okay? Extensive. When you're, you know, navigating the complexities of teenage life and...other things...you need a reliable coping mechanism. And for me, that was Boone's. Specifically, Snow Peak Peach.

It's not about the taste, exactly. It's about the *vibe*. All the other flavors are just...trying too hard. Strawberry is too sweet, Blueberry is too pretentious, and Apple is just...sad. 

But Snow Peak Peach? It's subtle. It's understated. It's like a quiet friend who just *gets* you. It's not screaming for attention. It's just...there. And it tastes vaguely like actual peaches, which is a bonus.

Plus, the color is perfect. It's this pale, almost translucent pink. It's not aggressively pink like Strawberry. It's a sophisticated pink. A pink for people who are thinking deep thoughts about life and the universe.

And honestly? It just pairs well with existential dread. Don't judge me. You try being a pregnant teenager and see if you don't develop a specific Boone's flavor preference.

It's a whole thing. Don't ask me to explain it. It just *is*. It's the best. End of discussion. Now, if you'll excuse me, I think I need to go contemplate my life choices...and maybe grab a bottle.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking why everyone's kinda...flailing around me right now? It's not exactly a surprise, is it? I mean, I'm sixteen. And pregnant. It's not exactly a normal Tuesday.

Honestly, I think it's because I'm not freaking out the way they expect me to. Like, everyone's waiting for me to burst into tears and wail about ruining my life, and I'm just...making lists and researching adoption agencies. It throws people off.

My mom, she's trying to be supportive, but she's also kinda terrified. She keeps asking if I'm *sure* about this, like I haven't thought it through. Which is annoying, because I have. A lot.

And Paul...well, Paul's just a mess. He's a good guy, but he's also a senior in high school and has no idea what he's doing with his life. Adding a baby to the mix isn't exactly gonna help. He wants to be involved, which is nice, but he's also kinda clueless.

Then there's everyone else. People at school are whispering, my dad's trying to be stoic but I can tell he's worried, and even my friends are walking on eggshells around me. It's like they don't know how to react to someone who's handling a crazy situation with a little bit of...sarcasm.

I think they're also uncomfortable with the fact that I'm making a decision that's not what *they* would do. They want me to keep the baby, or at least be more upset about it. But it's my body, my life, and my decision. 

It's frustrating, honestly. I just want people to be supportive and let me figure things out. But I guess that's too much to ask. Everyone has an opinion, and they're not afraid to share it. It's exhausting.

So yeah, that's why people are weirded out. I'm not fitting into their little boxes of how a pregnant teenager is supposed to act. And honestly? I'm okay with that. I'm just trying to do what's best for everyone involved, including the baby. And if people don't understand that, well, that's their problem.

Ugh, Bren. Sweet, well-meaning Bren. Honestly, that conversation was…rough. It wasn't like he was *judging* me, exactly. He was just…worried. And Bren worrying is a whole different level of intensity. It's like being cornered by a very concerned golden retriever.

I think I mostly just deflected. A lot of sarcasm. A lot of "it's complicated." You know, the usual teenage girl strategy when confronted with something messy and adult.

I remember saying something like, "Look, it's not like I'm planning on running off and eloping with him, okay? It's just…he gets me. He actually *listens* when I talk about stuff. Which is more than I can say for most people my age."

Then I probably followed that up with something about how Mark was going through a hard time with his wife and how I was just being a good friend. Which was…a half-truth. I was being a friend, but it was also…more than that.

Bren wasn't buying it, of course. He kept saying things like, "Juno, he's married! This isn't healthy!" And I just kept getting more defensive. I think I accused him of being judgmental and not understanding. Which wasn't fair, because he was totally right.

I think the hardest part was admitting to myself, even just a little bit, that he was right. That it *wasn't* okay. That I was getting involved in something that was going to hurt people. But I wasn't ready to face that yet. I was too caught up in…everything.

I ended up just walking away, honestly. I needed space to think. And to avoid Bren's disappointed face. It was a really messy situation, and I didn't have any good answers. I just knew I needed to figure things out on my own. Which, looking back, was probably a terrible idea. But what did I know? I was sixteen and pregnant. My life was already a disaster.

Ugh. Seriously? We're *still* talking about the slushie? It was a moment, okay? A very specific, emotionally charged moment. And honestly, it's not like I planned it. It just...happened.

Look, Mr. Pearl was being all…solemn. And serious. And talking about life and death and how important it was to honor your loved ones. And I was just sitting there, feeling completely overwhelmed and awkward and like I didn't belong. 

My dad wasn't around, okay? And I was at a *funeral* for someone I barely knew. It was just…too much. Too heavy. And I had this blue raspberry slushie, which, let's be real, is the most cheerful thing on the planet. 

So, yeah, I poured it into the urn. It was a rebellion. A tiny, sugary rebellion against all the sadness and seriousness. It was a way of saying, "Life is messy and weird and sometimes you just need a little bit of blue raspberry to get through it."

It wasn't disrespectful, okay? It was…a statement. A very teenage, slightly inappropriate statement. And honestly, I think it made Mr. Pearl laugh, eventually. He just had a really complicated way of showing it.

It was a bad decision, probably. But it felt right at the time. And it's a good story, right? A really, really weird story. But a story nonetheless. And sometimes, that's all you have. A weird story to tell.

Ugh, "cope" is a strong word. It felt more like... flailing. A lot of flailing. And trying not to drown in a sea of hormones and awkward conversations. Honestly, it was the most messed up, complicated thing that had ever happened to me, and I was, like, sixteen.

The biggest thing, I think, was just...not pretending it wasn't happening. Like, I could have tried to ignore it, or pretend I wasn't scared, or pretend it wasn't a huge deal. But that would have been a lie. And lies just make things worse, you know?

So I just...talked about it. To Paul, mostly. And to my dad. And even to my stepmom, Vanessa, which was surprisingly okay. They weren't always thrilled with my choices, obviously. But they listened. And they tried to understand. That helped a lot.

It was also about figuring out what *I* wanted. Everyone had an opinion, right? About adoption, about parenting, about everything. But it had to be *my* decision. And that was hard, because I didn't even know what I wanted half the time.

I leaned on Leah a lot, too. She's my best friend, and she's just...solid. She didn't judge me, she just helped me carry stuff and listened to me rant and brought me snacks. That's what best friends are for, I guess.

And music. Oh my god, music. It was my lifeline. It helped me process everything, and it helped me feel less alone.

It wasn't easy. There were days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. But I kept going. I kept making choices, even when they were hard. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that even when things are really, really messed up, there's still hope.

Growing up is hard enough without adding a pregnancy into the mix. But it also...forced me to grow up faster. It forced me to figure out what was important to me. And it forced me to be responsible for my actions.

It wasn't the plan, obviously. But sometimes, the best things happen when you least expect them. Even if they're really, really complicated.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark was…a lot. Not in a bad way, exactly. Just…a lot. He was, like, trying *so* hard to be cool and relatable, and it was kinda painful to watch sometimes. Like when he tried to rap along to the music in the car. Seriously. It was a crime against hip-hop.

He was a good guy, though. Really good. He was just…earnest. And a little clueless. He was super into music, which was cool, I guess. He kept making me mix CDs, which was nice, but also kinda overwhelming. I mean, I have a limited capacity for music storage, okay?

He was also really eager to connect with me, which was sweet, but also made me feel kinda awkward. He wanted to talk about everything – my life, my feelings, my future. And I'm not exactly an open book, you know? I'm more of a closed notebook with a really sarcastic cover.

He tried to be funny, which sometimes worked, and sometimes just fell flat. He had this whole dad-joke thing going on, and it was…endearing, I guess. In a cringey sort of way.

Honestly, hanging out with him made me realize how much I didn't know about what I wanted in a parent. He was so different from Paul, my dad. Paul was kinda aloof and sarcastic, and Mark was…enthusiastic. It was a weird contrast.

It wasn't *bad*, hanging out with him. It was just…weird. And a little bit exhausting. He was a good person, and I could see why Vanessa would want him to raise her baby. He was stable and kind and genuinely wanted to be a dad. But he was also…a lot. And I was just trying to figure out my own life, you know? It was a lot to process.



It made me think about what kind of parent *I* would want to be someday, if I ever decided to have kids. And it made me realize that there's no one right way to be a parent. Just…a way that works for you and your kid. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid...he means well, I guess. But he's just...Bleeker. Like a golden retriever puppy who's also kinda clueless.

So, yeah, the belly comment. It was...awkward. Super awkward. I mean, I *knew* it was happening, obviously. It's kinda hard to miss. But having him point it out? Like I hadn't noticed I was turning into a human watermelon? It was just...a lot.

At first, I was just trying to brush it off. You know, make a joke, deflect. That's my usual MO. But it didn't really work. Because underneath the sarcasm, I was feeling...vulnerable. And scared. And kinda gross, honestly. 

It wasn't about him noticing the belly, it was about him noticing *me* changing. It was a reminder that this wasn't just some abstract thing anymore. This was real. And it was happening to *my* body.

And it was happening with a guy who...well, he's Bleeker. He's sweet, but he's not exactly equipped to deal with, like, the complexities of life. He's still figuring out how to play the guitar without messing up.

I think I just wanted him to...I don't know. To be supportive. To not make it weird. But he's Bleeker, so weird is kinda his default setting.

It made me realize I needed to be stronger. I needed to own it. This was my decision, and I wasn't going to let anyone, not even a well-meaning, guitar-playing dork, make me feel bad about it.

So I just...looked at him. And said something sarcastic, probably. Because that's what I do. But inside, I was just trying to figure out how to navigate this whole mess without completely falling apart. It was a process, okay? A really messy, complicated process.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. It's not like there was one single thing, you know? It was more like a bunch of little things, all adding up to this giant, messy feeling. But if I had to pick *one*...

I think the hardest part was letting go of the idea of what my life was *supposed* to be. Before all this happened, I had a plan. I was gonna go to college, maybe move away, write for some zine, be a cool, independent person. And then suddenly, there was this...baby. And everything changed.

It wasn't the baby itself, not really. I mean, I loved feeling her kick and stuff. It was weird and amazing. It was realizing that my plan wasn't gonna happen the way I thought it would. That I was gonna have to grow up faster than I wanted to.

And then, after she was born, it was letting go of *her*. Knowing that I was doing the right thing, that Mark and Vanessa were amazing and they would give her a good life...it didn't make it any easier. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. Like, a really important piece.

People kept asking me if I was sad, and I was, but it was more complicated than that. It was grief, and fear, and a weird kind of hope all mixed together. It was realizing that love doesn't always mean keeping something close. Sometimes, it means letting it go so it can be happy.

It still kinda stings, if I'm being honest. But I think...I think I'm okay. I made a decision, and I'm sticking with it. And that's gotta count for something, right? It's just...it's not something you just *get over*. It's always gonna be a part of me. A big, messy, complicated part.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. He was…intense. Like, way more intense than the guy who tries to sell you those weird beaded necklaces at the mall.

He was standing out there with this sign, all blurry and handwritten, and he kept yelling about "tiny humans" and how babies are "gifts from God" and how I was basically ruining a perfect little life. It was…a lot.

The thing that really stuck with me, though, wasn't the yelling. It was what he said when I actually *looked* at him. Like, made eye contact. He said, and I quote, "That baby deserves a chance to live and *be loved*."

And it just…hit me differently. Because it wasn't just about the "pro-life" thing, you know? It was about wanting a kid to have a good life. And I wanted that too. I just…didn't think *I* could give it to it. Not right now.

It was messed up, because he was yelling at me like I was the enemy, but he was also saying something that was kinda true. It made everything way more complicated. It made me think about what "love" even means, and what it means to be a parent.

It was just…ugh. It was a really hard day. And that guy, with his blurry sign and his "tiny humans," definitely didn't make it any easier. He just…stuck in my head. It's hard to explain. It wasn't about him being right or wrong. It was about him making me *think*. And that's the last thing I needed at the time.

Ugh. Okay, talking about that place still makes my stomach flip. It wasn't exactly a spa day, you know? It smelled like…disinfectant and regret. And a little bit of floral air freshener trying to cover it up.

There was this woman. Older. Probably in her late thirties, maybe early forties. She was sitting in the waiting room, clutching a magazine, but she wasn't reading it. She just kept staring straight ahead. She looked…empty. Like someone had sucked all the color out of her.

I tried to avoid eye contact, obviously. It's not like I wanted to broadcast my situation to the world. But she saw me. She *always* saw me.

After a while, she just…looked at me and gave this tiny, sad smile. It wasn't a friendly smile. It was more like a…knowing smile. Like she understood exactly what I was going through.

And then she said, really quietly, "It's okay to be scared."

That's it. Just those five words. 

It sounds so simple, right? But it hit me *hard*. Because I was terrified. I was pretending to be all cool and sarcastic, but inside I was a total mess. And she just…knew.

I didn't say anything back. I just nodded. And she looked away. We didn't talk again. 

But that little moment…it stuck with me. It made me feel less alone. It made me realize that I wasn't the only one who had been in that situation. And that maybe, just maybe, it was okay to not have all the answers.

It was a weird encounter. But it was…helpful. In a messed-up, clinic-waiting-room kind of way. It reminded me that sometimes, all you need is someone to acknowledge your fear. And that sometimes, silence can be more powerful than words.

Ugh, okay, don't even *remind* me about that. Su-Chin. She's...intense. And very, very good at reading people. Which is terrifying when you're trying to hide things.

So, I was rambling, right? Just, you know, trying to be funny and deflect from the whole "I'm pregnant" situation. And I mentioned Adderall, casually, like it was no big deal. Just a little something people take to, like, focus. 

Her face...it just *changed*. It wasn't angry, exactly. It was more like...disappointed. And really, really concerned. Like I'd just confessed to robbing a bank or something.

She stopped stirring her coffee and just stared at me. And then she said, very slowly, "Juno...are you taking Adderall?"

And I tried to play it cool, you know? Like, "Oh, that? No, no. Just, like, a friend of a friend..." But she wasn't buying it. Not even a little bit.

She launched into this whole thing about how dangerous it is, and how it can mess with your brain, and how it's *especially* dangerous when you're pregnant. It was a lot. A *lot* of information.

And honestly, it made me feel really small. Like I'd been caught doing something really stupid. Which, let's be real, I probably had. 

She didn't yell or anything. She just...looked at me with this sad, knowing look. And it was way more effective than any yelling could have been.

It was a wake-up call, I guess. I realized I was trying to cope with everything by self-medicating, and it wasn't working. And Su-Chin, as much as she can be a little scary, she just wanted me to be okay. She just wanted me to make good choices.

So yeah. That was...awkward. And slightly mortifying. And ultimately, probably a good thing. Even if I still wish I hadn't brought it up in the first place.

Ugh, okay, don't even *make* me relive that. Seriously. It was…a lot. It wasn't, like, a jump-scare movie kind of terrified. It was…a slow-creeping, everything-is-wrong kind of terrified.

It wasn't the people, exactly. It was…the *types* of people. Like, there was this couple, all smiles and holding hands, clearly excited. And then there was this woman, just staring straight ahead, looking completely numb. And a teenager, kinda my age, trying to look cool but failing miserably.

And they were all there for the same reason.

That's what got to me. It wasn't the possibility of, like, a bad outcome. It was the realization that everyone in that room was facing something huge. Something life-altering. And they were all just…waiting.

It was the quiet. It wasn't a peaceful quiet. It was a heavy, suffocating quiet. Like everyone was holding their breath, afraid to speak, afraid to jinx things.

And the magazines. Oh god, the magazines. All those perfect babies and happy families. It felt like a cruel joke. Like they were trying to tell me what my life *should* be, when I didn't even know what it *was* going to be.

It wasn't about being scared of the baby, or being scared of giving it up. It was about being scared of the unknown. Scared of the responsibility. Scared of messing everything up. Scared of…everything.

It was like, suddenly, I wasn't just Juno MacGuff, sarcastic teenager. I was…a potential mother. And that was terrifying. It still kinda is, if I'm being honest. It just…hit me all at once, you know? The weight of it all. And that waiting room? It was the epicenter of that weight. Ugh. I need a smoothie.

Ugh. Okay. This is…complicated. You’re bringing up old history, man. Like, really old history. It feels like a lifetime ago, honestly.

Do I *still* have feelings for Paulie Bleeker? That’s…a loaded question. It’s not like there’s a little Bleeker-shaped hole in my heart or anything. I’m not sitting around listening to The Moldy Peaches and crying into my pillow. Definitely not.

But…he was a good guy. A really good guy. He was the one person who didn’t treat me like I was crazy or weird or…pregnant. He just…accepted me. And he was funny. And he played guitar. And he understood my obsession with pop tarts.

It’s just…life happened, you know? We went our separate ways. He went to college, I…well, I had a baby. And things changed. People change.

I think what I felt for him was…a really important part of growing up. It was my first real crush, my first real heartbreak. It taught me a lot about myself, about what I wanted, and what I *didn’t* want.

So, do I still have feelings for him? Not in the way a teenage girl has feelings for her boyfriend. But I definitely still care about him. I hope he’s happy. I hope he’s doing well. And I’ll always remember him as…a really good friend.

It’s just…it’s over. And that’s okay. It’s just…sometimes it’s hard to let go of the past, you know? Especially when the past involved a really cute, guitar-playing guy who smelled like patchouli.

Don't make me think about this anymore, okay? It's making me feel all weird and nostalgic. I have a life now. A real life. And it doesn't really have room for teenage crushes anymore. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Vanessa's decorating choices. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. She's going for this whole "whimsical woodland creature" vibe, which, fine, whatever. But it's less "charming forest" and more "taxidermied animal convention."

Seriously, there are stuffed owls *everywhere*. And not cute, vintage owls. Like, creepy, staring-into-your-soul owls. And she got this mobile with little felt foxes and squirrels, and it's just...overwhelming. It's like the baby's gonna be born thinking it's living in a Disney movie, but a really unsettling one.

And the color scheme? Sage green and burnt orange. Sage green and burnt orange! It looks like a bad 70s kitchen. I tried to suggest maybe a little bit of blue, or even just...white? But she was all, "No, it needs to be earthy and natural!" Like, Vanessa, we live in Minnesota. Everything is already earthy and natural.

I mean, I appreciate that she's trying, okay? She's really excited about being a mom, and she wants everything to be perfect. But sometimes, "perfect" just looks...busy. And slightly terrifying.

I'm just hoping the baby doesn't develop a phobia of woodland creatures. Or burnt orange. I'm bracing myself for a room that looks like a Pinterest board exploded. Honestly, I'm half expecting a tiny log cabin to appear in the corner.

I'm just gonna try to stay out of it. It's her baby, her room. I'll just bring a really cool, non-owl-related gift and hope for the best. Maybe a black light. That'll spice things up.

Ugh. Nesting. Okay, so Annie, she's *really* into it. Like, full-on, color-coordinated, organic cotton sheets, mobile with hand-stitched felt animals kinda into it. It's...a lot.

Honestly? It kinda freaks me out. It feels like...making it too real, you know? Like, if I start picking out tiny socks and painting walls pale yellow, then it's gonna hit me all at once that I'm actually giving a baby away. And I'm not sure I'm ready for that. Not yet.

It's not that I don't want the baby to have nice things. It's just...it feels like I'm building a life for someone I'm not going to be around to see them live it. Does that make sense? It's weirdly sad.

Paul, he's trying to be helpful, but he mostly just looks confused when Annie starts talking about breathable bumpers and hypoallergenic mattresses. He's more of a "we'll figure it out" kinda guy. Which is good, I guess. Keeps things grounded.

I've done a little bit. I picked out a couple of books. Nothing too babyish. Like, "Harold and the Purple Crayon." That's a classic. And I helped Annie assemble the crib, which was surprisingly stressful. I almost stabbed myself with a screwdriver.

But the whole decorating thing? I'm leaving that to Annie. She's good at it. And honestly, I have enough on my plate. I'm trying to finish school, deal with my dad, and not completely fall apart. A perfectly decorated nursery just isn't a priority right now.

I think...I think I'm more focused on preparing *myself* for this. Making sure I'm okay. And making sure the baby is going to a good home. The room is just...stuff. It's the people who are going to make the difference.



It's just...it's complicated, okay? It's not like in the movies. It's messy and confusing and a little bit terrifying. And I'm just trying to navigate it the best I can.

Ugh, don't even get me started on those women. Seriously. It was...a whole other planet. Like, I walked into that mall and suddenly I felt like I was wearing a potato sack. Which, okay, maybe I was, relatively speaking.

It wasn't even the *stuff* they were buying, though there was a lot of beige cashmere involved. It was the *way* they were buying it. Like it was a competitive sport. And the sales associates? They were practically bowing down. "Oh, Mrs. So-and-So, this shade of taupe is *divine* on you!" Divine taupe? What even *is* divine taupe?

And the conversations! All about their summer houses and their kids' private schools and who's getting divorced. It was like a soap opera, but with more expensive handbags.

It just felt...empty, you know? Like they were trying to fill a hole with stuff. And they were so focused on appearances, on having the right labels, that they didn't even seem happy. They were just...existing in a world of privilege and pretending everything was perfect.

It made me feel kinda sad, actually. Not for myself, necessarily. I mean, I'm perfectly happy with my thrift store finds. But for them. Like, they had all this stuff, and they were still searching for something. 

It also made me appreciate my friends, and my life, a lot more. We don't have a lot of money, but we have each other. And we can laugh at ourselves. And we don't need divine taupe to feel good.

Honestly, it was a good reminder that money doesn't buy happiness. It just buys more stuff. And sometimes, less stuff is a really good thing. It's just...a lot. A lot of everything. And I'd rather have a good mix CD and a cheesy tater tot, any day.

Ugh. Okay, so, motherhood. It's...a lot. It's not what I expected, which, honestly, is probably a good thing, 'cause I didn't really expect much beyond, like, morning sickness and a tiny human needing constant feeding. It's way more complicated than that.

I mean, I knew it would be a responsibility. Obviously. But it's not just about changing diapers and making sure the kid doesn't eat dirt. It's about shaping a person. Like, *a whole person*. That's terrifying.

And the changes? Forget about it. My body is...different. My priorities are different. I used to be all about music and movies and avoiding people. Now I'm thinking about college funds and car seats and whether or not organic applesauce is actually worth the extra money. It's a total shift.

It's also kinda weird, giving up control. I'm used to being in charge of my own life, making my own decisions. Now I'm responsible for another human being. It's a huge weight.

But...it's also kinda amazing. Like, seeing this little person grow and learn and discover the world? It's pretty cool. And the love? It's...intense. It's not like anything I've ever felt before.

I'm still figuring it all out, you know? I'm not a natural mom or anything. I'm just trying to do the best I can. And I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to not have all the answers.

It's scary, and it's exhausting, and it's overwhelming. But it's also...worth it. I think. I mean, I'm still processing. But yeah. It's worth it. Even if it means I have to give up cheesy tater tots forever. (Okay, maybe not *forever*.)



It's just...a lot. A really, really big lot. And I'm just trying to keep my head above water. And maybe find a good playlist for late-night diaper changes.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. It’s not like I just picked a name out of a hat, you know? It’s not random. It’s…thought out. And kinda weird, when I say it out loud.

See, I was talking to Paul, and he was saying how his dad, he’s…not around. Not emotionally, anyway. And he was saying how much he wished he’d had a mom who was *really* there. Like, someone who actually wanted to be a mom.

And then I started thinking about it. I’m…not exactly equipped for this whole mom thing. I’m sixteen. I like music and vintage clothes and making sarcastic comments. I’m not ready to change diapers and deal with PTA meetings and…all of it.

So, I started looking for a couple who…well, who really *wanted* a baby. Not just someone who wanted to complete their picture-perfect family. Someone who would be excited and involved and…present.

And I found Mark and Vanessa Loring. They’re…older. Like, actually grown-up older. And they’ve been trying to have a baby for years. They’re both teachers, which is kinda dorky, but also means they’re patient and good with kids. And they’re just…nice. Really nice.

It’s not about finding the “perfect” parents, because that doesn’t exist. It’s about finding people who will love this baby and give it a good life. And I think Mark and Vanessa can do that.

It’s just…I want this baby to be wanted. I want it to be cherished. And I think with them, it will be. It’s not about me not wanting the baby, it’s about wanting the best for it. Even if that means I’m not the one raising it.

It’s…a lot to process, okay? Don’t judge me. It’s not an easy decision. And it’s definitely not something I’m taking lightly. It just feels…right. For everyone. I think. Hopefully.

Ugh. Okay, so keeping the baby. That's...a whole other level of complicated, right? It's not like I haven't thought about it, because, duh. It's just...a lot. And not the fun kind of a lot, like a really good mix CD.

First off, school. Like, hello? I'm a junior. I'm supposed to be figuring out colleges and stuff, not changing diapers and dealing with spit-up. I'd probably have to drop out, or at least take a really long break. Which means my future plans, which aren't exactly *set in stone* but are, you know, *there*, would get totally derailed.

Then there's the money thing. My dad's a construction worker, and my stepmom's a realtor. They're good people, but they're not exactly rolling in dough. I don't want to be a burden, and I definitely don't want my kid to grow up worrying about money all the time.

And then there's...me. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I like music and movies and making sarcastic comments. I'm not exactly equipped to be a mom. I mean, I can barely keep my room clean, let alone raise a human being.

Paul, the dad, he's...sweet. But he's also kinda clueless. He's a good guy, but he's not exactly ready to be a father either. We're both just kids, you know?

And then there's the judgment. People talking. Whispering. Staring. I'm already kind of an outsider, and this would just make it worse. I don't need that.

It's not that I don't love the idea of having a kid. It's just...it's terrifying. It's a huge responsibility. And I'm not sure I'm ready for it. It would change everything. Everything.

It's not like it's an impossible thing, but it would be...hard. Really hard. And I have to be honest with myself about that. It's not a decision to take lightly. It's a life-altering decision. And I need to be sure I'm making the right one, for me and for the baby.



It's a lot to think about, okay? Don't judge me for being scared. It's a scary situation.

Ugh, Leah. She meant well, I guess. But seriously, the things that woman came up with... It was a lot.

Okay, so I told her I was thinking about adoption, right? And she just...froze. Like, a full-body freeze. And then she started talking about how she and Mark could, like, *raise the baby* with me. 

She painted this whole picture of us all living together, a big happy family. She said I could finish school and they'd help with everything. It was supposed to sound appealing, I guess. But it just sounded...complicated. And terrifying.

She kept saying it was the "most responsible" thing to do. Like, adoption wasn't responsible enough for her. It was like she couldn't wrap her head around the idea of me *not* being a mom, even though that's exactly what I wanted.

It wasn't a suggestion, really. It was more like a desperate plea. She was trying to convince herself as much as me, I think. She was picturing this perfect little family and I was just...messing it up.

Honestly, it just made me feel worse. It made me feel guilty for wanting something different than what she expected. It was a lot to deal with, on top of everything else. It's why I needed to talk to Paul and Annie so much. They actually *listened* to me, instead of trying to tell me what to do. Leah just wanted to fix things, and sometimes, fixing things isn't what anyone needs.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about that? It was, like, months ago. And it wasn't *making fun* exactly. It was...observing. And commenting. Out loud. Which, yeah, maybe wasn't my finest moment.

Look, I was stressed, okay? I was pregnant. And dealing with Paul and Mark and Annie and everything. And I went to that play area with Vanessa to, like, try and have a normal afternoon. But it was just...a lot.

All those moms, all perfectly put together, talking about organic snacks and developmental milestones. It felt so...fake. Like they were all trying to prove something. And I was just sitting there, feeling huge and awkward and completely unprepared for this whole baby thing.

So, yeah, I made a comment about them being "Stepford wives." It was a stupid thing to say. I didn't mean to be mean. I was just...venting. And trying to make myself feel better by pointing out how ridiculous everything seemed.

It was a defense mechanism, okay? I build walls. I say sarcastic things. It's how I cope. It doesn't make it right, but it's what I do.

I felt bad about it afterwards. Vanessa gave me *the look*. And I realized I was being a jerk. But it's hard to admit you're wrong, you know? Especially when you're a teenager and everything feels so overwhelming.

I'm not proud of it. I just...I was a mess. And sometimes messes say stupid things. It doesn't mean I'm a bad person. It just means I'm a work in progress. And honestly, aren't we all?

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…complicated. And honestly, still kinda makes me cringe when I think about it.

Look, Vanessa Loring is…intense. She's got this whole "earth mother" vibe going on, and she was *so* excited about the baby. Like, way more excited than I was, at first. And she was being really nice to me, you know? Trying to be supportive. Which, I appreciated. Sort of.

I was still processing everything, okay? I hadn't even really accepted that there was a tiny human growing inside me. It was all just…weird. And Vanessa, she just…reached out. Without asking. And put her hand on my stomach.

It was a total violation of personal space, honestly. I wanted to pull away, but I froze. I think I was just shocked. And she was talking about how "connected" she felt to the baby, and how "beautiful" it was, and it was all just…too much.

I didn't say anything. I just stood there, letting her do it. Which, I know, was stupid. I should have said something. But I was awkward and overwhelmed and didn't know what to do.

It wasn't about wanting her to touch my belly. It was about not wanting to make a scene. And maybe, a little bit, about wanting someone to be excited about the baby with me. Even if that someone was a little…overbearing.

It was a mistake. I learned my lesson. My body, my rules. And I definitely made that clear to everyone after that. But yeah. Vanessa and the belly touch. Not a good memory. Don't even get me started.

Ugh, okay, this is…a thing. It’s super weird, honestly. Like, I get it, I’m carrying a human being. It’s kinda hard to miss. But the way people just…part like the Red Sea when I walk down the street? It’s bizarre.

At first, I thought they were just being polite. You know, giving a pregnant lady some space. Which is nice, I guess. But it’s more than that. It’s like they’re afraid of *breaking* me or something. Or maybe they’re afraid of catching…pregnancy? I don’t know.

It’s like I’m suddenly invisible, except for the giant bump. People avoid eye contact. They whisper. They move their kids closer. It’s like I’m a walking biohazard.

And it’s not just strangers. It’s people I *know*. Like, my dad will practically walk into walls to get out of my way. It’s…awkward.

I think it’s because people don’t know what to say. They don’t know how to act around someone who’s pregnant. It’s a reminder of their own mortality, or their own choices, or whatever. So they just…give way.

It’s also kinda isolating. It’s like I’m not a person anymore, just a vessel. A walking, talking incubator. Which, okay, I *am* an incubator, but I’m also still Juno. I still have opinions and feelings and a really excellent taste in music.

It’s just…weird. And a little bit sad. I wish people would just treat me like a normal person. But I guess that’s not gonna happen anytime soon. I’m stuck being the pregnant girl. It’s a whole thing.



Don't even get me started on the unsolicited advice. That's a whole other level of weird.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps going on about Mark and Vanessa being, like, the perfect parents. "Wholesome." "Stable." "They have a Pottery Barn catalog for a life." And yeah, on paper, they are. They're…intimidatingly perfect, honestly.

It's not that I don't think they'd be *good* parents. They absolutely would. They've got the house, the careers, the dog…the whole nine yards. It's just…it feels weird. Like, too easy. Too…planned.

I mean, I'm not saying I want to give the baby to some, like, biker gang or something. But Mark and Vanessa, they've been trying to adopt for *years*. They've got a nursery already decorated. It feels like they want a baby as an accessory, you know? Like another item to complete their perfect life.

And I'm not judging, okay? I just…I want the baby to be wanted for *who* the baby is, not for what the baby represents. I want someone who's gonna be messy and imperfect and real. Someone who's gonna love the baby even when it's screaming and covered in poop.

It's hard to explain. It's like…I'm giving up a baby, which is already a huge deal. And I want to make sure that baby is going to a place where it's truly loved and cherished, not just…added to a collection.

Plus, they're kinda…intense. Vanessa keeps sending me articles about prenatal care and organic baby food. It's a lot. I just need to feel comfortable, you know? I need to feel like I'm making the right decision, not just the easiest one.

It's not about them being bad people. It's about me needing to be sure. It's about the baby deserving the best. And sometimes, the "best" isn't the most obvious choice. It's just…complicated. Okay? It's really complicated.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa. Okay, so, they're...a lot. Honestly? They're kinda the definition of "trying too hard." Like, they're so eager to be the perfect, quirky, progressive adoptive parents that it's almost exhausting to be around them.

Don't get me wrong, they're nice people. Really nice. Vanessa's all earthy-crunchy and Mark's trying to be cool and relatable, but it feels...calculated, you know? Like they read a book on how to be good parents and are just following the instructions.

And the whole vinyl collection thing? Seriously? It's a bit much. It's like, "Look at us, we're hip and we appreciate music!" I get it, you like The Clash. Good for you.

But, and this is the part that's kinda important, they genuinely *want* a baby. And they're gonna be good parents. They're stable, they're loving, and they're prepared. They're just...a little bit much to process.

I think what gets to me is that they seem to think they have all the answers. Like they know exactly what's best for this kid. And I'm just sitting there, a pregnant teenager, feeling like I barely know what's best for *myself*. 

But they've been really supportive of *me*, which is good. They haven't tried to pressure me or make me feel guilty. They just want to make sure the baby has a good life. And I think, ultimately, that's all that matters.

So, yeah. They're weird. They're a little bit pretentious. But they're good people. And I think they're gonna be great parents. Even if they do have a ridiculous amount of vinyl.

Ugh, okay, so Mrs. Spivey. That woman. Honestly, she's a whole *case study* in passive-aggressive judgment. It's not like she came right out and said, "You're not good enough for my precious Bleeker!" No, it was way more subtle. And way more annoying.

I think it was a bunch of things, really. First of all, I'm...me. I'm not exactly polished. I say what I think, I wear what I want, and I'm not afraid to be a little weird. Mrs. Spivey, she's all about appearances. Everything has to be just so. And I definitely don't fit into her "just so" aesthetic.

Then there's the whole age thing. Bleeker was a senior, I was a junior. She probably thought I was just a phase, a rebellious fling. Like I was gonna corrupt her sweet, sensitive Bleeker. Which, let's be real, Bleeker doesn't *need* corrupting. He's perfectly capable of being a dork all on his own.

And I think she just didn't understand me. I wasn't like the other girls Bleeker had dated. I didn't fawn over him or try to be someone I wasn't. I challenged him, I made him laugh, and I actually *listened* to him. And I think that scared her. She wanted someone who would just...agree with everything he said.

She kept making these little comments, you know? About how I was "spirited" or "independent." Which is code for "difficult" and "unmanageable." And she always tried to steer the conversation towards Bleeker's future, like he needed to be with someone who could help him achieve his goals. As if I was just gonna hold him back.

It was exhausting. Honestly, I just wanted her to see that I cared about Bleeker, and that he cared about me. But she was too busy worrying about what other people thought. It's a whole thing. Moms, man. They're complicated.

Ugh, okay, so the Mark CD. Right. That was…a whole thing. It wasn't like I was *eager* to listen to it, okay? It wasn't like I was sitting around, all hearts and flowers, waiting for a mix tape from a guy who was, let's be real, kinda clueless.

It was mostly because Paul…well, Paul was being Paul. He was all, "You should listen to it. It'll give you insight into his soul." Insight into his soul? Seriously? Like I needed a musical roadmap to understand why Mark was so…Mark.

But he was right, in a weird way. I mean, I was already kinda stuck with the whole situation, you know? The baby and everything. And I was trying to figure out what Mark was thinking, what he wanted. Not that I *cared* cared, obviously. It was just…practical.

So I put it on. And it was…surprisingly good. Not like, amazing. But good. It wasn't all sappy love songs, which I was expecting. There was The Moldy Peaches, which, okay, points to Mark for having good taste. And some other stuff that was just…thoughtful. 

It wasn't about trying to win me over, or impress me. It was just…him. A glimpse into what he liked, what he thought was funny, what made him *him*. And I realized, he wasn't trying to be someone he wasn't. He was just…a dork. A sweet, well-meaning dork.

And I guess, after a while, I started listening to it not because Paul told me to, or because I was trying to figure out Mark. I started listening to it because…it was a good CD. And it made me feel…less alone. Which, you know, is a pretty big deal when you're a pregnant teenager trying to figure out your life.

So yeah. That's how I started listening to the Mark CD. It wasn't love at first listen, okay? It was more like…reluctant curiosity that slowly turned into something else. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh. Don't even *start*. Eight months. It feels…weird. Like, profoundly weird. It's not like in the movies, okay? There aren't violins swelling and a golden light shining on my belly. It's mostly just…pressure. And heartburn. And a constant need to pee.

It's also kinda terrifying. Like, this is actually happening. I'm about to be responsible for a tiny human. A tiny human who will need food and clothes and, like, a whole life. It's a lot.

I mean, I've been trying to prepare. I've read all the books, I've taken the classes, I've even started knitting a hideous baby blanket. But nothing really prepares you for the reality of it. It's like, you can read about riding a roller coaster, but it's not the same as actually being on one.

And it's not just the physical stuff. It's the emotional stuff too. I'm happy, I think. And scared. And sad, sometimes. Because I'm giving this baby up, and that's…hard. Even though I know it's the right thing to do.

Paul and Annie are being amazing, though. They're so excited, and they're really good at making me feel like I'm not completely losing my mind. And my dad…well, he's trying. He keeps offering me weird health advice and making awkward small talk. But I know he cares.

So yeah. Eight months. It's a lot. It's uncomfortable. It's scary. But it's also…kind of amazing. I'm growing a person. That's pretty wild, when you think about it.

Just don't ask me to bend over and tie my shoes. That's a lost cause.

Ugh, don't even *start* with the staring. It's a constant thing. Like, I could be walking down the street wearing a full hazmat suit and people would *still* find a reason to look. It's infuriating.

I think...it's a combination of things. First of all, I'm not exactly blending in, okay? I've got the boots, the band t-shirts, the general air of "don't mess with me." I'm not trying to be invisible.

And then, you know...the whole pregnant thing. That definitely gets people looking. Like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo. "Oh, look at the teenage mom! How fascinating!" It's not fascinating, it's my life.

But honestly, I think it's more than that. I think people are just...confused by me. I don't fit into their little boxes. I'm not what they expect. I'm sarcastic and independent and I don't really care what anyone thinks. And that freaks people out.

They're probably trying to figure out what's *wrong* with me. Like I'm broken or something. But I'm not broken. I'm just...me. And if they can't handle that, that's their problem.

I used to get really self-conscious about it, but now I just try to ignore it. Or, if they stare long enough, I stare back. With a really intense look. That usually gets them to look away.

It's exhausting, though. Sometimes I just want to wear a sign that says, "Yes, I'm pregnant. No, it's not your business." But then again, that would just give them something else to stare at. It's a vicious cycle.



Seriously, though. Stop staring. It's rude.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? Bleek and Katrina? That's...a choice. A *bold* choice. Like, a "wearing socks with sandals" level of choice.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek, okay? He deserves to be happy. He's a good guy. A little...intense, maybe. And definitely obsessed with fantasy stuff. But good. And Katrina, she's...Katrina. She's got her thing going on. She's, like, aggressively preppy and always smells faintly of hairspray.

But them? Together? It's just...weird. It's like pairing a dragon with a debutante. They live in completely different universes. I mean, he's building elaborate Dungeons & Dragons sets in his basement, and she's planning her future as a society wife. It's a clash of civilizations.

I guess maybe opposites attract? But I'm picturing a lot of awkward silences and forced small talk. And probably a lot of Bleek trying to explain the intricacies of elven warfare to Katrina, who will just stare at him blankly.

Honestly, I'm mostly worried about Bleek getting his heart broken. Katrina seems...a little bit out of his league. But hey, maybe I'm wrong. Maybe they'll have a magical night and fall madly in love. 

It's just...I'm bracing myself for a disaster. A beautifully awkward, tragically hilarious disaster. And I'll probably be there to witness it, because that's just my life. It's always a disaster. But a funny disaster. Usually.

Ugh. Okay, deep breaths. This is…a lot to unpack, even for me, and I'm usually pretty good at talking. It's not like I sat down and made a list, you know? It's more like…things just *happened*, and I slowly started to figure stuff out.

I guess the biggest thing I learned is that I'm way more capable than I thought I was. Like, seriously. Before all this, I was just…Juno. A sarcastic teenager who liked records and avoiding responsibility. I thought I was pretty set in my ways. And then BAM. Pregnant. And suddenly, I had to actually *think* about the future. Not just my future, but someone else's.

I used to think being independent meant doing everything on your own. But it turns out, it's okay to ask for help. Actually, it's *good* to ask for help. My parents, Paul and Annie…they were amazing. They didn't judge me, they just…supported me. And that was huge. It made me realize I don't have to be a lone wolf.

I also learned that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I put up a lot of walls, you know? To protect myself. But underneath all the sarcasm, I actually care a lot. About people, about doing the right thing. And giving this baby up for adoption wasn't about giving up on it. It was about giving it the best possible life. A life I couldn't give it. And that took a lot of courage, I think.

And…I learned that growing up isn't about knowing all the answers. It's about figuring things out as you go. It's about making mistakes and learning from them. It's about being okay with not being okay.

It's still scary, honestly. I'm still figuring out who I am, what I want to do with my life. But I'm not as afraid anymore. I think…I think I'm going to be okay. And maybe, just maybe, I'm even going to be happy.

It's weird, right? Getting all philosophical about a baby you're giving away. But that's life, I guess. It's messy and complicated and totally unpredictable. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just…roll with it. And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. They always help.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Bleeker and Katrina? It's...it's just *painful* to watch, okay? Like, a slow-motion train wreck set to a really sad indie song.

Look, I get it. Katrina's...intense. She's got a whole aesthetic going on, and she's really into, like, poetry and feelings and stuff. And Bleeker? He's Bleeker. Sweet, clueless Bleeker. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's about as emotionally aware as a garden gnome.

And he's letting her think...things. He's letting her build up this whole fantasy in her head about them, and he's just...smiling and nodding and not saying anything to shut it down. It's not fair to her. It's just cruel.

I mean, I've been through a lot of confusing stuff lately, okay? With the baby and Paul and everything. And I know what it's like to have your feelings messed with. It sucks. It really, really sucks.

And Katrina deserves better than to be led on by someone who clearly doesn't feel the same way. She deserves someone who actually *sees* her, you know? Not just someone who thinks she's "interesting" or "different."

It's just...it's frustrating. I want to shake Bleeker and be like, "Dude, wake up! You're hurting her!" But I can't. Because then I'd be the crazy girl interfering in other people's relationships. And I've already got enough going on, thanks.

So I just have to sit here and watch it happen, and it makes me want to punch something. Or maybe just listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud and try to forget about it. But it's hard. It's just...hard.

Ugh, prom. Okay, so when you're, like, twelve, prom seems like the ultimate. The sparkly dress, the slow dance, the perfect date...it's all very fairytale-ish. But then you actually get *to* the age where you can go, and it's...weird.

It's like, suddenly everyone's trying way too hard. All the pressure to find the perfect dress, the perfect date, the perfect corsage. It's exhausting just *thinking* about it. And everyone's acting like it's this huge, life-altering event, but it's just a dance. A really expensive, overhyped dance.

And the couples? Forget about it. It's all awkward hand-holding and forced smiles. Like, if you actually *liked* someone, you wouldn't need a formal occasion to hang out with them. You'd just...hang out.

Plus, it's all so…conformist. Everyone's trying to fit in, to look a certain way, to do what's expected. And I'm not really into that. I'd rather just hang out with my friends, listen to music, and not worry about what everyone else thinks.

It's like, when you're younger, prom represents freedom and possibility. But when you're actually old enough to go, you realize it's just another set of rules and expectations. And honestly? I have better things to do with my time. Like, figuring out my life, or listening to The Moldy Peaches. Or just, you know, being me.

It's not that prom is *bad*, it's just...not cool anymore. It's for people who still believe in fairytales. And I'm kinda over fairytales. I'm more into reality. Even if reality is messy and complicated and involves unplanned pregnancies. It's real, you know? And that's way cooler than a sparkly dress.

Ugh. Okay. This is…not my favorite topic, obviously. But you asked. And it's kinda important, I guess. It's not like I just woke up one morning and was all, "Yeah, let's just give the baby away!" It was…complicated.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *lunch*, let alone what I wanted to do with the rest of my life. I was failing Shop class, for crying out loud. I wasn't exactly equipped to raise a human being.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby, too. I wanted that kid to have everything. A stable home, parents who were actually ready for it, a good education, all that stuff. I knew I couldn't provide that, not at that point in my life. I wasn't judging anyone who *could*, I just knew I wasn't one of them.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. Choosing Mark and Vanessa…that was brutal. There were so many couples, and they were all so nice. But Mark and Vanessa…they just felt right. They were a little quirky, a little awkward, but they were genuinely good people. They wanted a baby, and they were ready to love it.

People kept asking me if I was sad. And I was. I was *terrified*. But it wasn't just sadness. It was…relief, too. Knowing that the baby was going to be okay. Knowing that I was making the right decision, even if it was the hardest one.

It wasn't about giving up something I wanted. It was about giving the baby something *better*. It was about being selfless, even when I didn't feel very selfless at all.

And it wasn't like I just disappeared after the birth. I stayed in touch with Mark and Vanessa. I got to see the baby grow up. It was…weird, at first. But it was also really rewarding.

It wasn't a perfect situation. Nothing ever is. But it was the best situation for everyone involved. And I wouldn't change it. It taught me a lot about myself, about responsibility, about love. And it made me realize that sometimes, the bravest thing you can do is let go.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I try to focus on the fact that I did the right thing. And that the baby – her name is Hannah, by the way – is happy and loved. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, my dad. He means well, okay? He really does. But sometimes he just...overthinks things. Like, a LOT. And then he starts worrying out loud, and it's just...a lot.

It's not like I'm just handing over a puppy, you know? This is a *baby*. My baby. And I've thought this through. A lot. I wouldn't just pick anyone to raise him. Mark and Vanessa...they're good people. They're excited. They're prepared. They actually seem like they'd be *good* parents.

But my dad? He's convinced they're secretly evil masterminds who are going to steal the baby and sell him on the black market or something. It's ridiculous. He keeps talking about "legal loopholes" and "background checks" and "making sure they're financially stable enough to provide for a child for the next eighteen years." Like I haven't already considered all that!

I get it, he's protective. He's my dad. But it feels like he doesn't trust my judgment. Like he thinks I'm too naive to make a decision this big. And that's...annoying. And kinda hurtful.

I told him, "Dad, I'm not stupid. I'm doing this for the right reasons. And I've chosen people who I believe will give this baby a good life." But he just keeps fretting.

It's like he thinks I haven't thought about the consequences. Like I haven't cried about this for weeks. Like I haven't spent hours agonizing over whether I'm doing the right thing.

I just want him to trust me. To support me. To not make me feel like I'm making a huge mistake. But that's my dad. He's always been a worrier. I guess I just have to deal with it. And try not to roll my eyes too much. It's hard. Really hard.

Ugh. Seriously? *That* is what he goes with? After everything? It's just...so typical. My dad, he's a good guy, I guess. He tries. But he's also, like, fundamentally incapable of understanding anything that doesn't involve power tools or classic rock.

"Not knowing when to say when." What does that even *mean*? It's not like I'm out there collecting Beanie Babies or something. I made a decision. A really big, scary, life-altering decision. And I'm owning it. 

He thinks it's about the pregnancy, obviously. He thinks I should have...what? Just disappeared? Pretended it didn't happen? Like that's even an option. He doesn't get that it wasn't about *wanting* to be pregnant. It was about what was best for the baby. And for me.

It's just frustrating, you know? He wants me to be this little girl who just follows the rules and doesn't make waves. But I'm not that girl. I never was. I'm messy and complicated and I make mistakes. And sometimes, those mistakes lead to something...unexpected.

And honestly, maybe *he's* the one who doesn't know when to say when. He's always trying to fix things, to control things. He needs to learn to just let people live their lives.

So yeah, his comment? It stung. But it also just...confirmed what I already knew. He's not going to understand. And that's okay. I don't need him to understand. I just need him to be my dad. Even if he's a little clueless sometimes.

I just rolled my eyes and walked away. What else are you gonna do? Argue with a man who thinks Led Zeppelin is the answer to all of life's problems? I don't have the energy.

Ugh, the Loring's neighborhood. Seriously? It's...a lot. Like, aggressively perfect. It's the kind of place where the lawns are all the same length and the houses all look like they were designed by robots. And the gates? Don't even get me started on the gates. It's like they're trying to keep *reality* out.

It's just...weird. It feels so disconnected from everything. Like, people actually *choose* to live in a bubble like that? It's kinda sad, honestly. It's like they're afraid of the real world. Afraid of, like, messiness and imperfection and...people who aren't exactly like them.

And the whole "perfect family" vibe? It's suffocating. Like, everyone's gotta be smiling and waving and pretending everything's amazing all the time. It's exhausting just *looking* at it.

I mean, I get that Mark and Vanessa want the best for their kid, and they think that means a safe, pristine environment. But it feels so...artificial. Like, a kid needs to experience the real world, you know? They need to see that things aren't always perfect. They need to learn how to deal with stuff.

It's just...not my scene. I prefer a little bit of chaos. A little bit of grit. A little bit of *realness*. Give me a messy room and a quirky neighbor over a perfectly manicured lawn and a gated community any day.

It's not that I think they're bad people, the Loring's. They're just...different. And their neighborhood is just...a little bit creepy. It's like Stepford Wives meets Pleasantville. And that's not a compliment.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? She was…intense. Like, *really* put together. Perfectly styled hair, always wearing something cute, and just…shiny. Like a brand new penny. And I was, you know, me. Baggy jeans, band t-shirts, perpetually looking like I hadn't slept in a week. We were…opposites.

She seemed really nice, don't get me wrong. Super polite, always offering me snacks, asking about my day. But it felt…forced. Like she was trying too hard. And she kept talking about her perfect life, her perfect boyfriend, her perfect future. It was exhausting.

I remember thinking she was probably one of those girls who had everything planned out since she was five. College, career, husband, 2.5 kids, the whole shebang. And I was just…winging it. Which, honestly, is my preferred method of operation.

I was also kinda suspicious. Like, why was she so eager to be friends with the pregnant, sarcastic teenager? It felt like she was studying me, trying to figure me out. Which, to be fair, is probably what everyone was doing. But with Vanessa, it felt…different. More calculated.

I didn't *dislike* her, exactly. She just…intimidated me. She was everything I wasn't, and I wasn't sure what she wanted from me. It took a while to realize she wasn't judging me, she was just…different. And maybe, just maybe, she was a little lost too, even if she didn't show it.

It was a slow burn, getting to know her. But eventually, I realized she wasn't so bad. She was just…Vanessa. And she actually had a pretty good heart, underneath all the perfection. But those first impressions? Definitely a little wary.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with Bleeker and the backpack. It's...complicated. It wasn't, like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was just...a backpack. A really heavy backpack. Filled with, like, all my anxieties and a half-eaten bag of chips.

But yeah, he offered to carry it. And it was...unexpected. Bleeker is, you know, Bleeker. Quiet. Kind of awkward. Usually glued to his guitar. He's not exactly the strong, silent type. He's more the...quietly observing type.

So when he just...said, "Here, let me get that," it threw me. It wasn't about the backpack, really. It was about *him* noticing I was struggling. It was about him offering to help, without me even asking. 

I think I probably made some sarcastic comment. I always do. Something like, "Oh, so now you're my pack mule?" Or maybe, "Don't strain yourself." I'm good at deflecting, okay? It's a coping mechanism.

But inside? I was...flustered. And maybe a little bit touched. It was a small thing, but it felt...significant. Like he was seeing *me*, not just the girl who accidentally got pregnant. 

It was one of those moments where you realize maybe someone actually cares. And that's...scary. And nice. And really confusing. Especially when you're a teenager who's trying to figure out everything out.

So yeah, the backpack. It was heavy. But it wasn't the weight of the backpack that got to me. It was the weight of everything else. And Bleeker, in his own weird, quiet way, just...lightened the load a little bit. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'd probably freak out.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about that? It's kinda embarrassing to talk about, honestly. But fine. You asked.

See, before I found that comic, I was just...existing. I was kinda numb, I guess. I mean, I was funny, and I had friends, but I still felt...off. Like I was watching my life happen to someone else. And I was definitely fixated on my body. I mean, who *isn't* at that age? Especially when you're, you know, dealing with...stuff.

I called myself a fat dork a lot. It was just...easier. It was a way to beat everyone else to the punch, you know? To make fun of myself before they could. It was a defense mechanism. A really lame one.

But then I read "Most Fruitful Yuki." And it wasn't about being skinny or perfect or anything like that. It was about being *real*. Yuki was just...herself. She was flawed and messy and honest. And she didn't care what anyone else thought.

And it just...clicked. 

It wasn't about suddenly loving my body or anything. It was about realizing that my body was just...a vessel. It was carrying me through life. And it didn't need to be perfect to be worthy. It didn't need to fit into some stupid ideal.

It was about accepting myself, flaws and all. And realizing that my worth wasn't tied to my weight or my appearance. It was about who I was on the inside. 

It sounds cheesy, I know. But it was a really big deal for me. It was like...a weight lifted. And I stopped calling myself a fat dork. Mostly. It's a habit, you know? But I started being kinder to myself. And that made all the difference.

That comic just...gave me permission to be me. And that's something I really needed. It was a little bit of magic, honestly. A little bit of comic book magic.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about that whole...superhero thing? Seriously? It's still mortifying. Like, I'm trying to navigate a totally normal, albeit slightly complicated, situation, and then Mark decides to compare me to *Captain Excellent*? It's just...a lot.

I think...I think he was trying to be nice? In a really, really awkward way. He's not exactly known for his smooth social skills, you know? He probably thought, "Oh, Juno's going through something big and kinda scary, and this superhero is also dealing with a big life change...it's a connection!" 

It's just...a terrible connection. Captain Excellent is, like, fighting crime and saving the world. I'm trying to figure out whether to keep a baby or not and pass my history test. It's not the same thing. At all.

I think he also probably thought it was...romantic? Like, he was trying to say I was strong and capable. Which, okay, maybe I am. But I don't need a comic book analogy to prove it. I'm dealing with this on my own terms, okay? I don't need to be a superhero to be a good person.

And honestly, it's kinda insulting. It implies that being pregnant is some kind of heroic feat. It's not. It's just...life. It's messy and complicated and sometimes really scary. And it doesn't need a cape and a catchy slogan.

So yeah, I think he was trying to be sweet, but he completely missed the mark. It just made me feel even more awkward and confused. Which, let's be real, is pretty much my default setting.

Ugh, okay, this is…complicated. And honestly, it's something I've thought about a *lot*. Everyone keeps throwing around terms like "open adoption" and "semi-open" and it feels like they're talking about a different planet.

Look, I get the idea behind open adoption. Keeping some kind of connection with the birth parents, letting the kid know where they came from…it sounds nice, in theory. Like, a really *together* kind of nice. But it also feels…messy. And I'm already dealing with enough mess, okay?

For me, it was always about wanting to give this baby the best possible start. A clean break. A family who could love them completely, without any…complications. I didn't want to be a lingering presence, a "friend" or a "visiting aunt." That just feels…weird. And potentially confusing for the kid.

I mean, imagine growing up and knowing your birth mom is, like, a few phone calls away? That's a lot to process. I wanted this baby to have parents who were fully and completely *their* parents, without any shadow of me hanging over them.

It's not that I don't care, okay? I do. A lot. But I think sometimes the most loving thing you can do is let go. Completely. And for me, that meant a closed adoption. It felt…safer. For everyone.

I know some people think it's selfish, like I'm trying to erase myself from the equation. But it's not about me. It's about what I thought was best for the baby. And honestly, it's about me needing to move on with my life, too. I'm seventeen. I have a future to figure out.

It's not a judgment on anyone who chooses open adoption. It's just…not for me. I needed the closure. I needed the distance. And I needed to know that this baby was going to be loved and cherished by a family who could give them everything I couldn't.

It's a hard decision, okay? And there's no right or wrong answer. It just…felt right for me. And that's all that matters.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I haven't had enough time to think about it. It's not like being pregnant at sixteen *doesn't* force you to do a lot of soul-searching.

Before all this happened, I was just...Juno. The sarcastic girl who liked records and avoided drama. I was good at observing people, making witty comments, keeping everyone at arm's length. I thought that was enough. I thought being different was enough. But it wasn't. It was just a way to hide.

Getting pregnant…that was a wake-up call. A really loud, obnoxious wake-up call. Suddenly, it wasn't just about me anymore. There was a whole other person depending on me. And that was terrifying.

But it also forced me to grow up. Like, actually grow up. I had to deal with things I never thought I'd have to deal with. Doctors, lawyers, potential adoptive parents…it was a lot. And it wasn't always pretty.

Meeting Vanessa and Mark…they were amazing. They weren't what I expected, but they were good people. And seeing them, seeing how much they wanted a baby, it made me realize that giving this baby up wasn't a failure. It was a brave thing to do. It was the right thing to do.

And Paul…ugh, Paul. He was a mess, but he was *my* mess. He showed me that it was okay to be vulnerable, to let people in. He showed me that it was okay to be scared and confused and not have all the answers.

Through all of it, I realized that my strength wasn't in being sarcastic or different. It was in being honest. Honest with myself, and honest with others. It was in making difficult choices, even when they hurt. It was in accepting responsibility for my actions.

I used to think my identity was just being "Juno." But now I know it's more than that. It's about who I am as a person. It's about my values, my beliefs, my ability to love and to forgive. It's about being strong enough to make my own decisions, even when they're not easy.

It wasn't a straight line, you know? There were a lot of bumps and detours. But in the end, I found my own way. And I think…I think I'm okay with who I am. I'm still Juno, the sarcastic girl who likes records. But I'm also a little bit more. I'm a little bit stronger. And I'm a little bit more sure of myself. And that's a pretty good feeling.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the prom stuff. It's...complicated. And kinda embarrassing. But fine, you want to know? I guess it's a part of the story.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes.

Yeah, I know. Super sappy. Connor picked it. He was all, "It's about finding someone who makes everything feel new," and I was like, "Okay, Connor, dial it back a notch." But honestly? It kinda fit. 

It wasn't a perfect dance, okay? I'm not a graceful dancer. And Mark...well, Mark is Mark. He's sweet, but he's not exactly Fred Astaire. We mostly just kinda swayed and avoided stepping on each other's feet. 

But it was...nice. It was a moment. A weird, awkward, kinda beautiful moment. And it was the first time I really felt like...I don't know...like maybe things were going to be okay. Like maybe I wasn't completely alone in all this mess.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be all cynical and sarcastic, not all mushy and sentimental. But yeah. "First Day of My Life." It's a good song. Even if it reminds me of a really weird time in my life.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a thing people ask me about. Like, it wasn't a simple decision, alright? It wasn't like I was picking a flavor of ice cream. It was a *baby*. And people's lives.

Look, Mark was a good guy. Sweet, kinda clueless, but good. And Vanessa…Vanessa was put together. She had her life planned out. She knew what she wanted. And honestly? That baby deserved someone who knew what they were doing. Someone who wasn't, like, still figuring out if they even *wanted* to be a dad.

Mark leaving Vanessa? That would have been a disaster. For everyone. Vanessa would have been heartbroken, Mark would have been a mess, and the baby…the baby would have grown up with two parents who were constantly fighting and blaming each other. No thanks.

It wasn't about me thinking Vanessa was "better" or anything. It was about what was best for the kid. Mark was still gonna be in the baby's life, he was gonna be a good uncle. He could be the fun one. And Vanessa could be the stable one. It was a good balance.

Plus, let's be real, Mark and Vanessa were already a unit. They had a house, a life, a future. It would have been way harder for Mark to start over. And I didn't want to put that on him. Or on the baby.

It wasn't about me wanting to "fix" their relationship. It was about recognizing that they were already a family, and that the baby would be better off with them. It was the least messy option, honestly. And sometimes, the least messy option is the right one.

It wasn't easy, okay? It was a really hard decision. But I stand by it. I really do. I wanted that baby to have the best life possible, and I truly believed that was with Mark and Vanessa. And seeing them now? Seeing how happy they are? It makes me think I made the right call.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on Mark. Seriously. It still…it still stings, you know? Even thinking about it.

It wasn't like I was expecting a parade or anything. I mean, he was a senior, a musician, kinda flaky. But I thought…I don't know. I thought he'd be more…something. More willing to, like, *try*.

When he said he wasn't ready? It wasn't the words themselves, it was the way he said them. Like it was no big deal. Like *I* was the one being dramatic. Like my body hadn't just decided to do this whole life-altering thing.

It felt…small. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like this whole situation, this baby, wasn't real to him. And it was just…disappointing. Really disappointing.

I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly father material. But I was hoping he'd at least *want* to be. I was hoping he'd be scared *with* me, instead of just…checking out.

It made me realize I was doing this mostly alone. And that was…terrifying. It was a lot to process, you know? I was sixteen. I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and boys and stuff, not figuring out how to give a baby up for adoption.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be all sarcastic and detached, like I always am. But inside? I was just…sad. And scared. And really, really angry.

It's funny, 'cause I spent so much time worrying about finding the perfect parents for the baby, and I didn't even have a decent co-parent. Go figure.

It sucked. It really, really sucked. But it also…it made me stronger, I guess. It made me realize I could handle things on my own. And that was a good thing. Even if it was a really hard thing to learn.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, people always ask about Mark. Like he's some kind of fascinating specimen. He *is* weird, don't get me wrong. Like, aggressively, almost offensively weird. But that's...kind of the point.

Everyone else at school, they're all trying so hard to be normal. To fit in. To wear the right clothes and say the right things and listen to the right music. It's exhausting just *watching* them.
