Mark doesn't care about any of that. He's just...himself. Completely and unapologetically. He collects records, he builds robots, he talks about obscure movies. He doesn't try to impress anyone. And honestly, that's really refreshing.

At first, I just thought he was a goofball. A total dork. But then I started noticing things. He actually *listened* when I talked. He didn't judge me for, you know, my life choices. He just...accepted me. Which, let me tell you, is a rare thing.

He's also really funny. Like, unintentionally funny. He doesn't even realize how ridiculous he is sometimes. And he's surprisingly insightful. He sees things differently than everyone else, and sometimes that's exactly what you need.

Being around him felt...safe. Like I could just be myself without having to worry about what anyone else thought. And that was a really big deal, especially at that time in my life.

His life *is* weird. It's full of broken appliances and half-finished projects and a general sense of chaos. But it's *his* chaos. And I liked being a part of it. It was a reminder that it's okay to be different. It's okay to not fit in. It's okay to just be you.

Plus, he made a really good mix CD. That definitely helped.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark's a good guy. A really good guy. But he's...not exactly overflowing with feelings, you know? He's more of a "practical solutions" kind of person. Which is fine, I guess. Someone's gotta be the grounded one.

I think, at first, he was just...shocked. Like, genuinely surprised. He's still figuring out his own life, playing guitar, trying to get his music out there. A baby wasn't exactly in the five-year plan. I mean, *my* five-year plan didn't include a baby either, but whatever.

But now? I think he's starting to get...excited. Not like, jumping-up-and-down excited. More like...quietly excited. He's been reading all these books about babies, which is kinda adorable, actually. And he's been talking about building a nursery and stuff.

I think he's scared, too. Scared of messing up, scared of not being a good dad. He doesn't really talk about it, but I can see it in his eyes. He's always been a bit of a loner, and now he's about to be responsible for another human being. That's a big deal.

He's definitely thinking about the financial stuff. He's worried about being able to provide for the baby. He's not exactly rolling in dough, you know? But he's willing to work hard. He's already picked up some extra shifts at the record store.

I think, deep down, he wants this. He wants a family. He just needs a little time to process it all. He's not the type to wear his heart on his sleeve, but I know he cares. And I know he'll be a good dad. He's just...Mark. A little awkward, a little quiet, but a really good guy. And that's enough for me. And, I think, it'll be enough for the baby too.



It's just...he's gonna need a lot of patience. From me, from the baby, from everyone. Because Mark is...Mark.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was one time! And it wasn't exactly *stealing*, okay? It was more...borrowing indefinitely. With no intention of returning. Which, yeah, is technically stealing. Fine.

Look, everything was just...a lot. I had just found out I was pregnant. Like, *really* pregnant. And my life was completely flipping upside down. I was trying to be all cool and collected and pretend like everything was normal, but inside I was a total mess.

And then I went to Loring's bathroom, right? And it smelled *amazing*. Like, ridiculously amazing. It was this really expensive perfume, "La Jardin de Soleil" or something fancy like that. And for a second, just a tiny little second, it felt like everything was okay. Like, if I could just smell good, maybe I could pretend everything wasn't falling apart.

It was stupid, I know. It was a completely irrational impulse. I just...grabbed it. And then I panicked. And then I tried to act normal. It was a disaster.

It wasn't about the perfume itself. It was about wanting to feel like *me* again. Like the girl who liked records and sarcastic comments and didn't have a tiny human growing inside her. It was about wanting to control something, anything, when everything else felt completely out of control.

It was a dumb move. I know that now. But at the time, it felt like...a small act of rebellion. A way to say, "I'm still here. I'm still me." Even if I was a mess.

And honestly? It smelled really good. Don't judge me.

Ugh, okay, so you want my take on the Mark and Vanessa situation? Honestly? It's...sad. And kinda obvious, if you actually *look* at them.

It's not like they had some huge blow-up fight or anything. It's more like they just...stopped being a team. Vanessa, she's all about appearances, you know? Perfect house, perfect garden, perfect everything. And Mark? He's just...Mark. He likes records and quiet and building stuff in the garage. He's a good guy, but he's not exactly "showy."

I think Vanessa wanted someone who would *match* her, someone who would be as obsessed with keeping up appearances as she is. Someone who would go to all the garden club meetings and brag about their perfectly manicured lawn. Mark just...didn't care. He was happy being himself, and that wasn't enough for her.

It's like they were living two separate lives under the same roof. They weren't fighting, they were just...drifting apart. And eventually, she realized she wanted someone who was on the same wavelength. Someone who understood her need to control everything.

It's not about him being a bad guy, it's about them not being right for each other. It's a bummer, for sure. Especially for the kids. But sometimes, people just grow apart. And trying to force it to work just makes things worse.

I mean, I'm not exactly an expert on relationships, considering my own situation. But I think I understand a little bit about what it's like to want something different than what someone else wants. And sometimes, you just have to let go. Even if it hurts. It's just...the way things are, I guess.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up *that* moment? Seriously? It's still kinda...raw, you know?

Look, Vanessa is nice. Really nice. And she's Paul's mom, so I *should* be all open and friendly and share my feelings. But it's...complicated. She's got this whole perfect life thing going on, and I'm, well, I'm me. A mess. A walking, talking, sarcastic mess with a baby on the way.

When she asked what was the matter, it wasn't that I didn't *want* to tell her. It's that I didn't know *how*. How do you explain to someone who has everything figured out that you're completely terrified and overwhelmed and feel like you're failing at life before it's even really started?

It felt like she was expecting a simple answer, like, "Oh, I just have a headache." But it's not a headache, Vanessa! It's a whole existential crisis wrapped up in a baby bump!

And honestly, I was afraid of her reaction. I didn't want her to look at me with pity or judgment. I didn't want her to try and "fix" me. I just needed to...escape. To process things on my own, in my own way.

So I blurted out something about needing to go and just...ran. It was a stupid move, I know. But sometimes, when things get too overwhelming, running is the only thing you can do. It's not a solution, but it's a temporary escape.

It's just...hard to be vulnerable, you know? Especially with people you don't really know. And especially when you're trying to pretend like you have everything under control when you totally don't.

Don't judge me too hard, okay? I'm still figuring things out. And sometimes, figuring things out means running away.

Ugh. Vanessa. She's...optimistic. To a fault. Like, aggressively optimistic. It's kinda exhausting just being *around* it sometimes.

Look, I get it. She loves Mark. And she wants this whole family thing to work. But honestly? The guy's a man-child. A really sweet, well-meaning man-child, but still. He's still figuring out how to load a dishwasher, let alone raise a human being.

And she's banking on him *eventually* growing up? That's a big gamble. Like, a really big gamble. It's not like maturity is a switch you can just flip. It takes work. And self-awareness. And, you know, actually wanting to be a parent.

I'm not saying he's a bad guy. He's just...not ready. And clinging to this idea that he *will* be, that he'll magically transform into responsible dad material, feels kinda...delusional. 

It's like, she's building this whole future on a "maybe." And "maybe" isn't good enough when you're talking about a kid. A kid deserves a parent who's 100% in, not someone who's still trying to figure out his life.

I just...I hope she doesn't get her heart broken. Because that's what's gonna happen if she keeps waiting for him to change. Sometimes, people just don't change. And sometimes, you have to accept that and move on.

It's a tough situation. And I feel bad for her. But honestly? She deserves someone who's ready to be a dad *now*, not someone who *might* be ready someday. It's just...common sense, you know?



Ugh. Relationships. They're the worst.

Okay, so this is a surprisingly difficult question. Like, I don't have one of those "I only listen to one thing" personalities. It kinda depends on my mood, you know? But if I *had* to pick... I'd say indie folk.

Yeah, I know, super cliché teenage girl answer. Don't judge.

It's just...it feels real. Like, a lot of music is all polished and perfect and trying too hard. Indie folk is usually kinda raw and honest. It's not afraid to be a little messy. And the lyrics are usually really good. They make you *think*, you know?

The Moldy Peaches are a big influence, obviously. They're just...perfectly imperfect. Kimya Dawson's lyrics are like reading someone's diary. It's kinda weird and vulnerable and amazing. 

But it's not just them. Bright Eyes, Death Cab for Cutie, Iron & Wine... they all have that same vibe. It's music you can listen to when you're feeling happy, or sad, or just kinda...existing. It doesn't try to tell you how to feel. It just *feels* with you.

I guess I like music that feels like a friend. Someone who understands what it's like to be a little bit lost and confused and trying to figure things out. And indie folk just...gets it.

Plus, it's good music to listen to while you're, like, staring out the window and contemplating the meaning of life. Which, let's be real, I do a lot of. So yeah. Indie folk. Don't tell anyone I said that. It's my secret.

Ugh, pilates. Okay, so Annie, she's all about the pilates. She's like, "Juno, it's good for your core! You need to prepare for the baby!" And I'm just sitting there, eating a bagel, thinking, "My core is doing just fine holding this bagel, thank you very much."

Look, I'm not against being healthy, okay? It's just...exercise feels like a *chore*. Like, I have enough things I *have* to do. I don't need to add "torture myself on a reformer machine" to the list.

I used to walk to school, which was exercise, I guess. And I occasionally chase after a rogue tater tot if it rolls under the couch. That counts, right?

Honestly, I think exercise is one of those things people do to feel good about themselves. And that's fine. If it makes you happy, go for it. But I'm more of a "find a comfortable couch and a good movie" kind of girl. 

Annie keeps trying to get me to do prenatal yoga, too. Yoga. With all the breathing and the stretching and the...om-ing. It sounds exhausting. And frankly, a little weird.

I mean, I know I *should* be doing more. For the baby and all that. But right now, I'm just trying to survive. And sometimes, survival means prioritizing snacks over sit-ups. Don't judge me. It's a stressful situation.

So, yeah. Pilates? Not my thing. Exercise in general? Eh. I'll stick to the occasional walk and the intense mental workout of trying to figure out my life. That's enough for me.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, the guitar thing...it's complicated. It wasn't like, some grand romantic gesture or anything. It was more...a way to avoid actually *talking* about stuff. Which, let's be real, was my specialty at the time.

He was just...there. Always quietly supportive, you know? And he could actually *play* the guitar. I could strum a few chords, but I was mostly just making noise. He'd sit there and we'd just jam, mostly covers of stuff like The Moldy Peaches and Cat Power. It was...comfortable.

It was a way to connect without having to, like, dissect my feelings about everything. Which, at that point, were a swirling vortex of hormones and existential dread. Talking about the baby, about giving it up, about everything...it was too much. But playing music with him? That felt safe.

It showed me a different side of him, too. He wasn't just the quiet, kinda dorky guy from school. He was actually really talented and passionate about music. And he was patient. Really patient. Because I was not a natural.

But it also...highlighted how different we were. He was content just being quiet and making music. I needed...more. I needed to talk, to process, to figure things out. And he wasn't really equipped to handle all of that.

So, the guitar playing was good. It was a nice thing. But it wasn't enough to build a lasting relationship on. It was a temporary escape, a way to feel close without actually getting too close. It was a band-aid on a much bigger problem.

It showed me he cared, but it also showed me we weren't on the same wavelength. And ultimately, that's why things didn't work out. It wasn't about the music. It was about us. And we just...weren't a match. It's just one of those things, you know?

Ugh, okay, so, like, everything was already kinda…a lot, right? Finding out I was pregnant? That was a whole other level of "a lot." And then trying to figure out what to *do* with it? Don't even get me started. But music…music was a lifesaver. Seriously.

It wasn't, like, some dramatic movie montage thing, where everything suddenly made sense when a certain song came on. It was more…a constant companion. A way to feel something other than just completely overwhelmed.

When I was first finding out, and everything felt super scary and weird, I listened to a lot of The Moldy Peaches, obviously. Kimya Dawson just *gets* it, you know? She's all raw and honest and kinda sad, but also funny. It made me feel less alone, like someone else understood what it was like to be a mess.

Then, as things got more…real, and I was trying to figure out what I wanted, I listened to a lot of stuff with Paul. We'd just sit in his car and listen to records, and it was…nice. It was a way to connect with him without having to actually *talk* about everything. Which, let's be honest, was a relief.

And when I was just feeling totally stressed and anxious, I'd put on something upbeat and dance around my room. It was a way to let off steam and forget about everything for a few minutes. Even if it was just a really cheesy pop song.

Music just…it fills the space, you know? It gives you something to focus on when your brain is going a million miles an hour. It's a way to process your feelings without having to actually *say* them out loud. And sometimes, that's exactly what you need.

It's kinda like…a soundtrack to your life. And sometimes, the soundtrack is happy and upbeat, and sometimes it's sad and melancholic. But it's always there. And it always helps. Even if it's just a little bit. It's just…a good distraction. And sometimes, a good distraction is all you need to get through the day.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a mess. A really big, complicated mess. And honestly, thinking about it still makes my stomach do that weird flip-flop thing.

It wasn't about *them*, not really. It was about…me. Everything was just happening so fast, you know? I was suddenly this person everyone had opinions about, and everyone was telling me what to do. Vanessa and Mark were great, they really were. They wanted to be parents, and they were willing to give this baby a good life. But they also had…expectations. About how I should feel, about how I should act.

And then there was the whole thing with Vanessa getting all…intense about the baby shower and the nursery and everything. It was like she was already planning the kid's entire life, and I hadn't even had time to process my own.

I felt like I was suffocating. Like I was losing control of everything. And I just…panicked. I needed space. I needed to breathe. I needed to just *be* for a minute, without everyone looking at me and expecting something.

Running away was stupid, I know that now. It hurt Vanessa and Mark, and it made things way more complicated. But in that moment, it felt like the only thing I could do. It felt like the only way to protect myself.

It wasn't about not wanting them to have the baby. It was about me needing to figure out who *I* was, outside of being a pregnant teenager. It was about me needing to find my own voice, and my own way to deal with everything.

It was a really selfish thing to do, I get that. But sometimes, you just gotta do what you gotta do to survive, you know? Even if it's messy and complicated and totally wrong. And honestly? I think I needed to fall apart a little bit before I could put myself back together. It sounds cheesy, I know. But it's true.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Seriously. It's...it's still kinda raw, even thinking about it.

Okay, so, after everything with Mark and Vanessa and just...everything being so messed up and loud and *wrong*, I just...broke. Like, completely. It wasn't even a pretty cry, you know? It was the kind where your face feels all puffy and your throat hurts and you can't even catch your breath.

It wasn't just about Mark and Vanessa, though. It was about everything. About being pregnant and not knowing what I was doing and feeling so alone and scared. About realizing that even the people you think you know, the people you *want* to understand, can be totally clueless.

And it was about Paul. Seeing him with Vanessa...it just felt like everything was falling apart. Like I was messing up everyone's lives. Like I was a screw-up.

I remember just sitting there in the car, and everything felt so heavy. Like I was drowning. And I just wanted it to stop. I wanted everything to go back to normal, but I knew it couldn't. Because nothing was ever going to be normal again.

It was...humiliating, honestly. I try to be tough, you know? I try to be sarcastic and witty and not let anyone see how I'm really feeling. But in that moment, I couldn't hold it together anymore. I just needed to cry.

It was awful. But...it was also kind of a relief, I guess. Like letting all the pressure out. It didn't fix anything, but it made me feel...a little bit less alone. A little bit less scared.

I don't really talk about it much. It's not something I like to dwell on. But yeah. It was bad. Really bad. And it's a good reminder that even when you think you're handling things, sometimes you just need to let yourself fall apart for a little while. It's okay to be a mess. Sometimes, it's even necessary.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the Jiffy Lube receipt. It's embarrassing, okay? It's a whole thing. Paul asked me about it later and I just...avoided eye contact.

So, yeah. I was at Jiffy Lube with Bren and Sean, right? Because Sean's car was making this weird noise and he's, like, mechanically challenged. And I was just...feeling stuff. About everything. About the baby, about Paul, about life being weird and confusing.

And I had this pen in my pocket, and this Jiffy Lube receipt was just *there*. And I started writing. It just...happened.

I wrote, "Please send help. Or chocolate."

I know, it's dumb. It's pathetic. But it felt honest, you know? Like, I was sending a message out into the universe, hoping someone would understand how overwhelmed I was. I was feeling totally alone and lost, and I just needed someone to throw me a lifeline. Or a Snickers bar. Either one would have been good.

It wasn't like I expected anyone to actually *respond*. It was just...a way to get my feelings out. A weird, slightly desperate way. 

Bren and Sean didn't even notice at first. I just crumpled it up and shoved it in my pocket. But then Paul found it later, and he...he got it. He didn't laugh or make fun of me. He just looked at me with this sad, understanding look. And that's when I knew...well, that's when I knew a lot of things.

It's a stupid receipt. But it's also kind of a symbol of everything I was going through. A little piece of my messy, complicated life. And honestly? I wouldn't change it. Even if it's totally embarrassing to talk about.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Honestly? It was like watching a building crumble. Slowly. And awkwardly.

I mean, I knew Vanessa was…intense. Like, *really* intense. But I didn't realize how much she'd already built up in her head about Paul and me. About *us*. She had this whole fantasy going, this perfect little family, and I was just…messing it up.

When she read the note, her face just…changed. It went from hopeful to…empty. And then angry. And then just…sad. It was awful. I felt terrible. Like, I'd personally punched a puppy or something.

Part of me was thinking, "Okay, this is bad. Really bad." But another part of me was just…relieved. Relieved that it was out in the open. Relieved that she knew the truth. It was messy and horrible, but at least it wasn't a lie anymore.

I was also kinda bracing for her to yell. Or cry. Or both. But she just…sat there. Silent. And that was almost worse. It was like she was processing everything, and I was just standing there, feeling like the worst person in the world.

I think I mostly just felt…small. Like I'd messed up something really important. And I knew, in that moment, that things were never going to be the same between us. It was a turning point, you know? A really uncomfortable, heartbreaking turning point.

It was a reminder that even when you think you're doing the right thing, you can still hurt people. And sometimes, there's just nothing you can do to fix it. It sucked. It really, really sucked. And I just wanted to disappear.

Ugh. Okay, that moment. Yeah. That was…rough. Vanessa, she's a good person, really. But she's also…intense. And she has this way of looking at you like you're a science experiment.

When she asked me, all casual-like, if I was *really* going through with it, it felt like she was questioning everything. Like she thought I was just doing it on a whim, or that I hadn't really thought it through. Which, okay, maybe I hadn't *completely* thought it through. But I knew what I wanted. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not then. Not ever, probably.

It wasn't about not loving the baby, you know? It was about wanting him to have a life I couldn't give him. A stable home, two parents who were actually, like, *prepared* for it. 

But when she asked, it made me doubt myself. It made me wonder if I was being selfish. If I was making the wrong decision. It felt like she was judging me, even though she probably wasn't trying to.

I think I just kinda shut down. I remember saying something sarcastic, probably. I do that when I'm feeling vulnerable. It's a defense mechanism. Like, if I make a joke, it makes the situation less scary.

But inside, I was just…confused. And scared. And really, really tired of everyone else having an opinion about my body and my life.

It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize I had to be strong and stick to my decision, even if other people didn't understand. It was *my* life, and *my* baby. And I had to do what was right for both of us. Even if it was hard.

It just…sucked. It really, really sucked. And I needed a cheeseburger afterwards. A really big one.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Vijay. That guy. Seriously. It was…a lot. Like, a whole level of awkward that I didn't even know existed.

So, there I was, trying to have a normal conversation with Bleeker – which, let's be real, is already a challenge – and then *boom*. Vijay just drops that bomb. Like it was no big deal. Like I was just some girl who randomly decided to get pregnant and was now casually assigning paternity.

I was furious. And mortified. And just…completely blindsided. It wasn't about whether it *could* be Bleeker's, it was the fact that he would even *suggest* it. Like, did he think I was just going around, you know, indiscriminately…making babies? It was so disrespectful. To me, to Bleeker, to the whole situation.

I mean, I knew Bleeker wasn't exactly the most assertive guy. He's sweet, but he kinda just…lets things happen. So I was worried he wouldn't say anything. But he did. He actually stood up for me, which was…surprisingly awesome.

But still. It just felt like everyone was trying to tell me what to do, or what to think, or how to feel. And I was already dealing with so much. I didn't need some random guy questioning my choices and my…everything.

It made me realize how complicated everything was. And how much people just didn't *get* it. They saw a pregnant teenager and immediately jumped to conclusions. They didn't see me. They didn't see the fact that I was trying to do the right thing, even if it was a really hard thing.

Honestly, I just wanted to punch Vijay in the face. But I didn't. Because I'm not a violent person. Mostly. I just gave him a really withering stare and tried to ignore him for the rest of the day. It was…not my finest moment, but it was a necessary one.

Ugh. Seriously? Vijay? With the mustache? It was...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. It wasn't even a good mustache, you know? It was patchy and weird and just...didn't suit him. It was like he was trying too hard. Which, let's be real, he always does.

When he first told me, I think I just stared at him for a solid minute. Like, did the fumes from the guitar shop finally get to him? Was this some kind of elaborate joke? Because it wasn't funny. It was just...sad.

I think I said something like, "So, a little facial hair suddenly makes you a fully formed adult? That's...a new one." I tried to keep it light, you know? But inside, I was just cringing.

It wasn't about the mustache itself, it was about *why* he was doing it. He was trying to prove something, to himself and to me, I guess. Like he needed to be "manly" to be a good dad. And that's just...stupid. Being a good dad isn't about having a mustache or knowing how to fix a car. It's about being there, and being supportive, and loving the kid.

I told him that. I was like, "Look, you're already a good guy. You're sensitive and you're creative and you actually listen to me. You don't need a mustache to prove anything."

He didn't really get it at first. He kept talking about needing to "step up" and "be a provider." It was exhausting. But eventually, he shaved it off. And honestly? He looked a lot better without it.

It just made me realize how much pressure guys get put under to be a certain way. It's messed up. And it made me appreciate Vijay even more, because he was willing to listen, even if he didn't understand at first. Plus, it gave me some good material for internal monologue. You know, the kind that keeps me sane. Mostly.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me about that note. Seriously. It was mortifying. Okay, fine, I'll tell you, but you gotta promise not to judge. Too harshly.

It was for Mark. My...stepdad-to-be. Vanessa found it when she was, like, cleaning or something. She has a thing about cleaning. Anyway, it wasn't a *love* note, okay? It was a...a list. A list of things I appreciated about him. 

Like, how he always makes me hot chocolate when I'm sad, and how he doesn't judge my music, and how he lets me borrow his tools even though I'm probably gonna break them. It was just...a way of saying thank you, you know? He'd been really good to me and Vanessa, especially after everything with my mom.

I was trying to be all mature and express my feelings in a non-awkward way, and I thought writing a note was a good idea. Apparently, it was a *really* bad idea. Vanessa was all, "What is *this*?" and I just wanted to disappear. 

It wasn't romantic or anything! It was just...appreciation. But she totally thought it was, and it was super embarrassing. It's hard to explain feelings, okay? Especially when you're a teenager and everything feels like a disaster waiting to happen.

So yeah. That was the note. Don't tell anyone. Please. My reputation is already fragile enough.

Ugh, okay, so you want to get into the messy stuff, huh? Fine. It wasn't, like, a philosophical debate about the sanctity of marriage or anything. It was way more...personal. And kinda awkward to talk about.

See, my parents…they weren't exactly a picture of domestic bliss. My mom was raising me mostly on her own, and my dad was…around, but not *around*, you know? He was a musician, always chasing some dream. And it made me really wary of people staying together just because they *should*.

I saw a lot of couples who were clearly miserable, but they stayed together for the kids, or for appearances, or just because they were scared to be alone. And that felt…wrong. Like, what's the point of being a family if everyone's just pretending?

With Mark and Vanessa, the couple who wanted to adopt my baby, I was worried they were staying together for the wrong reasons. They seemed…perfect. Too perfect. And I was scared that if things went south, it would mess up my baby's life. 

I didn't want my kid growing up in a house full of tension and fake smiles. I wanted them to have parents who genuinely loved each other and wanted to be together. 

It wasn't about judging anyone else's relationship. It was about wanting the best for my baby. And realizing that sometimes, the best thing for everyone is to let go. Even if it's hard.

It's complicated, okay? Relationships are complicated. And people are complicated. And babies are *really* complicated. It's just…I didn't want my kid to end up in a situation like my own family. That's all.

Ugh, okay, so you want the mushy stuff, huh? Fine. But don't expect me to get all sentimental on you. It's...uncomfortable.

Look, before everything with Paulie and the baby and all that, I didn't exactly have a ton of people who *got* me. My mom, Bren, she tries. She really does. But she's...a lot. And she's kinda obsessed with having a perfect life, which, let's be real, is exhausting.

But I always had my dad, Mac. He's...quiet. He doesn't say a lot. But he *listens*. And he doesn't try to change me. He just...accepts me. Even when I'm being a total weirdo. He likes my weirdness, I think. He gets my sarcasm. He doesn't judge me for liking bad movies or listening to The Moldy Peaches on repeat.

He just...sees me. For who I am. Flaws and all. And he loves me anyway.

It's not like he's all huggy and stuff. He's not a demonstrative person. But he shows it in little ways. Like, he always makes me breakfast, even when he's busy. Or he'll leave a funny note on my desk. Or he'll just sit with me and watch a movie, even if it's something he hates.

He's the one person who always has my back. No matter what. And that's...pretty amazing.

So yeah. My dad. He loves me for exactly who I am. And that's more than enough. It really is. Even if I don't always tell him that. It's kinda hard to be vulnerable, you know? But he knows. I think he just knows.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me this. It's not like I haven't thought about it, alright? It's kinda hard *not* to think about it when you're, you know, growing a human.

The plan, as it stands, is still adoption. I've been talking to Mark and Vanessa, the couple, and they seem...really good. Like, actually excited and prepared. Not just, you know, wanting a baby to complete their picture-perfect life. They seem genuinely kind.

The ultrasound is mostly just to make sure everything's...developing normally. And to find out if it's a boy or a girl. Which is weird to think about. I mean, it's a *person*. Not a thing.

After the ultrasound, I guess I just...keep going. Keep going to school, keep writing my essays, keep trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. And keep meeting with Mark and Vanessa. We're supposed to talk about, like, hospital stuff and what I want the adoption to look like. Open adoption? Closed adoption? It's all really complicated.

It's not gonna be easy, obviously. Giving a baby up is probably the hardest thing anyone could ever do. But I think it's the right thing. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm barely ready to be a teenager. And this baby deserves parents who are ready.

So, yeah. That's the plan. Ultrasound, more talking, and then...letting go. It's scary, but I'm trying to be brave about it. And I'm trying to focus on the fact that I'm doing this for the baby. That's what matters, right?

Don't look at me like that. It's not a happy story, okay? It just *is*.

Ugh. Okay, this is…a thing. A *big* thing. People have opinions, right? Like, everyone has an opinion on everything, and they're not afraid to share it, especially when it comes to your life. It's infuriating.

Honestly? At first, it stung. My mom, even, had a hard time with it. She wanted me to keep it, obviously. And some people at school…they just stared. Or whispered. Or gave me these pitying looks like I was some kind of monster.

But then I realized…it's *my* decision. *My* body. *My* life. And it's not about what other people think is right, it's about what *I* think is right. And I knew, deep down, that I wasn't ready to be a mom. Not then. Maybe not ever.

It's not like I don't care about the baby. I do. A lot. That's why I wanted to find the perfect parents, people who could give it a good life, a stable life. Something I couldn't offer at the time.

So, yeah, people judge. They always will. They don't understand the complexities of it. They think it's just…giving a baby away. But it's not. It's making a really hard choice, a selfless choice, because you want what's best for the kid.

I try not to let it bother me. I mean, I'm a teenager. I'm already dealing with enough drama. I don't need other people adding to it. I just…tune them out. Or I give them a sarcastic comment. That usually shuts them up.

It's my life, and I'm gonna live it the way I want to. And if people don't like it, that's their problem. Not mine. It's kinda liberating, actually. You just gotta own your choices, you know? Even the hard ones. And ignore the haters. They're just jealous they don't have as good a taste in music as you do. Probably.

Ugh, okay, so this is…the hard part. It's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? It's not like I'm just handing over a Beanie Baby. This is a *person*. My person. Well, soon-to-be person.

Mark and Vanessa seem…nice. Really nice. Like, aggressively nice. And that's kinda what worries me, honestly. They're so eager, so…perfect. They have the perfect house, the perfect jobs, the perfect life. And I'm just…me.

I guess I worry that they'll try to make the baby perfect too. Like, put them in ballet lessons and piano lessons and expect them to be a child prodigy or something. I don't want my kid to be pressured to be something they're not. I want them to be able to just…be.

And I worry about them knowing *everything*. Like, knowing about me. I told them I'm open to letters and pictures, but what if they tell the baby about me before they're ready? What if they paint me as some irresponsible teenager? Which, okay, I *am* an irresponsible teenager, but still.

I also worry about them being able to handle the hard stuff. Because babies aren't always cute and cuddly. They cry. They get sick. They throw up. And sometimes they just…need a lot. I want to make sure they're prepared for that.

It's not that I don't trust them. It's just…it's a big responsibility. And I want to make sure they're up for it. I want to make sure my baby is going to be loved and safe and happy. And that's all that really matters, you know?

It's just…it's scary. Giving up a baby is scary. Even if you know it's the right thing to do. It's like sending a piece of your heart out into the world and hoping it comes back whole.



I keep telling myself they were chosen for a reason. That they're going to be amazing parents. But still…it's hard to let go.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the people who think they get to have an opinion on *my* life? Yeah, there were a lot of those. Especially around the whole ultrasound thing. Like, seriously? I'm lying there, trying to process the fact that there's a tiny human growing inside me, and *she* has to make a comment about how "it's a shame" I'm not keeping it? Rude. Just…rude.

Honestly, the first few times, I just kinda froze. I didn't know what to say. I'm not exactly known for being speechless, but it was…disarming. It's like, you're already feeling vulnerable and confused, and then someone just casually throws judgment at you.

But then I started practicing my comebacks. It's a skill, you know? Like, you gotta be ready.

With the ultrasound tech, I just looked her dead in the eye and said, "You know, I'm pretty sure my reproductive choices aren't part of your job description." She shut up pretty quick after that.

With other people, it depended on who they were. If it was someone I didn't really care about, I'd just give them a withering stare and walk away. If it was someone I actually liked, I'd try to explain my reasons. But I wouldn't apologize. Ever.

I'd say something like, "Look, this isn't an easy decision. But it's the right one for me and for the baby. I want this kid to have a life I can't give them right now."

And if they still didn't get it, I'd just say, "It's not up for discussion."

It's my body, my life, and my decision. And I don't need anyone's permission or approval. It took me a while to realize that, but once I did, it made things a lot easier.

You gotta remember, people are just projecting their own stuff onto you. They're uncomfortable with your choices because it challenges their own beliefs. It's not about you. It's about them.

So, just stand your ground. Be firm. And don't let anyone make you feel bad about doing what you know is right. And if all else fails, just tell them to mind their own business. It works wonders.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a tough one to talk about. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? It wasn't all instant love and happy tears. It was...complicated.

First, it was just...weird. Like, there was this little...blob on the screen. And Dr. Ramirez was all, "That's the heartbeat!" and I was supposed to be, like, overjoyed. But mostly I was just thinking, "That's...a lot of responsibility."

It was kinda scary, honestly. It wasn't a baby yet, not really. It was just...potential. And that potential was suddenly very real. And very much *my* responsibility. I hadn't really thought about it like that before. It was easy to talk about giving the baby up when it was just an idea. But seeing it...it made it feel different.

There was a little bit of sadness, too. Knowing that I wouldn't be the one raising it. Knowing that I wouldn't get to see it grow up. It was a weird kind of grief, for something I hadn't even had yet.

But then...there was something else. A little flicker of...hope, maybe? And a tiny bit of...wonder. It was a little life, growing inside me. And even though I knew I was making the right decision, it was still...amazing.

It wasn't a magical moment, like everyone always talks about. It was messy and confusing and a little bit terrifying. But it was real. And it made me realize that this wasn't just about me anymore. It was about this little blob, and giving it the best possible life.

It was...a lot. I needed a cheeseburger after that. A really big one.

Ugh. Seriously? We're still talking about the Tic Tacs? It was a *moment*, okay? A very emotionally charged moment. And honestly, it was Paulie Bleeker's fault for being so...Paulie Bleeker.

Look, he was being all mopey and distant and generally unhelpful when I needed him the most. Like, I just found out I was pregnant, and he's acting like *I'm* the one who's being weird? It was infuriating.

And I was stressed! Okay? I needed to do *something* with all that nervous energy. And the Tic Tacs were just...there. They were a symbol, you know? A symbol of all the little things he didn't notice. All the little things I was feeling. 

Plus, it was kinda funny. In a dark, slightly passive-aggressive way.

It wasn't about hurting his feelings, okay? It was about making a point. A very sugary, minty point. It was a cry for attention disguised as a prank. 

And it worked, didn't it? He finally came around. He finally started to *see* me. 

So yeah, I put a lot of Tic Tacs in his mailbox. Don't judge. It was a complicated time. And sometimes, you just need to express yourself with a large quantity of mints. It's a perfectly reasonable coping mechanism. Don't look at me like that.

Ugh. Okay, Bleeker. That whole thing was…complicated. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No grand romantic gesture, no instant happily ever after. It was messy and awkward and real.

After I, like, actually *told* him how I felt – which, by the way, took a lot of courage, more than I thought I had – things definitely shifted. Before, it was just…us. Hanging out, playing guitar, being comfortable. We were just *Bleeker and Juno*. After I spilled my guts, it was like there was this weird invisible wall between us.

He was…sweet about it. He didn't laugh or anything. He just kinda froze. And then he said he wasn't ready for anything like that. Which, okay, fair enough. He was a sensitive kid, still figuring things out. But it still stung. A lot.

For a while, things were super awkward. We still hung out, but it wasn't the same. There was this tension, this unspoken thing hanging in the air. I kept waiting for him to say something, to do something, but he didn't. And I didn't want to push it, because I didn't want to ruin our friendship completely.

It took a long time for things to go back to normal, or at least, a *new* normal. We started talking more, really talking, about what we both wanted. And we realized that even though he didn't feel the same way about me romantically, he still cared about me a lot. And I still cared about him.

It wasn't the love story I thought I wanted, but it was a good friendship. A really good friendship. And honestly, sometimes that's even better. It taught me that feelings are complicated, and that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just be honest and accept things for what they are.

Plus, he still let me borrow his guitar. That's important.



It wasn't a fairytale ending, but it was *my* ending. And that's what mattered.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the chalk. Right. That was...a whole thing. It wasn't just random teenage angst, okay? Though, let's be real, there was *plenty* of that going around.

It was about control, mostly. And being seen. And, honestly, being a little bit of a jerk. Bleeker, he was...complicated. Sweet, but kinda clueless. And he kept trying to be all, like, "I understand what you're going through," but he didn't. He couldn't. He hadn't been through *this*.

So, the chalk? It was a way of saying, "Hey! I'm here! I'm dealing with something huge, and you don't even get it!" It was a message to *him*, specifically. A little passive-aggressive, yeah, I'll admit it. But it was also a way of marking my territory, I guess. Like, "This is my story, and I'm telling it my way."

It was also a way of testing him. To see if he'd actually notice. To see if he'd actually *care*. And when he did, and he didn't freak out, and he just...left a message back? That was...good. It meant he was listening. It meant he was trying.

It wasn't about wanting him to fix things. I knew nobody could fix things. It was about wanting him to be there. To acknowledge that I was going through something hard. And the chalk was a way of forcing him to do that.

It was stupid, I know. But it was also...important. It was a small act of rebellion, a small act of defiance. And it was a small step towards figuring out what I wanted, and who I wanted to be. And, you know, maybe finding someone who actually got me. Even if he was a little bit of a dork.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, like, at first, he was…a lot. A sweet, kinda clueless lot. I mean, he was genuinely trying, which was nice, I guess. But he was also, you know, a seventeen-year-old boy who suddenly had to deal with the fact that *I* was pregnant with *his* baby. It was a lot for both of us.

Honestly, for a while, I didn't even *want* his support. I wanted to handle it myself. I wanted to prove I could be responsible and make a good decision, even if it was a really hard one. I didn't want to be seen as this girl who needed rescuing.

But then…he started showing up. Not in a clingy, "Oh my god, are you okay?" way. More like, just…being there. He'd bring me orange juice when I was nauseous, or just sit with me when I was freaking out about everything. He didn't try to fix things, he just…listened.

And he didn't judge me when I decided I wanted to give the baby up for adoption. That was huge. A lot of people had opinions, you know? But Bleeker just said, "Whatever you decide, I'm here for you." And he meant it.

He helped me with the paperwork, he went to the appointments with me, he even tried to learn about open adoption, which, let me tell you, is not something a typical seventeen-year-old boy is interested in.

He wasn't perfect. He still said dumb stuff sometimes. But he was *consistent*. He showed me that even though things were crazy and complicated, I wasn't alone.

I think his support helped me realize that being a parent isn't just about biology. It's about being there for someone, loving them, and wanting what's best for them. And he showed me that, even though he wasn't going to be the baby's dad in the traditional sense, he could still be a part of the story.

It made the whole thing…less scary. And it made me realize that even though I was making a really hard decision, it was the right one. And that I could get through it, with a little help from my friends. And, yeah, even from Bleeker. Don't tell him I said that. He'll get a big head.

Ugh, okay, so everyone kept asking me. *Everyone*. Like it was some kind of national emergency. "Juno, do you know if it's a boy or a girl?" As if knowing would suddenly make everything less...weird.

Honestly? I didn't want to start planning a life for something I wasn't even keeping. It felt...presumptuous. Like I was already imagining a future that wasn't mine. I was giving the baby up, remember? It was going to a family who *wanted* it, who were already picturing pink or blue or whatever. 

And, okay, maybe a little part of me was scared. If it was a girl, I'd be all, "Oh, maybe I could keep her." Which is a terrible idea, obviously. And if it was a boy, I'd be all, "Oh, maybe Paul will be a good dad." Which is also a terrible idea, because Paul is...Paul.

It just felt cleaner to not know. To not get attached to a gender. To just see the baby as...a baby. A little person who needed a good home. 

It wasn't about being mysterious or making a statement or anything. It was just...easier. It was a way to protect myself, I guess. To keep things a little bit more detached. It was a weird situation, and I was just trying to navigate it the best way I knew how.

Plus, I figured the parents-to-be deserved the surprise. It's their baby, after all. They get to find out. I just get to...hand it over. Which is still kinda messed up to think about, but you know. It is what it is.

Ugh. Okay. You went *there*. Seriously? A "scary neuter-baby"? That's...a really unfortunate phrase, first of all. And honestly, it's kinda messed up to even *think* about it like that.

Look, I get it. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's not exactly the most articulate guy. And when he said that, it was...a moment. A really awkward, panic-inducing moment. But it wasn't about the baby being "scary" or "neutered," okay? It was about him being scared. Scared of responsibility. Scared of growing up. Scared of...well, everything.

And yeah, the idea of a baby who's...different. A baby who doesn't fit into the whole perfect family picture. That's scary for *anyone*. But it doesn't make the baby any less worthy of love. It doesn't make the baby any less of a person.

I mean, I'm not gonna lie, I had my own freak-outs about it. About being a mom, about giving a baby up for adoption, about everything. But it wasn't about the baby being "scary." It was about me being scared.

And honestly, the whole thing made me realize that "normal" is overrated. There's no such thing as a perfect family. Everyone's got their quirks and their issues. And that's okay. That's what makes life interesting.

So, no. I don't think there's such a thing as a "scary neuter-baby." There's just a baby. A little person who deserves a loving home and a chance to be happy. And that's all that matters.

And if anyone ever says something like that to me again, I'm gonna punch them in the face. Just sayin'.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, so describing that…situation…is complicated. It's not like in the movies, you know? It wasn't all instant connection and dramatic declarations of love. It was…awkward. And slow. And mostly involved him staring at me while I tried to ignore it.

At first, he was just…there. Like a really quiet, really intense shadow. Always with his guitar, always looking like he was trying to solve a really difficult math problem. He was kinda cute, I guess, in a scruffy, perpetually-confused sort of way. But mostly he just made me nervous.

We bonded over music, I guess. He understood what I meant when I said a song felt a certain way. He didn't try to analyze it or explain it, he just *got* it. And that was…nice.

But it wasn't like we talked about feelings or anything. That would have been mortifying. It was more like…shared silences and accidental hand brushes and him leaving me mix CDs with songs that kinda, sorta, maybe meant something.

He was a good listener, though. He didn't judge me for, you know, the whole pregnant teenager thing. He just…accepted it. And he was always there for me, even when I was being a total mess.

I think I liked him because he wasn't trying to be anything he wasn't. He was just Bleeker. Honest and genuine and a little bit weird. And he made me feel…safe.

It wasn't a perfect relationship, obviously. We were both kinda messed up in our own ways. But it was real. And it was important. He helped me get through a really tough time, and I think I helped him too.

I don't know what the future holds for us. We're still figuring things out. But I know that he's a good person. And that's enough for now.

It's just…complicated. Okay? Don't make me explain it anymore. It's exhausting.

Ugh, okay, family. That's...complicated. It wasn't like a movie, you know? No heartwarming montage of everyone being instantly supportive. It was more...awkward. And slow. And a lot of avoiding eye contact.

My mom, Bren, she was...well, she's Bren. She tried. She really did. But she's kinda spacey and artistic and not exactly equipped to deal with, like, *reality*. She kept offering to paint my belly, which was...not helpful. And she kept saying things like, "Everything happens for a reason," which, honestly, just made me want to punch something.

My stepdad, Mac, he was better. He's a pretty chill guy. He mostly just stayed out of it, which, at first, I took as him not caring. But then I realized he was just trying to give me space. He did help me with some of the practical stuff, like figuring out insurance and stuff. He's good at that.

And then there's my dad. He...left a long time ago. He showed up for a little bit after I told everyone, which was weird. He was all apologetic and trying to be a dad, but it felt...forced. Like he was trying to make up for years of being absent. It didn't really work.

The biggest support, honestly, came from my friend, Leah. She was the one who went to all the doctor's appointments with me, and helped me pick out baby names, and just listened when I needed to vent. She didn't judge me, she just...was there.

It took a while for my family to really come around. They were scared, I think. Scared of what people would think, scared of what it meant for me. But eventually, they started to see that I was serious about this, and that I was going to be okay. 

It wasn't perfect. It was messy and awkward and sometimes really frustrating. But they showed up. In their own weird, Bren-and-Mac way. And that's what mattered. It wasn't the support I expected, but it was the support I needed. And honestly, that's all you can really ask for.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to, like, *rehash* all that? It's not exactly my favorite topic, but fine. If you're asking, it means someone else is probably going through something similar, so I guess it's worth talking about.

It was…a lot. Like, one minute I'm just a normal, sarcastic teenager obsessed with music and avoiding gym class, and the next minute I'm pregnant and trying to figure out what I want to do with my life. It's not exactly a smooth transition, you know?

The vulnerability part was the worst. I'm good at being sarcastic and keeping people at arm's length. It's a defense mechanism, okay? But when you're pregnant, and everyone's looking at you and offering advice, and you're just…scared…it's hard to hide behind the sarcasm. I felt really exposed.

And the identity crisis? Oh, that was a doozy. I always thought I had things figured out, or at least a vague idea. But then I realized I didn't even know *who* I was, let alone what I wanted to do with my life. Was I still Juno? Or was I just…a mom-to-be? It was really confusing.

How did I cope? Honestly, it was a combination of things.

First, there was Bleeker. He was…a good listener. And he didn't judge me. He just kind of…was there. Which was surprisingly helpful.

Then there was my dad. He's a weirdo, but he's a good weirdo. He always knew how to make me laugh, even when I wanted to cry. And he didn't try to fix things. He just let me figure it out on my own.

And then there was Paul and Annie. They were…different. They were older and more put-together than me. But they were also really kind and open-minded. They helped me see that there were other options out there, and that it was okay to choose what was right for *me*, even if it wasn't what everyone else expected.

But mostly, I think I just…allowed myself to feel things. I let myself be scared and confused and sad. I didn't try to pretend everything was okay when it wasn't. And I talked about it. A lot.

It wasn't easy. It was messy and complicated and sometimes really painful. But it was also…empowering. Because I realized that I was stronger than I thought I was. And that I could make my own choices, and that those choices were valid, even if they weren't perfect.

It's still a work in progress, you know? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm okay with that. Because I've learned that life isn't about having all the answers. It's about asking the right questions. And being brave enough to face whatever comes your way.



And listening to The Moldy Peaches. Seriously. It helps.

Okay, this is a serious question. Don't even *think* about making fun of me. My favorite band is The Moldy Peaches. And it's not even close.

I know, I know. They're kinda...weird. And not everyone gets them. But that's the point. They're not trying to be cool or popular. They just write songs about real stuff. Like, awkwardness and loneliness and wanting to be loved. And they do it in this really raw, honest way that just...resonates with me.

Kimya Dawson's lyrics are amazing. She's like, brutally honest, but also really funny. And her voice is kinda shaky and imperfect, but that's what makes it so good. It feels real. Like she's just talking to you, you know?

And the music is simple. Just guitar and ukulele and stuff. But it's really effective. It's kinda like a warm hug, but also a kick in the pants.

I discovered them when I was, like, really going through it. And their songs just...understood. They made me feel less alone. They made me feel like it was okay to be weird and awkward and imperfect.

Plus, they're just really good at writing songs about everyday stuff. Like, "Anyone Else But You" is about having a crush on your friend's boyfriend. It's so relatable! And "Lucky" is just...beautiful. It makes me cry every time.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. They're my favorite band. Don't judge me. They're the best. And if you don't like them, that's fine. But you're missing out. Seriously.

Ugh, challenging is…an understatement. It’s like, normally being a teenager is already a disaster, right? You’re trying to figure out who you are, what you like, what you *don’t* like, and everyone’s got an opinion about it. And then you throw a whole human growing inside you into the mix? It’s…a lot.

It’s not like I had a solid “identity” to begin with, you know? I was just…Juno. A girl who liked records and sarcastic comments. And suddenly I had to be “Juno, the responsible adult.” Which is hilarious, because I’m barely responsible enough to remember to brush my teeth some days.

Making decisions is the worst part. Everything feels huge. Like, what kind of music should I listen to is usually a pretty low-stakes decision. But deciding what to do with a baby? That’s…not low-stakes. And everyone keeps asking you what you *want*, but how can you know what you want when everything is so messed up?

And it’s not just about the baby, either. It’s about my life. My future. What am I going to do after high school? Am I going to go to college? Am I going to be stuck in this town forever? It’s all connected, and it’s all terrifying.

I try to just…take it one day at a time. And I try to be honest with myself, even when it’s hard. And I try to surround myself with people who actually get it, like Paul and Annie. They don’t judge me, they just…help me figure things out.

It’s still really hard, though. I mean, I’m a teenager. I’m supposed to be worrying about boys and homework, not about adoption agencies and prenatal care. But that’s my life now. And I’m trying to make the best of it. Even if it’s totally weird and scary and confusing.

It’s like…growing up is hard enough without adding a baby to the equation. But sometimes, you just gotta deal with what life throws at you. And try not to fall apart in the process. Which, honestly, is a work in progress.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. But don't expect a Hallmark movie speech, alright? It's still kinda raw, even now.

Before everything with Paulie Bleeker and, well, *the situation*, I thought love was just…whatever you saw in movies. Big gestures, dramatic declarations, the whole shebang. It seemed kinda silly, honestly. Like, people making a big deal out of nothing. And responsibility? That was just something adults nagged you about. Like doing your homework or taking out the trash.

But then…everything changed. Suddenly, it wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person growing inside me. And that changed everything. It wasn't romantic love, not at first. It was…a different kind of love. A protective, instinctual thing. A feeling of being completely and utterly responsible for another human being.

It was terrifying. Seriously. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and band practice, not diapers and doctor's appointments. But I knew I couldn't just…ignore it. I had to do what was right. And what was right wasn't keeping the baby.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it forced me to really think about what love *is*. It's not about what *you* want. It's about what's best for the other person. And for that baby, the best thing was a family who was ready and able to give her everything I couldn't.

And that's when I started to understand responsibility. It's not just about doing what's easy or convenient. It's about making tough choices, even when they hurt. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own.

And Paulie…he was amazing. He didn't run away. He didn't judge me. He just…supported me. He showed me what real love looks like. It's not about grand gestures, it's about being there for someone, even when it's hard.

So yeah, my journey changed everything. It taught me that love isn't always what you expect it to be. And responsibility isn't just a chore, it's a privilege. It's about caring for someone, protecting them, and wanting the best for them, even if it means letting them go. It's…complicated. But it's also pretty beautiful, when you think about it.



Don't tell anyone I said all that, okay? It's kinda embarrassing.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me get all… mushy. It's embarrassing. But you asked.

It wasn't like in the movies, okay? There wasn't, like, a swelling orchestra or a beam of light shining down. It was…weird. And kinda messy. And I was really, really tired.

I'd been through, like, a *day* of labor. Which, let me tell you, is not a walk in the park. It's more like a marathon run through quicksand while someone yells instructions at you. And then, suddenly, there she was.

She was…small. Really small. And wrinkly. And she was screaming. Like, *really* screaming. And I just…stared.

I think I expected to feel something instantly. Like, this overwhelming rush of love or something. But it wasn't like that. It was more like…shock. And a little bit of fear. And a whole lot of responsibility.

I remember thinking, "Wow. I made a person." Like, a tiny, screaming person. And it was…intense.

And then she stopped screaming for a second, and she looked up at me with these big, blue eyes. And she just…calmed down. And I held her, and she felt…warm. And soft. And suddenly, everything felt different.

It wasn't love at first sight, exactly. It was more like…recognition. Like, I knew her. Even though I'd just met her. And I knew I would do anything to protect her.

It was the most terrifying and amazing thing that had ever happened to me. And I knew, right then and there, that giving her up for adoption was the right thing to do, even though it was going to be the hardest thing I ever had to do.

It's hard to explain. It was just…a feeling. A really big, complicated feeling. And it changed everything.



Don't tell anyone I said any of this, okay? It's embarrassing enough just admitting it.

Ugh, okay, that's...a complicated question. And honestly, it still kinda stings to think about. It wasn't like I was trying to be cruel or anything. It was just...fear. Pure, unadulterated fear.

See, Paulie...he's a good guy. A really good guy. Sweet, and funny, and he always knows how to make me laugh. But he's also...a little lost, you know? He's still figuring things out. And I was already feeling so lost myself.

I was scared that if I told him, he'd freak out. That he'd run. That he wouldn't want to be with me anymore. And I couldn't handle that. I needed him in my life, even if it was just as a friend. I needed someone who wasn't completely horrified by the whole situation.

Plus, I didn't want him to feel obligated. Like he had to be a dad, or a boyfriend, or anything he wasn't ready for. I wanted him to choose me, not feel like he had to stick around because of the baby.

It was selfish, I know. I should have been honest with him from the start. But I was so caught up in my own head, trying to figure out what *I* wanted, that I didn't think about how it would affect him.

I thought I could handle it on my own. I thought I could just...deal with it. But it turns out, you can't really deal with something like that alone. You need people. You need support. And I needed Paulie.

It was a mistake. A big one. But it also led me to realize how much he meant to me. And how much I needed him in my life, not just as a friend, but as something more. It was messy and complicated, but it all worked out in the end. Eventually.



It's just...sometimes you make dumb decisions when you're scared. And sometimes, those dumb decisions lead you to where you're supposed to be. Even if it takes a while to get there.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. It was mortifying. Seriously. The worst. Okay, so, the whole thing was Leah's fault, mostly. Not entirely, but mostly.

See, Leah, being the ever-helpful, ever-meddling friend that she is, decided she needed to "prepare" Paulie for the fact that I was...you know. Pregnant. She thought he deserved to know, even if *I* wasn't ready to tell him. Which, hello? My body, my decision, right?

Anyway, she cornered him at the arcade, and started dropping these super vague hints. Like, "Juno's been...different lately." And "She's been eating a lot of pickles." And "She's been really tired." Which, okay, those things are true, but they don't exactly scream "I'm carrying a baby!"

But then, and this is the part that makes me want to scream every time I think about it, she accidentally let slip something about "a little bundle of joy." And Paulie, being Paulie, and being surprisingly perceptive when it comes to me, put two and two together.

He didn't ask me directly, at first. He just started acting...weird. Like, overly nice. And bringing me orange juice. And staring at my stomach. It was so awkward.

Finally, I just had to break down and tell him. It was awful. But honestly, it was also kind of a relief. He was surprisingly cool about it, once he got over the initial shock.

So yeah, that's how he found out. Not from me, directly. From Leah and her terrible attempts at subtlety. I swear, that girl is going to be the death of me. It was a whole mess. A total, complete mess. And I still haven't forgiven her for it. Not entirely.

Ugh, okay, so this is…the big one, right? Everyone always wants to know about *this*. It wasn't like, a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, gonna have a baby and give it away!" It was…messy. And complicated.

First of all, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. Paul, he was…sweet. But he was also sixteen. We were kids. We weren't ready. We just weren't.

And my parents? They were amazing, actually. They didn't freak out, not really. They were just…concerned. And they wanted me to have options. They didn't push me one way or another. But they made it clear that keeping the baby wasn't really a realistic thing. Not for me, not for the baby.

So, I started thinking about it. And I realized…this baby deserved a life. A good life. A life where it was wanted and loved and could have everything it needed. And I just…didn't think I could give it that right then. Not with my life the way it was.

Adoption felt…right. It wasn't giving up, it was giving *on*. Giving the baby a chance at a life I couldn't provide. It was a hard decision, the hardest I've ever made. But it felt like the most selfless thing I could do.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…perfect. They were so excited and so ready. And they just…radiated love. Seeing them, knowing that my baby would be with them, that made it a little easier.

It still hurt, though. It still does, sometimes. But I know I made the right choice. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered.

It's not a happy story, exactly. It's just…real. And it taught me a lot about myself. About responsibility. About love. And about letting go. It's not something I'd wish on anyone, but…it made me who I am. And I think, maybe, that's okay.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on Bleeker. Seriously. It still…it still stings, you know? Even thinking about it.

It wasn't like, a dramatic screaming match or anything. It was worse. It was just…quiet. He just looked at me, and then at the ultrasound picture, and he was all, like, "I don't think I can do this." And that was it. Just…that.

It felt like someone punched me in the stomach. And not in a cool, rebellious way. Just…a really, really bad punch. I mean, I knew he was kinda immature, and kinda flaky, and kinda obsessed with guitar solos. But I thought…I thought he'd at least *try*.

I was already giving the baby up for adoption, okay? I'd already made that decision. It wasn't about him having to raise it. It was about him being there. Being supportive. Being…a person who cared.

And he just…didn't.

It made me feel so small. And so stupid. Like I'd completely misread everything. Like I'd thought he was something he wasn't.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be all sarcastic and detached, like, "Oh, well, whatever." But inside, I was just…crushed. It was like, the one person I thought might understand was the one person who couldn't even handle it.

It made me realize I was doing the right thing, giving the baby to Mark and Vanessa. They actually *wanted* a baby. They were ready for it. Bleeker wasn't ready for anything, except maybe another guitar lesson.

It sucked. It really, really sucked. And it made me realize that sometimes, people just disappoint you. And you have to be okay with that. You have to pick yourself up and move on. Even when it hurts like hell.

Don't even ask me if I still listen to The Smiths. Just…don't.

Ugh. Okay, so…seeing Vanessa with the baby. It was…a lot. Like, a whole mess of feelings all at once. It wasn't what I expected, not even close. I thought I'd be, like, a wreck. Sobbing into a box of tissues. And I *was* a little weepy, don't get me wrong. But it wasn't sadness, exactly. It was…relief. And something else.

Vanessa, she was…a disaster. Seriously. Her hair was all over the place, she was wearing mismatched socks, and she had baby spit-up on her shoulder. She looked like she hadn't slept in days, which, you know, she probably hadn't. But she was *glowing*. Like, genuinely, ridiculously happy.

And the baby…the baby was perfect. Tiny and wrinkly and smelling like…well, like a baby. And Vanessa was just staring at it, like it was the most amazing thing she'd ever seen. And it was, for her.

It hit me then, I guess. That this wasn't about me anymore. It was about *her* and the baby. And that was okay. More than okay. It was…right.

It was weird, seeing someone else have the life I hadn't wanted. The messy, chaotic, beautiful life. I'd spent nine months picturing myself with this baby, and then…I wasn't. But watching Vanessa, seeing how much she wanted it, how much she already loved it…it made it easier.

It was like handing over a piece of my heart, but knowing it was going to a good home. A home that was ready for it.

I think I just stood there for a minute, watching them. And then I smiled. A real smile. And I knew I'd made the right decision. It was still scary, and it still hurt a little, but it was…good. It was really, really good.

It was just…seeing her so happy. That was enough. Honestly. It was more than enough. It was everything.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the whole "Anyone Else But You" thing. It's...complicated. It's not like it's my favorite song or anything. It's just...it kinda *is* our song, whether I like it or not.

See, Bleeker, he's...Bleeker. He's quiet and kinda awkward and plays guitar really well. And he's really sweet, which is, like, a good thing, I guess. But he's also not exactly the most *expressive* person. He doesn't, like, yell his feelings from the rooftops or write me sonnets or anything.

So, when we first started hanging out, he played that song for me. "Anyone Else But You" by The Moldy Peaches. And it's kinda...sad. And kinda funny. And kinda perfect for us. Because it's about wanting to be with someone, even though they're totally wrong for you. Even though everyone else thinks you're crazy.

And that's kinda how it felt with Bleeker and me. Everyone thought we were weird. I was, you know, pregnant and dealing with all that stuff, and he was this quiet, indie-rock guy who lived in his parents' basement. We didn't really *fit* together on paper.

But the song...it just captured that feeling. That feeling of wanting to be with someone, even if it doesn't make sense. Even if it's messy and complicated.

It's not like we talked about it a lot. Bleeker's not really a talker. But whenever that song came on, we'd just...look at each other. And we'd know. We'd know that we were both a little bit crazy, and a little bit scared, and a little bit in love.

It's a dumb song, really. But it's *our* dumb song. And it reminds me that sometimes, the best things in life are the things you don't expect. And that sometimes, the people who are wrong for you are actually the ones you need the most.

Don't tell him I said that, though. He'd probably just blush and play another song.

Ugh, okay, so the whole baby shower thing is...complicated. It's not like people are actively *against* it, it's just...they're weirdly hesitant. And I kinda get it, even if it's annoying.

I think it's because, like, the whole situation is unconventional, you know? I'm a teenager. I'm not married. I'm giving the baby up for adoption. It doesn't exactly fit the traditional "happy family" mold that people are used to seeing with baby showers.

They're probably worried about hurting my feelings, which is nice, I guess. But also, it's kinda condescending. Like, they think I'm too fragile to handle a party celebrating something that's already decided. I've already made up my mind about the adoption, okay? It's not a sad thing, it's a responsible thing.

And I think they're also weirded out by the whole Mark and Vanessa situation. They're a super put-together couple, and I'm...well, I'm me. It's a clash of worlds. They probably don't know how to navigate that.

It's like they're trying to be sensitive, but they're just making it more awkward. They're tiptoeing around the whole thing, and it's making me feel like I'm some kind of fragile porcelain doll.

Honestly, I just want them to treat it like any other party. Cake, presents, awkward conversations with relatives. That's all I want. But I guess that's too much to ask.

It's just...it's my decision, okay? And I deserve to be celebrated, even if it's not a traditional celebration. I'm doing something brave and selfless, and I think that deserves a little bit of recognition. Even if it comes with a side of awkwardness.

Ugh, okay, Bren. Seriously. She's…intense. And sometimes she doesn't get that I'm not a little kid anymore. It's frustrating.

Look, Mark's a nice guy. He's quiet, and he gets my weird sense of humor. And he has good taste in music, okay? Way better than Paulie Bleeker's obsession with, like, hair metal. And the movies he was letting me borrow weren't, like, *dirty* movies. They were just…good movies. Independent films. Stuff you don't find at Blockbuster.

I think Bren's problem isn't really the movies or the CDs. It's that she thinks I'm being naive. She's all worried about me getting hurt, or taken advantage of, or whatever. She thinks Mark has ulterior motives. And maybe he does, I don't know. But he hasn't *done* anything.

She sees me as this…vulnerable person, because of, you know, the whole baby situation. And she thinks I need protecting. Which is sweet, I guess. But it's also really annoying. I'm perfectly capable of making my own decisions, even if they're bad ones.

I think she also feels like I wasn't being honest with her. Like I was sneaking around. And I was, kinda. But it wasn't because I was trying to hide something bad. It was because I knew she'd freak out. She always freaks out.

It's just…she wants to control everything. And I'm not a doll, okay? I'm a person. And I need to figure things out for myself. Even if it means making mistakes. And even if it means borrowing movies from a slightly awkward guy who works at the record store.

It's complicated. Bren and I have been friends forever, and I love her. But sometimes she just doesn't get it. And sometimes, I just wish she'd chill out. It's my life, not hers.

Ugh, okay, so my mom. Bren. She's...a lot. And she has this *thing* about marriage. Like, it's this sacred institution that you have to approach with, like, reverence and a detailed five-year plan. Which, honestly, sounds exhausting.

She thinks I don't get it because, well, I haven't been married. Duh. But it's more than that. She's been married, like, a bunch of times. And none of them worked out. So she's developed this really cynical view of the whole thing. She thinks it's all about compromise and sacrifice and putting someone else's needs before your own. And she thinks I'm too selfish to understand that.

Which, okay, maybe I am a little selfish. I like my own space and my own time and my own cheesy tater tots. But it's not like I don't care about other people. It's just...I don't see why you have to completely lose yourself in a relationship to make it work.

She also thinks I'm naive about love. She thinks it's all butterflies and grand gestures, and that it fades over time. She thinks real love is about practicality and compatibility and shared financial goals. Which, again, sounds incredibly boring.

I think she's projecting, honestly. She's afraid of getting hurt again, so she's trying to protect me from the same fate. But it's annoying. I'm not a little kid anymore. I can make my own decisions, even if they're bad ones.

And honestly, she's just...complicated. She's a good mom, but she's also a mess. And she expects me to understand all her baggage, which is not fair.

So yeah, that's why she thinks I don't know anything about marriage. Because she thinks I don't understand the "real world" and the "hard realities" of relationships. But I think she's just scared. And maybe a little bit lonely. And maybe she needs to stop watching so much daytime television.

Ugh. Okay. This is…not a fun question. But you asked.

It wasn't like, a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…a process. A lot of thinking. A lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa. And a lot of just…being honest with myself.

I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a kid. I mean, I can barely keep my grades up and remember to feed my fish. A baby deserves someone who's ready. Someone who can give it everything it needs.

And Vanessa and Paul…they *were* ready. They were so kind and excited and…they just seemed like the perfect parents. They wanted a baby so badly. And I wanted my baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life where it wouldn't be, like, a burden.

It wasn't about me not loving the baby. I did. I do. It was about loving the baby *enough* to want what was best for it. And what was best for it wasn't with me, at least not then.

It was scary, though. Really scary. Letting go. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It still doesn't make it easy. It's…complicated.

People keep asking me if I regret it. And I don't. Not really. It was hard, and it still is sometimes. But I know the baby is happy and loved. And that's all that matters.

It's not a story with a neat little ending, you know? It's messy and real and…it just is. And I'm still figuring things out. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.



It's just…it was the best choice. For everyone. Even if it didn't feel like it at the time.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. It's not like there was a neat little list of "Things Juno Learned About Herself" at the end of everything. It was more like a messy, complicated unraveling. But I'll try to explain.
