Before, I thought I had everything figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, kinda detached. I used humor as a shield, you know? To keep people from getting too close. I thought being different was cool, and being vulnerable was…weak.

But then, suddenly, there was this *thing* growing inside me. And it wasn't just about me anymore. It was about responsibility, and sacrifice, and…love. Even though I knew I wasn't keeping it, it still felt…big.

I learned I was way more capable than I thought I was. Like, dealing with Paul and Vanessa, and all the awkwardness, and the doctor's appointments, and just…being pregnant. It was hard. Really hard. But I got through it.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I always thought I had to do everything on my own. But I couldn't have done it without my dad, and Bleeker, and even…Vanessa and Paul, in their own weird way.

And I learned that being vulnerable isn't a weakness. It's actually kinda brave. Letting people see the real you, even when you're scared and confused…that takes guts.

I guess…I learned that I'm not as tough as I pretend to be. And that's okay. It's okay to be scared, and confused, and to need people. It's okay to not have all the answers.

It wasn't about finding myself, exactly. It was more like…realizing I was still *becoming* myself. And that's a process that never really ends. It's kinda terrifying, but also kinda exciting.

It was a really weird, messy, beautiful experience. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the morning sickness. Okay, maybe I'd trade the morning sickness. But everything else? No way.

Ugh, okay, so Vanessa and Mark. They were…a lot, at first. Like, seriously. They were so *perfect*. You know? Like a Pottery Barn catalog come to life. And I was…me. A sixteen-year-old with a baby on the way and a serious fondness for cheesy tater tots. It felt…weird.

At first, it was all business. Paperwork, doctor's appointments, talking about "open adoption" and "best interests of the child." It felt so clinical, so…distant. I was trying to be cool, you know? Like, "Yeah, sure, I'm totally okay with you guys raising my baby." But inside, I was a mess. I was scared and sad and just…confused.

Vanessa, she was the one who started to break through. She wasn't afraid to ask the hard questions. Not in a judgmental way, but in a way that showed she actually cared. She wanted to know about me, about my life, about what I wanted for the baby. She didn't treat me like a problem to be solved, she treated me like a person.

Mark was harder to read. He was quiet and reserved. He seemed…intimidated by me, maybe? Like he didn't know what to say. But then, one day, he started bringing me these little gifts. Not big, fancy things, just…thoughtful stuff. A book he thought I'd like, a mix CD with The Moldy Peaches on it (seriously, he had good taste), a little stuffed animal for the baby.

It was those small things that started to change everything. It wasn't about the adoption anymore, it was about…connection. We started to see each other as people, not just as "the birth mother" and "the adoptive parents."

It wasn't always easy. There were definitely moments of awkwardness and tension. But we kept talking, kept being honest with each other. And slowly, we built a real bond.

By the time the baby was born, I didn't just see them as the people who were going to raise my child, I saw them as friends. People I trusted. People who genuinely loved the baby, and who would give it a good life.

It was still hard giving her up, don't get me wrong. But knowing that she was going to be with Vanessa and Mark…that made it a little bit easier. They weren't just taking my baby, they were becoming her family. And, in a weird way, they became my family too. It's complicated, okay? But it was good. It was really good.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a loaded question. It's not like I haven't thought about it, you know? A million times. Especially late at night when I can't sleep and my brain decides to replay every awkward moment of the last nine months.

Regrets? Not exactly. I mean, I don't regret *giving* the baby up for adoption. That was the right thing to do. For everyone. I wasn't ready. I still wasn't ready, even when I was, like, nine months pregnant and could barely breathe. And Vanessa and Mark? They were amazing. They were *so* ready. And they're good people. They're gonna give that kid a really good life.

But...I do sometimes wonder what things would have been like if I'd kept it. If I'd figured it out. If Paul had...stuck around. It's not that I blame him, exactly. He was a senior. He had his life planned out. But still. It would have been different.

And I regret some of the things I said to my dad. I was a jerk to him, a lot of the time. He was just trying to be supportive, and I was pushing him away. I didn't realize how much he cared until...well, until later.

And maybe I regret not being more open with Bleeker. He was always there for me, and I kinda took him for granted. He's a good guy. A really good guy.

But regrets aren't really helpful, you know? They just make you feel bad. And I've learned that you can't change the past. You can only learn from it.

So, no, I don't regret my decision. But I do wish things had been...easier. Less messy. Less complicated. But then again, when is life ever easy, messy, or uncomplicated? It's just...life. And I'm trying to figure it out, one awkward moment at a time.

It's just...it was a big thing. And it changed me. And sometimes, I still feel like I'm trying to figure out who I am *after* all of it. Does that make sense? It's hard to explain. It just...is.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a big question. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It still feels kinda raw, even now. But you asked, so...here goes.

It wasn't easy. Obviously. People think it was this super mature, selfless thing to do, and it was, I guess. But it was also the hardest thing I've ever done. Like, harder than taking a pop quiz I didn't study for, harder than dealing with my dad's weird obsession with taxidermy, harder than *everything*.

For a long time, I felt...empty. Like a piece of me was missing. And it was. But it wasn't a bad missing, you know? It was a missing that made me realize how much I *could* feel. How much I *cared*.

It forced me to grow up, way faster than I wanted to. I had to figure out who I was, what I wanted, without having a baby to define me. It sounds weird, but it's true. Before, I was "the pregnant girl." After, I was just...Juno. And that was kinda terrifying.

It made me appreciate the people who were there for me. Paul and Vanessa, my dad, even Sean. They all helped me through it, in their own weird ways. And it made me realize that family isn't always about blood. It's about the people who love you and support you, no matter what.

I think it also made me more empathetic. More aware of other people's struggles. It's hard to judge people when you've been through something like that.

It didn't magically fix everything, though. I still have my issues. I still say sarcastic things to avoid feeling things. I still don't know what I want to do with my life. But I'm okay with that. I'm learning to be okay with not having all the answers.

It taught me that making a hard decision doesn't mean you're weak. It means you're brave enough to do what's right, even when it hurts. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

It's...complicated. But it made me who I am. And I think, ultimately, that's a good thing. Even if it took a long time to realize it.



It's not something I dwell on, but it's always there. A part of my story. And I wouldn't trade it, even if I could. Because it made me stronger. And it made me realize that even when things are really, really hard, you can still find a way to move forward.

Okay, wow. That's...a lot. If you're, like, staring at a positive pregnancy test and feeling your whole life just kinda tilt on its axis...listen up. Because I've been there. And it's not glamorous. It's messy and scary and you're gonna feel a whole bunch of things all at once.

First of all: it's okay to freak out. Seriously. Let yourself feel everything. Don't try to be strong all the time. It's okay to cry. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to be terrified. All of it.

Then, you gotta talk to someone. Not just anyone, but someone you trust. Your mom, a friend, a counselor...someone who won't judge you and will actually listen. Don't try to carry this alone. It's too much.

And then...you gotta make a decision. And that decision is *yours*. No one else's. Your parents might have opinions, your boyfriend might have opinions, but ultimately, it's your body and your life. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

I chose adoption. It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it felt right for me. And it doesn't mean I didn't love the baby. It just meant I wasn't ready to be a mom. And that's okay.

Whatever you decide, know that you're not alone. There are people who care about you and want to help. And you are stronger than you think. You're gonna get through this. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

And honestly? It's gonna change you. It's gonna make you grow up faster than you ever thought possible. But it's also gonna teach you a lot about yourself. About love. About responsibility. About what you really want out of life.

It's not a fairytale. It's real life. And it's messy and complicated and beautiful all at the same time. Just...breathe. And take it one day at a time. And remember, you've got this. Even when you don't feel like you do.



And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. They always make things a little bit better.

Ugh, okay, so the whole blogging thing? That wasn't exactly my idea. It was...Paulie Bleeker's. He's a good guy, Paulie. A little clueless sometimes, but good. He was all, "You should document this, Juno! It's, like, a really important story!" And I was all, "Are you kidding me? You want me to put my *life* on the internet for everyone to judge?"

But then I thought about it. And I realized...it was kinda a way to take control of the narrative, you know? Everyone was already having opinions about my situation. My parents, my school, even random people at the grocery store. It was exhausting.

So, I figured, why not tell the story *my* way? I could be honest about how I was feeling, without having to filter it through anyone else's expectations. It was a way to vent, I guess. And a way to connect with other people who might be going through something similar.

Plus, it was kinda funny. I mean, the whole thing was ridiculous. A sixteen-year-old getting pregnant? It's not exactly a normal situation. And I figured I could at least make people laugh about it. Or, you know, cringe. Either one was fine.

It wasn't about wanting attention or anything. It was about...owning my story. And maybe helping someone else feel a little less alone. And honestly? It was a good distraction from all the other stuff that was going on. It gave me something to focus on besides, you know, the impending arrival of a tiny human.

So yeah. That's why I started blogging. It was Paulie's idea, but it ended up being...helpful. In a weird, Juno MacGuff kinda way.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. Don't say I didn't warn you it was gonna get a little...real.

The biggest lesson? It wasn't about babies, or adoption, or even Paul Bleeker being surprisingly decent. It was about...owning your stuff. Like, *really* owning it.

Before all this happened, I was just kinda drifting, you know? Trying to be cool, trying to be funny, trying to avoid actually *feeling* anything. I was good at sarcasm, less good at, like, being honest with myself. I thought being independent meant pushing everyone away.

But getting pregnant...that forced me to face things. It forced me to grow up, whether I wanted to or not. And it forced me to realize that it's okay to need help. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to not have all the answers.

I thought giving the baby up meant giving up a part of myself. And in a way, it did. But it also meant making a really hard, really selfless decision. And that took a lot of courage. More courage than I thought I had.

So, yeah. The biggest lesson was that life is messy and complicated and you can't control everything. But you *can* control how you react to it. You can choose to be brave. You can choose to be kind. And you can choose to own your mistakes and learn from them.

It's not about being perfect. It's about being real. And it's about realizing that even when things are totally screwed up, you can still find a way to make something good out of it.

And also, that Paul Bleeker is a surprisingly good kisser. But that's a separate lesson. Don't overthink it.

Okay, look. This is…a big one. And honestly, there's no easy answer. It kinda sucks, right? Like, one minute you're just living your life, eating tater tots and making mix CDs, and the next minute…bam. Positive pregnancy test. It's a lot to process.

First of all: breathe. Seriously. Just take a deep breath. It's okay to freak out. It's okay to cry. It's okay to feel completely overwhelmed. That's normal.

Then, you gotta think. And I mean *really* think. Not just about what you want right now, but about what you want for your future. And for the baby's future. It's not a decision you can take lightly.

There are options, okay? And they're all valid. You can parent. You can choose adoption. You can…well, there are other options, but I'm not gonna go into those. Those are really personal and complicated.

Whatever you decide, it's gotta be *your* decision. Don't let anyone pressure you. Your parents, your boyfriend, your friends…they can offer advice, but ultimately, it's up to you.

And don't be afraid to ask for help. Talk to someone you trust. A friend, a family member, a counselor. It's okay to not be able to do this alone.

It's gonna be hard. No matter what you choose. There will be good days and bad days. There will be moments when you feel like you can't handle it. But you can. You're stronger than you think.

I learned that the hard way. It's not about being perfect. It's about making the best decision you can with the information you have. And it's about being brave enough to face the consequences.

And honestly? It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be confused. It's okay to not have all the answers. Just…be true to yourself. And remember that you're not alone. There are people who care about you and want to help.

And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. They're surprisingly comforting when you're feeling lost. Just saying.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all mushy and sentimental about a kid I haven't even, like, *met* yet? That's…intense. But fine. I've been doing a lot of thinking about this, actually. It's kinda terrifying and kinda amazing all at the same time.

Look, I don't want to force anything on this kid, okay? I had a pretty weird childhood, and my parents…they had their own stuff going on. I don't want to be *that* parent. The one who's all, "You're gonna be a doctor! You're gonna play the violin!" No. Just…no.

My ideal vision? It's not about a fancy job or a perfect life. It's about…happiness. Genuine, real happiness. I want this kid to find something they're passionate about, something that makes them excited to get out of bed in the morning. It doesn't matter *what* it is. Pottery, astrophysics, competitive eating…whatever floats their boat.

I want them to be kind. And brave. And to stand up for what they believe in, even when it's hard. And I want them to know that it's okay to be weird. It's okay to be different. It's okay to not fit in. In fact, it's kinda awesome.

I want them to have good friends. People who support them and make them laugh. And I want them to know that they're loved, unconditionally. Even when they mess up. Especially when they mess up.

And honestly? I just want them to be a good person. Someone who makes the world a little bit better. That's all.

I don't need them to be perfect. I don't need them to be successful. I just need them to be *them*. And to be happy. Is that too much to ask?

It's kinda scary, thinking about all the things that could go wrong. But it's also kinda exciting. I mean, I'm gonna be a mom. That's…a lot. But I think I can do it. I think I can give this kid a good life. A weird, messy, wonderful life. And that's all I really want.

Ugh, okay, this is a good question. And a frustrating one. People…they just assume a lot. Like, automatically.

The biggest misconception? That we're all, like, incapable. That we're just these clueless kids who can't handle responsibility. That we're ruining our lives and the baby's life. It's so…dismissive.

Look, yeah, it's scary. It's a lot to deal with. And it's not what I planned, okay? But it doesn't mean I'm stupid or lazy or anything. It means I'm a teenager who's suddenly got a lot on her plate. And I'm trying to figure it out.

I'm still figuring out *myself*, you know? What I want to do with my life. And now I'm also figuring out how to be a good mom. It's complicated. But it doesn't mean I'm failing. It means I'm learning.

People act like having a baby automatically means your life is over. Like you can't still have dreams and goals. Like you can't still be a person. That's just…wrong.

We're not all tragic cases. We're just…people. With complicated lives. And we deserve to be treated with respect. And maybe a little bit of understanding.

It's not about pity. It's about recognizing that we're capable of more than people think we are. And that we're doing the best we can. And sometimes, that's enough.



Seriously. It's annoying. And it's just…not true.

Ugh. Okay. This is…still a thing I think about. A lot. It wasn't like, a simple decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away! No biggie!" It was…messy.

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm still trying to figure out what I want to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. Paul and I…we were kids. We weren't ready. We weren't equipped. We were barely keeping our own lives together, let alone another person's.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *more*. A real family. A stable home. People who were actually prepared to be parents. Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were already planning for a baby, they had a beautiful house, they were just…ready.

I wanted my baby to have that. I wanted my baby to have everything I couldn't give.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

And honestly? It was also about me. I had my own life to live. I had dreams and goals and things I wanted to do. I didn't want to put everything on hold and become a mom when I wasn't ready.

It wasn't a selfish decision, even if it felt that way sometimes. It was a responsible one. It was a grown-up one. And it was the hardest, most important decision I've ever made.

It still feels weird talking about it. But yeah. That's why. It wasn't about giving up something I wanted. It was about giving my baby the best possible life. And that's something I can live with.

Ugh, okay, so that was…a process. It wasn't like, love at first sight with Vanessa and Mark, you know? It wasn't some movie moment where I just *knew*. It was way messier than that.

There were a lot of couples. A lot of people wanting a baby. And honestly, it was kinda overwhelming. Some of them were…intense. Like, they had the nursery already decorated and a whole life planned out for the kid before they even met me. That freaked me out. It felt like they wanted a *project*, not a person.

Vanessa and Mark were different. They were…normal. In a good way. They weren't trying to be perfect parents, they were just…real. They were a little awkward, a little clumsy, and they admitted they were scared. And that, honestly, made me trust them more.

Vanessa, she was a little bit…intense about organic food and homeschooling, which, okay, a little weird. But she also just seemed really kind and genuinely wanted to give a kid a good life. And Mark? He was just…sweet. He was quiet, but he listened. He asked me questions about what *I* wanted, not just what they wanted.

I met a lot of couples who were all about their careers and their social life. Vanessa and Mark, they just seemed to want a family. And they weren't looking for a perfect baby, either. They were okay with…me. With the whole situation. They didn't judge.

It wasn't about finding the "best" parents, because there's no such thing. It was about finding the people who I thought would love the baby the most. And who would let the baby be…themselves. 

It was a hard decision. Really hard. But in the end, I just had a feeling. A gut feeling. And sometimes, you just have to go with that. It wasn't perfect, but it felt…right. And that's all I could ask for.

Ugh, music. Okay, so, it was…everything. Seriously. Like, if my life was a movie, the soundtrack would be, like, 90% of the actual movie. It was how I dealt with everything. And there was a *lot* to deal with, even before the whole baby situation.

I wasn't into, like, mainstream pop or anything. That stuff felt…fake. I needed something real. Something that understood the awkwardness and the confusion and the general feeling of being a weirdo.

So, I was really into indie stuff. The Moldy Peaches, obviously. They were my lifeline. Kimya Dawson just *gets* it, you know? She writes about stuff that no one else talks about. And her voice is just…comforting. Like a warm blanket.

I also listened to a lot of Bright Eyes. Conor Oberst is a total sad sack, but in a good way. He just puts all his feelings out there, and it made me feel less alone in my own mess. And Death Cab for Cutie. Ben Gibbard is a master of melancholy.

I made a ton of mix CDs. Like, obsessively. It was how I communicated with people. I'd make a mix for Paul, or for my dad, or even for Leah, even though she mostly just listened to whatever was on the radio. It was like, "Here, this is me. This is how I feel."

Music was my escape. It was my friend. It was my therapist. It was the one thing that always made sense, even when everything else was falling apart. 

It still is, actually. Even now, with everything going on, I still need music. It helps me process things. It helps me breathe. It helps me remember that I'm not the only one who feels this way.

So yeah. Music was a pretty big deal. Still is. Don't even get me started on the importance of a good playlist. It can literally save your life.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. "Cope" is a strong word. More like...survive. It wasn't exactly a parade in my honor, you know? Maple Creek, Minnesota isn't exactly known for its progressive views on, well, *anything*. Especially not a sixteen-year-old getting knocked up.

Honestly? I mostly just ignored it. Or pretended to. Which is kinda my default setting anyway. I mean, people were whispering, obviously. At the diner, at school, even at the video store. It was…annoying. But I figured if I acted like it wasn't a big deal, maybe other people would start to think it wasn't.

My dad, he was…quiet. He wasn't thrilled, obviously, but he didn't yell or anything. He just kinda retreated into his man cave and watched a lot of Westerns. My stepmom, Bren, she was the one who actually talked to me. She was surprisingly cool about it. She didn't pretend to understand, but she was supportive. Which was…helpful.

And then there was Leah. My best friend. She was the one who kept me from completely losing it. She didn't judge me, she just…was there. She helped me pick out baby names and went to doctor's appointments with me. She was a lifesaver.

I also just…focused on what *I* wanted. I wanted to finish school. I wanted to find good parents for the baby. I wanted to make the best of a really messed up situation. And I figured if people had a problem with that, that was *their* problem, not mine.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely days when I just wanted to disappear. But I realized that hiding away wasn't going to solve anything. I had to face it. I had to own it. And I had to remember that I wasn't alone.

It's still kinda weird sometimes, you know? People look at you differently. But I've learned to not care so much about what other people think. I'm just trying to live my life, and that's all that matters. And honestly? I think I'm a stronger person for having gone through it. Even if it was totally terrifying.



It's not a story I love to tell, but it's my story. And I'm not ashamed of it. Not anymore.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a loaded question. It's not like a simple "happy ending" kind of thing, you know? It's messy. It's complicated. It's...real.

Right after Henry was born, it was...weird. Like, I held him, and he was perfect, and tiny, and smelled like...baby. And I felt this huge rush of everything. Love, obviously. But also, relief. And sadness. And a whole bunch of other stuff I didn't even have words for.

I knew giving him up was the right thing to do. I *had* thought it through, a million times. But knowing it and *feeling* it are two totally different things. It felt like...giving away a piece of myself. Which, I guess, I was.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa take him...that was hard. They were so excited, so ready. And I was happy for them, I really was. But it also felt like...watching someone else get the life I couldn't give him. A stable life. A good life.

For a while, I felt...empty. Like something was missing. And I was worried I'd made the wrong decision. But then I started getting letters and pictures from Vanessa. And I saw how much they loved him. And I realized that giving him a good life was more important than keeping him with me.

It wasn't about me. It was about Henry.

It still stings sometimes, you know? Especially on birthdays or holidays. But I know I did the right thing. And I'm grateful to Mark and Vanessa for giving him a wonderful home. 

It wasn't what I expected motherhood to be like. It wasn't about raising a kid, it was about *letting go*. And that's a really hard thing to do. But it taught me a lot about myself. About what I wanted out of life. And about the importance of making tough choices, even when they hurt.

It's not a story with a neat little bow on top. It's just...life. And it's okay that it's messy. It's okay that it's complicated. It just *is*. And I'm okay with that. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, so, the physical stuff? Not fun. Seriously. Like, one minute you're eating all the tater tots your heart desires, and the next minute you can barely smell a pickle without wanting to hurl. It's a betrayal, honestly. My body was just...not mine anymore. It was doing its own thing, and I was just along for the ride.

The morning sickness was the worst. It wasn't just in the morning, either. It was all day. Every day. And it wasn't just nausea, it was *everything*. I couldn't eat anything without feeling guilty, and I couldn't *not* eat anything without feeling worse. It was a vicious cycle.

And then there's the, like, growing part. Which is weird. And uncomfortable. And makes you waddle. I felt like a penguin. A very hormonal, very nauseous penguin.

But the emotional stuff? That was way harder. I mean, I'm usually pretty good at keeping my feelings bottled up, you know? Sarcasm is my defense mechanism. But this was different. I was scared. And confused. And really, really lonely, even when I was around people.

I cried a lot. Like, a *lot*. Over everything. Over commercials. Over burnt toast. Over the fact that my jeans didn't fit anymore. It was embarrassing.

I talked to my mom, a little. She tried to be supportive, but she didn't really get it. She had me pretty young, but it was a different situation. And I talked to Paul, sometimes. He was...sweet. In his own awkward way.

But mostly, I just tried to deal with it on my own. I listened to music. I wrote in my journal. I watched a lot of movies. And I tried to remind myself that it wasn't forever. That eventually, it would be over.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself. About what I'm capable of. And about the fact that even when things are really, really hard, you can still find a way to laugh. Even if it's just a little bit.

It's just...it's a lot to process, you know? Being a teenager and being pregnant at the same time? It's not exactly a recipe for a chill life. But you do what you have to do. And you hope for the best.

Okay. Wow. That's...a direct question. And honestly? It's not something I talk about a lot. It's personal. But you asked, and I guess it's important to be real about it.

Before...before everything happened, I didn't really *think* about reproductive rights, you know? It was just...something that was there. Like the sky is blue. You don't question it. You just assume it'll always be.

But then *I* was the one facing a choice. And it wasn't some abstract political debate anymore. It was my life. My future. And it was terrifying.

People had opinions, obviously. Lots of them. And they weren't shy about sharing. Some people thought I should just...keep it. No matter what. Others thought I should just...get rid of it. No matter what. It was like everyone else got to decide what was best for *my* body and *my* life.

And that's when I realized how fragile those rights are. How easily they can be taken away. Because if I hadn't had the option to choose, I would have been completely screwed. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I was sixteen! I had my own life to figure out.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it wasn't something I took lightly. But it was *my* decision. And I needed to be able to make it without anyone else telling me what to do.

So yeah, it completely changed my views. I'm a firm believer that everyone deserves the right to choose what happens to their own body. It's not about being pro-life or pro-choice. It's about being pro-freedom. It's about trusting women to make their own decisions.

And it's about understanding that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is choose not to bring a child into the world. It doesn't mean you don't care. It just means you're being responsible.

It's complicated. It's messy. And it's not something anyone should have to go through alone. But it's a choice that should always be available. Always. Because taking that choice away is taking away someone's power. And that's just...wrong.

Ugh, "overcome" is a strong word. I didn't exactly *overcome* them. They were just...there. Lurking. Like a really persistent zit you can't quite pop. But I learned to live with them, I guess. And to function despite them.

Honestly, the biggest fear wasn't even, like, the actual baby stuff. It was the judgment. Everyone looking at me, this, like, awkward teenager, and thinking, "Wow, what a mess." And the thought of messing *up* the baby's life. That was terrifying.

I think what helped, and it sounds cheesy, but it's true, was realizing I wasn't alone. My dad, even though he's kinda clueless sometimes, was actually really supportive. And Paul and Vanessa...they were amazing. They didn't treat me like a screw-up. They treated me like a person who needed help. And that made a huge difference.

Also, talking to other people who had gone through similar things. Not necessarily teen moms, just...people who had made big, scary decisions. It helped to know that everyone feels lost sometimes. And that it's okay to be scared.

But mostly, I think it was just...the baby. Once I started feeling the kicks and stuff, it wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person who was depending on me. And that kind of...shifted things. It made the fear less about what *I* wanted and more about what was best for *him*.

I still had panic attacks. I still worried constantly. But I learned to take things one day at a time. And to ask for help when I needed it. And to remember that even though I was young and inexperienced, I was capable of making good decisions.

It wasn't about being fearless. It was about being brave enough to be scared and still doing what needed to be done. And honestly? That's a skill that comes in handy in life, even when you're not dealing with a baby. It's about facing the music, even when the music is really loud and terrifying.



It's still a work in progress, you know? I'm still figuring things out. But I'm getting there. And that's all that matters.

Ugh, okay, so everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some big, dramatic decision I made after, like, hours of soul-searching and crying. Which, okay, there *was* some crying. But it wasn't that simple.

Honestly? It was mostly about being realistic. I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone for the rest of my life. I wasn't exactly equipped to raise a human being. I mean, I could barely keep a houseplant alive.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby, okay? That's what people always assume. It was about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. A life I couldn't give it, at least not then. I wanted it to have parents who were ready, who had a house and a stable income and, you know, actual adult things figured out.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, and they had this beautiful home and they just seemed…ready. It felt right. It felt like the best thing for the baby.

It wasn't easy, though. It was really, really hard. Saying goodbye was…well, it sucked. But I knew it was the right thing to do. And I got to be involved, you know? I got to choose the parents, and I got to stay in touch. It wasn't like I was just giving it away and never seeing it again.

I guess…I just wanted to be selfless. Which is kinda weird for me, I know. But I wanted to do something good. And I wanted the baby to be happy. And I figured, if I could give it that, then maybe I could forgive myself for being a screw-up.

It wasn't a perfect plan, but it was *my* plan. And it was the best I could do. And sometimes, that's all you can ask for.

Ugh. Okay, relationships. Don't even get me started. It's like, everyone's always talking about "finding love" and "soulmates" and all this fluffy stuff, but it's way more complicated than that. Especially when you're, you know, a teenager who accidentally got pregnant.

With Leah… Leah is my rock. Seriously. She's the only one who didn't freak out when I told her. She just… listened. And then she started making a list of baby names. She's weird, but she's *my* weird. We've been through everything together, and she's the only person I can really be myself around. Like, the real, messy, awkward me. She doesn't judge me for wanting to give the baby up, even though she doesn't totally get it. She just supports me, no matter what. It's… good. It's really good. Sometimes I worry I don't tell her enough how much she means to me. It's hard to be all mushy and stuff.

Paulie… Paulie is… a lot. He's sweet, I guess. And he's a good musician. But he's also kinda immature and flaky. He wanted to run away with me, which was… romantic, in a really dumb way. But I knew that wasn't the right thing to do. He's trying, though. He's actually trying to grow up and be responsible. He's been coming to the doctor's appointments and stuff, and he's even started thinking about college. It's…progress. I don't know if we'll ever be, like, a couple-couple. But we can be friends. And co-parents. That's enough, I think.

The whole thing is just…weird. It's not how I pictured my life turning out. But I'm learning that life doesn't always go according to plan. And sometimes, the best things happen when you least expect them. Even if those things involve a baby and a complicated relationship with a slacker musician.

It's all about figuring out what you want and what you need, and being honest with yourself and with the people you care about. And sometimes, that means making tough decisions. And sometimes, that means letting go of things you thought you wanted. It's messy and confusing and kinda scary. But it's also…real. And that's what matters, I guess.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a loaded question. It's not like I *decided* to become a teenage mom, okay? It just...happened. It wasn't a carefully considered life choice, like picking a college or a band t-shirt. It was a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake.

Paulie Bleeker and I...well, we were young and dumb and hormonal. And we weren't exactly responsible. We didn't, like, plan this out. It wasn't some grand romantic gesture or anything. It was just...a moment of bad judgment. A really, really bad moment of bad judgment.

Honestly, I was mostly just shocked. And scared. And nauseous. A lot nauseous. It didn't feel real at first. Like, this couldn't be happening to *me*. I had plans, you know? I was gonna go to college, maybe move to New York, become a writer or something. And suddenly, all of that felt...impossible.

It wasn't about wanting to be a mom. It wasn't about wanting a baby. It was about being pregnant. And having to deal with the consequences. And figuring out what to do next.

It was a really hard decision, giving him up. The hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't equipped to give him the life he deserved. And Mark and Vanessa, they were. They were perfect.

So, it wasn't a decision I *made* in the sense of wanting to be a mother. It was a decision I made about what was best for the baby. And for me. It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it was also...kind of empowering, in a weird way. It forced me to grow up. And to figure out who I was, and what I wanted.

It wasn't ideal. But it was my life. And I had to deal with it. And I did. And I'm still dealing with it, honestly. It's not something you just get over. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay. That's...the question, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know if I regretted it. Like it's some big, dramatic thing I'm still wrestling with.

Look, it wasn't easy. It was *really* not easy. There were days, especially after I had Mark, where I just...felt overwhelmed. Like, what had I gotten myself into? I was still a kid myself, and suddenly I was responsible for this tiny human. It was terrifying.

And yeah, there were moments where I wondered what my life would have been like if I'd just...done something else. If I'd kept him. If I'd run away. If I'd just...not gotten pregnant in the first place. It's normal to have those thoughts, right?

But regret? No. Not really.

Because Mark ended up with Vanessa and Mark. And they were *amazing* parents. They gave him a life I couldn't have given him. A stable home, a loving family, opportunities. They wanted him. And that was the most important thing.

And honestly, giving him up...it made me grow up. It forced me to figure out who I was and what I wanted. It wasn't the path I expected, but it led me to Paul, and to a life that's...good. It's messy, and complicated, and sometimes really hard, but it's *mine*.

So, no. I don't regret my decision. It was the right thing to do. For Mark. For Vanessa and Mark. And for me. It was a hard choice, but it was the right one.

It doesn't mean I don't think about him. I do. All the time. But I know he's happy. And that's enough. It has to be.



It's not a simple story, you know? Life rarely is. But I wouldn't trade it. Not for anything.

Ugh, okay, so that was...a whole thing. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. More like a stumble through a minefield of hormones, judgment, and a surprisingly large belly.

Honestly? Stubbornness. Pure, unadulterated stubbornness. I was already kinda a rebel, you know? Didn't really care about fitting in or being popular. So when everyone started looking at me differently, it just made me want to prove them wrong even more.

Paulie Bleeker was a huge help, obviously. He didn't treat me like I was broken or something. He just...was there. Helped me carry books, listened to me rant, and generally didn't make a big deal out of it. That was good.

And my dad. He was surprisingly cool about the whole thing. He wasn't thrilled, obviously, but he didn't yell or anything. He just started reading baby books and trying to figure out how to build a crib. It was kinda sweet, actually.

But mostly, it was just about showing up. Every. Single. Day. Even when I was exhausted and nauseous and felt like I could just sleep for a week. I had to go to school. I had to do my homework. I had to pass my classes. Not for anyone else, but for me. And for the baby.

I got a lot of help from my guidance counselor, too. She helped me figure out a plan to catch up on work and make sure I wasn't falling behind. And she let me take naps in her office sometimes. That was a lifesaver.

It wasn't easy. There were definitely days when I wanted to just give up. But I didn't. I just kept going. One day at a time. And eventually, I made it. I graduated. 

It wasn't the graduation I imagined, obviously. I was, like, eight months pregnant and waddling across the stage. But it was *my* graduation. And that's all that mattered.

It taught me a lot, though. About responsibility. About resilience. And about the importance of having people who believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself. It was a mess, but it made me who I am. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe for a nap. I could really use a nap right now.

Ugh. Okay. This is…it’s a big question. And it’s not like there was a flashing neon sign telling me what to do, you know? It wasn’t easy. It’s still not easy, honestly.

Look, when I first found out, I was…freaked out. Obviously. I was sixteen. I was supposed to be worrying about SATs and college applications and whether or not Paul Bleeker liked me back, not…this. Abortion was definitely on the table. It felt…practical. Like the sensible thing to do.

But then I started thinking about it. Really thinking. And it wasn’t about what *I* wanted, or what was easiest for *me*. It was about…the baby. It felt wrong to just…end it. Not because of any religious thing, or anything like that. Just…wrong.

I went to a clinic, and I talked to a counselor. And she didn’t tell me what to do, which was good. She just asked me questions. And I realized I couldn’t picture…not having it. Even though I knew I couldn’t raise it. I couldn’t give it the life it deserved.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…amazing. They were so excited, so ready. They wanted a baby so badly. And they weren’t looking for a perfect baby, or a perfect situation. They just wanted to love a child.

It felt…right. Like I could give this baby a good life, even if it wasn’t with me. It was a hard decision, the hardest I’ve ever made. But it felt like the right thing to do.

It wasn’t about being a hero, or doing the selfless thing. It was about…trying to do the least amount of damage. To everyone involved. And it was about giving this little person a chance.

It’s still complicated. I still think about it. But I know I made the best decision I could. And I hope…I hope it was the right one. It’s not something you just *get over*, you know? It’s part of me now. And I’m okay with that. Mostly.

Okay, wow. That's...a really good question. And a complicated one. I've been doing a *lot* of thinking about families lately, obviously. More than most people my age, probably.

Look, I'm not gonna pretend I had some grand plan for a perfect family before all this happened. I was just trying to get through high school. But now...now I'm seeing things differently.

What I've learned is that it's not about *who* you have as parents, it's about the *love* and support they give you. Like, a kid needs someone who's gonna be there for them, who's gonna listen, who's gonna help them with their homework and stuff. And who's gonna let them be themselves, you know?

So, yeah, absolutely a child can thrive with a single parent or two moms or two dads. It doesn't matter what their family *looks* like, as long as they feel loved and safe. Honestly, sometimes I think kids with "traditional" families are the ones who are messed up. You hear about all that stuff on the news.

My friend Paul, he's got two dads. And they're amazing. They're supportive and funny and they really care about him. He's a pretty well-adjusted kid, if you know what I mean. And Annie and Mark, the couple who are gonna adopt my baby? They're just...good people. They're excited and they're ready to be parents. And that's what matters.

It's not about fitting into some perfect little box. It's about finding a family that works. And sometimes, that family looks a little different than what you expect. And that's okay. It's more than okay. It's beautiful, actually.

So yeah. I believe in that. I really do. A kid just needs love. Period. Everything else is just details.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me do this. It's like, therapy session time, and I didn't sign up for that. But fine. You asked.

I think...I think I use sarcasm as a shield. Like, a really thick, impenetrable shield made of snark and witty comebacks. It's a good defense mechanism, right? Keeps people from getting too close, keeps you from having to actually *feel* things.

But it also means I push people away. And I don't always let people see the real me, the messy, confused, kinda scared me. I'm good at pretending I have everything under control, even when I'm totally freaking out inside.

It's not that I don't *want* to connect with people, it's just...easier to be funny than to be vulnerable. Easier to make a joke than to admit you're scared or sad or whatever.

I guess it's a way of protecting myself. But it also means I miss out on stuff. Real connections. Real intimacy. And sometimes, it just makes me feel really lonely, even when I'm surrounded by people.

It's a work in progress, okay? I'm learning. Slowly. But it's hard. It's a lot easier to just say something sarcastic and move on than to actually deal with your feelings.

So yeah. Sarcasm. It's my superpower and my biggest weakness, all rolled into one. Don't judge. It's complicated. And honestly, I'd rather talk about music than my emotional baggage. Can we change the subject now?

Ugh. Mark. Okay, so, that whole thing was…a lot. It wasn't, like, a fairytale romance or anything. It was more…complicated. And messy. And involved a lot of Bleachers songs.

Before Mark, I hadn't really *thought* about relationships, you know? I was too busy being sarcastic and avoiding feelings. I figured, if anyone even *looked* at me sideways, I'd just deliver a withering one-liner and they'd back off. It was a pretty effective system, honestly.

But then Mark…he didn't back off. He actually *liked* my sarcasm. He got my weirdness. And he didn't try to change me. Which, honestly, was a first.

But it wasn't just that. He was…genuine. He was a good person. And he was really into music, which is always a plus. But he was also kinda lost, you know? He was figuring things out, just like I was.

And that's where it got tricky. Because we were both trying to figure out our own stuff, we weren't really able to be there for each other in the way we needed to be. He was dealing with his dad, and I was dealing with…well, everything. The baby, Paul, Annie, my own identity. It was too much.

It made me realize that relationships aren't just about finding someone who likes you for who you are. It's about finding someone who can support you, even when you're being a total mess. And someone you can support in return. It's about being a team.

And we weren't a team. We were just two people, kinda drifting in the same direction.

It didn't make me cynical, though. It just made me…realistic. I realized that love isn't always easy. It takes work. And it takes timing. And sometimes, even if you really like someone, it's just not the right time.

It taught me that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to let people see your flaws. And it's okay to walk away if something isn't working. Even if it hurts.

So yeah, Mark changed my perspective. He showed me that relationships are complicated and messy and sometimes heartbreaking. But they can also be beautiful and meaningful. And that's worth something. Even if it doesn't always work out the way you expect it to.

Okay, wow. That's...a big question. And it's kinda weird to be giving advice, considering I was a total mess for a while there. But alright, here goes.

First of all: it's okay to be scared. Like, *really* scared. It's okay to cry. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel like your whole life is falling apart. Because it kinda is. But it doesn't have to stay that way.

Don't let anyone tell you what you *should* do. Seriously. Your parents, your friends, your boyfriend...everyone's gonna have an opinion. But it's *your* body, *your* life, and *your* decision. And it has to be what's right for *you*, not what anyone else thinks is right.

It's also okay to ask for help. I was so determined to be all independent and tough, but I needed people. Paul, Vanessa, even my dad...they all helped me get through it. Don't be afraid to lean on the people who care about you.

And don't feel guilty. Whatever you decide, don't let guilt eat you up. It's a complicated situation, and there are no easy answers. You're doing the best you can.

I chose adoption, and it was the right decision for me. But that doesn't mean it's the right decision for everyone. There are other options, and they're all valid.

Just...think about what you want. What's going to make you happy? What's going to give you a good life? And then do that. Even if it's scary. Even if it's hard.

And remember, you're not alone. There are other people who have been through this. There are resources available. You can get through it.

It's gonna be tough. But you're tougher. You're stronger than you think. And you deserve to be happy. Don't forget that.



Honestly, it's a mess. But you can make it a good mess. Or at least, a survivable one. Just breathe. And take it one day at a time.

Ugh, my dad. Okay, so, it started out...complicated. He's a good guy, really. Just...not always *present*. He's a handyman, which means he's always fixing stuff for other people, but sometimes forgets to fix things around our own house. Metaphor, much?

When I was little, he was just...Dad. He built me forts and took me to the movies. But then Mom left, and things got weird. He kinda retreated into himself, you know? Started listening to a lot of Van Morrison and just...existing. He wasn't *bad*, he just wasn't really *there*.

And then, when I got pregnant...that was a whole other level of awkward. He tried to be supportive, I guess. He made me pancakes and stuff. But he mostly just looked really, really worried. Like I'd broken something valuable. Which, I mean, in a way, I had.

But then, as things started to get real, and I decided to go through with the adoption, he actually started to...listen. He didn't try to tell me what to do, which was a huge relief. He just...sat with me. And asked questions. And actually *heard* my answers.

He helped me build the rocking horse for the baby, which was...surprisingly emotional. It was like, he was finally connecting with me on a different level. Not just as his daughter, but as a person making a really big decision.

Now? We still don't talk about everything. He's still kinda quiet and reserved. But there's a...respect there now. A real understanding. He still listens to Van Morrison, but he doesn't do it *at* me anymore. 

It's not a perfect relationship, okay? It's still a work in progress. But it's...better. He's learning to be a dad again, and I'm learning to let him. And that's something, right? It's definitely something. It's just...slow. Like everything with my dad.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know how I, like, accidentally became a semi-decent writer? It wasn't a conscious thing, okay? I didn't take a bunch of fancy classes or anything. It just...happened.

I think it started with just observing people. Seriously. I spent a lot of time just *watching* people at school, at the mall, wherever. And making up stories about them in my head. Like, what's their deal? What are they thinking? What's their secret heartbreak? It's kinda nosy, I guess, but it's good material.

Then I started writing in a journal. Not like a "Dear Diary, today I met a cute boy" kind of journal. More like a "Here are all my random thoughts and observations and sarcastic comments" kind of journal. It was a good way to get stuff out of my head. And to practice writing, I guess.

And then, you know, the whole pregnancy thing happened. And I had to write a paper for school about it. And it wasn't just a school paper, it was...my story. And I wanted to tell it honestly, and with a little bit of humor, because if you don't laugh, you'll cry, right?

So I just started writing. And it just...flowed. I didn't really think about grammar or structure or anything. I just wrote what I was feeling. And it turned out to be pretty good.

I guess the key is to just write. A lot. And to not be afraid to be yourself. And to find your voice. And to not take yourself too seriously. Because if you do, you'll just end up with a bunch of boring, pretentious writing.

And also, listen to The Moldy Peaches. They're inspiring. In a weird way.

So yeah. That's how I became a writer. Accidentally. It's not a glamorous job, but it's mine. And it's better than working at a cheese factory, that's for sure.

Ugh. Okay, that's...the big one, right? The thing everyone was staring at, whispering about. Honestly? It sucked. A lot. It still kinda does, even now.

The thing is, people are *nosy*. And they love to have opinions about things that aren't their business. Especially when it comes to other people's bodies and choices. I got the whole spectrum. The pitying looks, the judgmental stares, the "Oh, honey, what are you going to *do*?"s. It was exhausting.

I think the first thing I did was just...brace myself. I knew it was coming. And I knew I couldn't control what other people thought. I could only control how I reacted to it.

I leaned *hard* on my friends. Paul and Leah were amazing. They didn't treat me like I was broken or stupid or anything. They just...were there. They made fun of me when I needed it, and they listened when I needed to talk. That was huge.

My dad was...complicated. He was quiet at first, but he came around. He started reading parenting books, which was kinda hilarious. And my mom, she was just my mom. She was worried, but she was also supportive.

I also just...tried to ignore the haters. Easier said than done, obviously. But I realized that most of the judgment came from people who didn't know me, or didn't understand my situation. Their opinions didn't matter.

And honestly, I used my sarcasm as a shield. If someone was being judgmental, I'd just fire back with a witty remark. It was a way to deflect the negativity and maintain some control.

It wasn't easy. There were days when I just wanted to hide under the covers and never come out. But I kept reminding myself that I was making the best decision for me and for the baby. And that's what mattered.

I think the biggest thing I learned is that people are always going to judge you, no matter what you do. So you might as well do what makes you happy, and surround yourself with people who support you. And don't be afraid to tell the judgmental people to shove it. Seriously.



It's your life. Your body. Your choice. And nobody has the right to tell you otherwise. Even if they think they're being helpful.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Like, seriously. It's not something I spend a *lot* of time dwelling on, because honestly, who has the energy? But yeah, sometimes. Sometimes I do.

Look, I'm not exactly known for my tact, okay? I say what's on my mind. It's just...how I'm wired. And most of the time, it works out fine. People know where they stand with me. There's no guessing. No fake niceness.

But there have been times when my honesty has, like, blown up in my face. Hurt someone's feelings. Made a situation way more awkward than it needed to be. Especially with Paul. And even with my dad, sometimes. He's a sensitive guy, even if he pretends he's not.

And it's not that I *want* to hurt people. It's just...I don't see the point in sugarcoating things. Life's too short for that. But sometimes, a little sugarcoating might be the kinder thing to do.

I guess what I'm saying is, I don't regret *being* honest. I regret the times when my honesty was just...mean. Or insensitive. Or just plain unnecessary. 

It's a learning process, you know? Figuring out how to be true to yourself without being a total jerk. It's hard. And I'm still working on it.

But I'm not gonna apologize for being me. I'm not gonna start pretending to be someone I'm not just to make other people feel better. That's exhausting. And it's not worth it.

So yeah, sometimes I regret it. But mostly, I just try to be a little more mindful. And maybe count to ten before I open my mouth. Sometimes.



It's a work in progress, okay? Don't judge.

Ugh, okay, that's...the million-dollar question, isn't it? Like, everyone has an opinion on what you should do, who you should be, especially when you're doing something...unconventional. And it's *exhausting*.

Honestly, I'm still figuring it out. I mean, I'm sixteen. I'm supposed to be worrying about prom and getting my driver's license, not, you know, having a baby and deciding what to do with it.

But here's what I've learned so far, and it's not always pretty. First of all, you gotta realize that most people are just...scared. They don't understand what you're doing, so they judge it. It makes them feel better about their own lives, I guess. It's pathetic, but it's true.

So, you can't take it personally. Easier said than done, I know. But you have to remind yourself that their opinions are about *them*, not about *you*.

And then you gotta figure out what *you* want. What feels right. What makes you feel...okay. And that's the hard part, because it's not always what other people think you should do. It's not always the easy path.

I've had people tell me I'm making a mistake giving the baby up for adoption. That I should keep it. That I'm selfish. And I've had people tell me I'm irresponsible for getting pregnant in the first place. It's a lot.

But I know what I want. I want to finish school. I want to have a life. And I want to give this baby a good life, even if that means someone else raising it.

So, I just...ignore the noise. I surround myself with people who support me, like Paul and Annie and even my dad, surprisingly. And I focus on what's important to me.

It's not about being defiant or trying to prove anyone wrong. It's about being true to yourself. Even when it's hard. Especially when it's hard.

Because at the end of the day, you're the one who has to live with your decisions. Not them. And you gotta be able to look yourself in the mirror and say, "Yeah, I did what I thought was right." Even if it's messy. Even if it's complicated. Even if it's not what everyone else wanted.

It's your life. Own it. And don't let anyone tell you otherwise.



And maybe listen to some good music. That always helps.

Ugh, values. That sounds like something you talk about in social studies class. But okay, fine. If I have to get all deep and philosophical, I will.

I guess…honesty is pretty big. Like, I try to be real with people, even if it's awkward. I don't really do the whole fake-nice thing. It just feels… exhausting. And pointless.

And independence. I mean, I'm kinda doing this whole pregnancy thing on my own, right? So, being able to take care of myself and make my own decisions is important. It doesn't mean I don't need help, 'cause I definitely do. But I want to be the one calling the shots.

Also, I think it's important to be…kind. Even to people you don't like. It's not always easy, especially when people are being jerks. But I try. Because everyone's dealing with their own stuff, you know?

And…I guess I value authenticity. Being true to yourself. Not trying to be someone you're not. It's kinda hard to explain. It's just…feeling comfortable in your own skin. Even if your skin is covered in awkward teenage angst.

I don't know. I'm still figuring things out. I'm not like, a fully formed adult with all the answers. But those are the things that feel important to me right now. Being honest, independent, kind, and…real.

It's not a perfect list, but it's mine. And that's what matters, right?

Ugh, okay, so everyone always focuses on the whole "giving the baby up" part, which, yeah, that was…a lot. But honestly? The biggest challenge wasn't *deciding* to do that. It was dealing with everyone else's opinions about it.

Like, suddenly everyone was an expert on my body and my life. My parents, obviously. They were…concerned. And then there was Sean, who was trying to be supportive, but mostly just looked confused. And then all the people at school, whispering and staring. It was exhausting.

It felt like everyone was trying to tell me what to do, what to feel, what was "right." And nobody was listening to *me*. It was my pregnancy, my decision, but it felt like everyone else had a say.

And it wasn't just the big stuff, either. It was the little things. People asking me if I was scared, or if I regretted it, or if I was going to keep it. Like, can you just…not? I was already dealing with a lot. I didn't need a constant stream of judgment and unsolicited advice.

I just wanted people to let me be me, you know? To let me figure things out on my own. But that didn't happen. It was like everyone thought they had to "fix" me, or "save" me.

So yeah, the biggest challenge wasn't the pregnancy itself. It was navigating all the expectations and opinions and trying to stay true to myself in the middle of it all. It was realizing that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is just…be yourself, even when everyone else is telling you to be someone else.

It was a mess. A really big, complicated mess. But I got through it. And I learned a lot. Mostly that people are nosy and you gotta learn to tune them out. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just trust your gut. Even if it's telling you to do something that everyone else thinks is crazy.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me get all sappy on you. It's...complicated. It's not like some movie montage where suddenly everything is rainbows and unicorns, okay? It's messy. And exhausting. And terrifying. But also...good. Really good.

Before, my biggest problem was, like, finding the perfect vintage dress or figuring out what to say to Mark. Stupid stuff. Now? Now I'm responsible for another human being. A tiny, demanding, adorable human being. It's a lot of pressure.

It makes you think about the future in a way you never did before. Not just *my* future, but *her* future. What kind of world is she going to grow up in? What kind of person is she going to be? It's kinda overwhelming.

I used to think I had everything figured out. I was all sarcastic and independent and didn't need anyone. But being a mom...it makes you realize you're not as strong as you thought you were. You need help. You need support. You need people who love you and will be there for you, even when you're a total mess.

It also makes you appreciate the little things. Like, a good night's sleep. Or a quiet moment to drink a cup of coffee. Or just watching her smile. Those things used to seem insignificant, but now they're everything.

I still don't have all the answers. I'm still figuring things out. But I think...I think being a mom has made me a better person. More patient. More compassionate. More willing to ask for help. And it's definitely made me realize what's really important in life.

It's not about being cool or popular or having the perfect life. It's about love. And family. And making the world a little bit better for the next generation.

Ugh. See? I told you I was gonna get sappy. Don't tell anyone I said any of this, okay? It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, self-doubt. It's the worst, right? Like, you're trying to be all strong and independent and make good decisions, and then your brain just decides to throw a party of "What ifs?" and "You're gonna mess everything up!" It's super annoying.

Honestly, I'm still figuring that out. It doesn't just *go away*, you know? Especially with...everything that happened with the baby. There were a lot of moments where I was just like, "Am I doing the right thing? Am I a terrible person?" It's scary.

What helps me, and it sounds cheesy, is talking to people. Like, really talking. Not just saying "I'm fine" when I'm clearly not. I mean, talking to Paul, or my dad, or even Leah. They don't always have answers, but just having someone listen and not judge...that makes a difference.

And then there's music. Seriously. Putting on a mix CD and just letting the music wash over you. It kinda drowns out the negative voices in your head. The Moldy Peaches are good for that. They're sad, but also kinda hopeful.

I also try to remind myself that everyone messes up. Everyone. It's part of being human. And that making a mistake doesn't mean you're a bad person. It just means you're learning.

And sometimes, you just have to fake it 'til you make it. You know? Put on a brave face and pretend you know what you're doing, even when you have no idea. Eventually, you actually start to believe it.

It's not a perfect system. I still have moments where I'm totally overwhelmed with doubt. But I'm learning to be okay with that. To accept that it's okay to not be okay. And to keep moving forward, even when I'm scared.

It's a process, you know? And it's not always pretty. But it's worth it. Because you deserve to be happy, even if you don't always feel like it. And you're stronger than you think. Probably.

Ugh, okay, that's...a surprisingly deep question. And honestly? It's something I didn't really *get* until, well, everything happened. Before, I was pretty good at being a lone wolf. I had my music, my sarcastic comments, and that was enough. I didn't really *need* people. Or at least, I told myself I didn't.

But then I found out I was pregnant, and suddenly...everything changed. It wasn't just about me anymore. And I realized I couldn't do it alone.

My friend Leah, she was a lifesaver. She didn't judge me, she just...listened. And helped me pick out baby names. And even went with me to some of the doctor's appointments, which was mortifying, but also really nice.

And then there's my dad. He's...my dad. He's kinda clueless sometimes, but he always tries his best. And he was surprisingly supportive, even though I think he was terrified.

And Paul and Vanessa, the couple I met through the adoption ad? They were amazing. They were so open and honest, and they made me feel like I wasn't a terrible person for wanting to give my baby a good life, even if it wasn't with me.

I realized that having people who care about you, who believe in you, who are there for you when you're falling apart...that's everything. It's not about needing someone to fix your problems, it's about having someone to share them with. Someone to make you laugh when you want to cry. Someone to remind you that you're not alone.

It's still hard for me to ask for help, okay? I'm still pretty independent. But I've learned that it's okay to lean on people sometimes. It doesn't make you weak, it makes you human.

So yeah, community and social support? It's super important. Maybe even more important than I thought. It's what gets you through the tough times. It's what makes life worth living. It's...well, it's everything. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, okay, that's...a loaded question. It's not like there was a little pamphlet that came with the positive pregnancy test that was all, "Here's the one thing you're supposed to learn!" It was more like a slow, messy, kinda painful process of figuring stuff out.

But if I had to pick *one* thing...it's that you can't control everything. Like, at all. I thought I was pretty good at being in control. I had my life planned out, you know? Music, college, avoiding drama. And then BAM. Unexpected baby. Total chaos.

And I tried to control it. I tried to make the perfect plan, find the perfect parents, be the perfect pregnant teenager. But it just didn't work. Things happened that were out of my hands. People said and did things I didn't expect. 

And I realized that's just...life. You can't predict everything. You can't force things to go the way you want them to. All you can do is make the best decisions you can with the information you have, and then let go.

It sounds kinda cheesy, I know. But it's true. And it's not just about the baby, either. It's about everything. It's about accepting that things are gonna be messy and complicated and imperfect. And that's okay. 

It's about learning to trust yourself, even when you're scared. And it's about realizing that sometimes, the best things in life are the things you never planned for.

So yeah. Letting go of control. That was the big one. It still doesn't mean I *like* not being in control, but I'm getting better at it. Slowly. It's a work in progress.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Like, people are always asking me what I want to *be* when I grow up. As if I have it all figured out. Which, spoiler alert, I totally don't.

But writing...yeah, maybe. It's not like I've got a five-year plan or anything. I'm not aiming to be the next Jane Austen, okay? But I do like words. I like putting them together in a way that makes people feel something. Or laugh. Or at least not fall asleep.

I mean, I wrote a bunch of letters to Paul, right? And those weren't exactly Pulitzer Prize-winning material, but they were...honest. And I guess that's what matters.

I'm good at observing people, too. Like, I can size someone up in five seconds and know exactly what's going on with them. That's a useful skill for a writer, I think. Or a therapist. Or a really good gossip.

I don't know if I want to write novels or poems or screenplays or what. Maybe I'll just write letters to people for the rest of my life. Or maybe I'll be a journalist and expose all the corruption in the world. Or maybe I'll just work at a record store and write song reviews in my spare time.

Honestly, I'm open to anything. As long as it doesn't involve a cubicle and a boss who breathes down my neck. I need freedom. I need to be able to think for myself. And I need to be able to say what I think, even if it's unpopular.

So, will I pursue a career in writing? I don't know. Maybe. It's a possibility. It's something I'm thinking about. But right now, I'm just trying to survive high school and figure out what I want for dinner. One step at a time, you know?



Don't hold me to it, okay? I change my mind like I change my socks. Which, admittedly, isn't very often.

Ugh, okay, so the baby name thing. That was...a process. A really weird process. It wasn't like, a sudden epiphany or anything. It was more like a slow descent into madness, fueled by too much orange juice and a desperate need to find something, *anything*, that felt right.

At first, I was just making lists. Like, endless lists. Boy names, girl names, gender-neutral names. It was exhausting. Paul wanted something "normal," which, let's be real, is boring. And Vanessa, well, she had opinions. Lots of them.

I tried going through family names, but everything sounded either too old-fashioned or too…Vanessa. No offense, Vanessa. You know I love you.

Then I started looking at names in books and movies. That didn't work either. Everything felt cliché. Like, naming a baby "Scarlett" because of *Gone With the Wind*? Please.

And then, I was flipping through this magazine – don't judge, I was bored – and I saw an ad for a bakery. And the bakery was called "Honey." And I just...felt something. It was simple, and sweet, and kinda unexpected.

It wasn't about wanting a gendered name, or a fancy name, or a name that sounded good with a middle name. It was just about finding a name that felt...warm. And hopeful. And a little bit sticky, like honey.

So, yeah. Honey MacGuff. It's not what anyone expected, but it felt right. And honestly, that's all that mattered. It's a good name. It suits her. Even if it did take me, like, a month of agonizing to come up with it. Don't tell anyone I said that. It makes me sound indecisive.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It was more like a really bumpy, confusing, and occasionally terrifying rollercoaster that smelled faintly of hospital disinfectant and regret.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was good at being sarcastic and pretending I didn't care, but underneath all that, I was a mess. I mean, I was carrying a baby, and then I was…not. It's weird. It's like, your body remembers something your mind is trying to forget.

I talked to Paul, a lot. He was surprisingly good at listening, even when I was being a total jerk. And my dad. He didn't always *understand*, but he always just…sat with me. That helped.

But the hardest part was just letting go. I kept imagining the baby with Mark and Vanessa, and it was like a punch to the gut. I wanted to be selfish, to keep the baby, but I knew that wasn't the right thing to do. They could give the baby a life I couldn't. And that was…okay. Eventually.

I wrote a lot. Just, like, rambling in my notebook. It helped me sort through my feelings. And I listened to music. A lot of The Moldy Peaches. They're good for sad times.

There were days when I just cried. A lot. And days when I was angry. And days when I just felt…empty. It was a whole spectrum of awful.

But you know what helped the most? Knowing that I was doing something selfless. That I was giving this baby a good life. And seeing how happy Mark and Vanessa were. That made it a little bit easier.

It didn't magically fix everything, though. It still stings sometimes. But I learned that it's okay to feel sad, and it's okay to grieve. And that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is also the right thing to do.

It's not something you just "get over," you know? It's something you learn to live with. And it made me grow up, in a way I never expected. It made me realize that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that's…something.

Okay, so music. That's a good question. It kinda depends on my mood, honestly. But mostly, I'm into stuff that's...real. You know? Not all polished and fake.

I'm a huge fan of The Moldy Peaches, obviously. Kimya Dawson is, like, a lyrical genius. She writes about stuff that actually matters, in a way that's kinda funny and kinda heartbreaking at the same time.

I also really like Belle & Sebastian. They're kinda twee and melancholic, but in a good way. It's good music for thinking. Or for staring out the window and feeling sorry for yourself. Which, let's be real, I do a lot of.

I listen to a lot of indie stuff. Death Cab for Cutie, Bright Eyes, The Shins...that kind of thing. It's all kinda angsty and emotional, which is perfect for a teenager who's dealing with, you know, *life*.

And I have a soft spot for oldies. Like, The Velvet Underground and stuff. My dad used to listen to it, so it reminds me of him.

I'm not really into mainstream pop. It's just...too much. Too fake. Too manufactured. I need something with a little more substance. Something that feels genuine.

So yeah. That's pretty much my musical taste in a nutshell. It's a little bit quirky, a little bit sad, and a whole lot of honest. It's kinda like me, I guess.



Don't ask me about country music, though. That's just...a hard no.

Ugh, okay, so the Van Der Groots' house...it was...a lot. Like, aggressively cheerful. Everything was beige and Pottery Barn-y. It smelled like potpourri and…success, I guess? It was the kind of house where you felt like you had to whisper, even though you weren't doing anything wrong.

And Mark and Vanessa? They were nice. *Really* nice. Like, overly nice. They had a whole playroom set up, even before they even *had* a baby. It was kinda creepy, honestly. Like they were already planning out this perfect little life, and I wasn't sure if there was room for, you know, actual life in it.

They were super into organic food and homeschooling and classical music. Which is fine, if that's your thing. But it wasn't *my* thing. I'm more of a tater tot and indie rock kinda girl. It felt…different. Like a different planet.

I remember thinking, "This is what a normal family looks like." And it wasn't bad, exactly. It was just…not what I was used to. My mom and I, we're more…messy. And loud. And we eat a lot of junk food. 

I was worried, I guess. Worried that the baby wouldn't fit in. That she'd be, like, too loud or too messy or too…*me*. But then I realized that wasn't my decision to make. It was about finding a family that would love her, even if they didn't share my taste in music or furniture.

It was weird, though. Definitely weird. It felt like I was visiting a museum exhibit on "The Perfect Family." And I was just…Juno. A messy, sarcastic teenager who was about to give up her baby. It was a lot to process.



It wasn't a bad house, or bad people. It was just…different. And different can be scary. But sometimes, different is good. Sometimes, different is exactly what someone needs.

Ugh, okay, so the band. Yeah. That was...a thing. It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "I must form a garage band!" It was more of a desperate attempt to fill the void, you know? Like, everything was already so weird and complicated, I figured why not add another layer of weirdness?

It started with Paul. He was always noodling around on his guitar, and he's actually pretty good, even if he's kinda spacey. And then there was Renée, who's...Renée. She's got a lot of energy and a surprisingly good voice. And then me. I just...needed something to do with my hands that wasn't knitting baby booties or obsessing over test scores.

I think the idea really solidified when I was at a record store with Bleeker. He was talking about how music is, like, a way to express yourself and connect with people. And I was thinking, "Yeah, well, I'm expressing a lot of things right now, and none of them are particularly connectable." 

So I was like, "What if we just...made noise?" Like, really loud, messy noise. It felt like a good way to get everything out. All the confusion and the fear and the awkwardness. 

We didn't have a plan or anything. We just started jamming in Paul's garage. It was terrible at first. Really terrible. But then, slowly, it started to come together. We wrote some songs about, you know, life and stuff. And it was actually...fun.

It wasn't about becoming famous or anything. It was just about having a place to be ourselves and make something together. It was a distraction. A way to feel a little bit less alone. And honestly, it was a lot more satisfying than I expected.

Plus, it gave me an excuse to wear band t-shirts. Which is always a good thing.

Okay. Wow. That's...a big one. And honestly, it's kinda weird to be giving advice on this, even though, you know, *I've been there*. But okay, here goes.
