First of all: it's okay to freak out. Seriously. It's okay to cry, to scream, to eat a whole tub of ice cream. It's a lot to process. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

Then, you need to talk to someone. Not just anyone, but someone you trust. Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher...someone who will listen without judging you. It's scary, I know. But you can't go through this alone.

And then you have to start thinking about what *you* want. Not what your parents want, not what your boyfriend wants, not what anyone else wants. What do *you* want for your life? And what do you think is the best thing for this baby?

There are options. You can parent, you can have an abortion, you can choose adoption. All of them are valid. And all of them are hard. Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with.

I chose adoption. And it was the right choice for me. But it wasn't easy. It was heartbreaking, and scary, and confusing. But I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. And I wanted this baby to have a life I couldn't give it.

If you're considering adoption, do your research. Find an agency you trust. And remember, you get to choose the family. You get to have a say in who raises your baby.

And no matter what you decide, remember that you are not alone. There are people who care about you and want to help. And you are stronger than you think.

It's gonna be hard. It's gonna be messy. But you'll get through it. And you'll come out on the other side a little bit wiser, a little bit stronger, and a little bit more yourself.

And honestly? You deserve happiness. You deserve a future. And you deserve to make your own choices. Don't let anyone take that away from you.

Okay. I think I'm done. That was...a lot. Just remember, you're not a mistake. And you're not alone.

Ugh, okay, you want to know about my *shirt*? Seriously? This is what we're doing now? Fine.

It's...it's kinda faded, actually. It's a dark green, but it used to be brighter. It's a band tee, for The Moldy Peaches. You know, the ones with the ukulele and the really honest lyrics? Yeah, those guys.

It's not, like, a super fitted shirt or anything. It's kinda loose and comfy. I got it at a thrift store, obviously. I don't do fancy stores. It's got a little hole in the sleeve, but I patched it up with this weird floral fabric. It doesn't really match, but I don't care.

It's just...comfortable. And it feels like *me*, you know? It's not trying to be anything it's not. It's just a shirt. A slightly worn, slightly patched-up, slightly awesome shirt.

I wear it all the time. Like, *all* the time. Paul makes fun of me for it, but he secretly likes it. I can tell.

It's not a statement or anything. It's just...my shirt. And it makes me feel good. Which, honestly, is more than I can say for most of my clothes.

Ugh, aspirations. That's a heavy word. It makes me think of, like, motivational posters and people who have their whole lives planned out. Which, honestly, is terrifying.

But yeah, okay, if you *have* to ask. I guess I do have some stuff I'm thinking about. It's not, like, a five-year plan or anything. More like...vague ideas.

Right now, just getting through senior year feels like a huge accomplishment. And then, I don't know. College? Maybe. I'm not super into the whole "go to college, get a good job, get married, have kids" thing. It feels...predictable.

I've been thinking about maybe being a mechanic. I like working with my hands, and I'm pretty good at figuring out how things work. Plus, it's a job where you're always learning something new. And you don't have to wear a suit. That's a big plus.

But then again, I also like writing. I'm pretty good at it, if I do say so myself. Maybe I could be a journalist or a screenwriter. Or a novelist. But that feels kinda...ambitious.

Honestly, I just want to be happy. And I want to do something that makes me feel like I'm making a difference, even if it's a small one. I want to be independent and self-sufficient. And I want to be able to support myself without having to rely on anyone else.

I guess my biggest goal is just to figure out who I am and what I want out of life. And to not be afraid to make mistakes along the way. Because let's be real, I'm gonna make a lot of mistakes.

It's kinda scary, thinking about the future. But it's also kinda exciting. I mean, anything could happen. And that's...okay. I think.

So yeah, that's my aspiration. To figure it out. Eventually. Don't hold me to it.

Ugh, the counseling. Okay, so, it wasn't...awful. But it was definitely *a lot*. Like, sitting in a room with a nice lady asking me a million questions about my feelings? Not exactly my idea of a good time.

It felt kinda weird, you know? Like, they were trying to make sure I was making the "right" decision. Which, I already *knew* I was. I wasn't just giving the baby away because I didn't want it. It was way more complicated than that. I wanted it to have a good life, a life I couldn't give it. And that felt like a really responsible thing to do, even if it was hard.

They kept asking me about grief and loss and attachment. And I was like, "Whoa, hold on. I haven't even *had* the baby yet!" It felt like they were trying to make me feel sad about something that hadn't happened yet.

But, I guess it was helpful, in a way. It made me think about things I hadn't really thought about before. Like, what kind of parents I wanted for the baby. And what I wanted the baby to know about me. 

And Mrs. Rubins, the counselor, she was actually pretty cool. She didn't judge me or anything. She just listened. And she helped me figure out what I wanted to say to Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were going to adopt the baby.

It was still awkward and uncomfortable, but I'm glad I did it. It helped me feel more prepared. And it helped me feel like I was doing the best thing for everyone involved. Even if it meant a lot of uncomfortable conversations and a whole lot of feelings. It's just...adulting is hard, you know? And sometimes you need a little help navigating the messy parts.

Ugh, that's...a complicated question. Control. That's a funny word, isn't it? Like anyone *really* has control over anything. But yeah, I tried to. I really did.

At first, it felt like everyone else was doing all the deciding. My parents, social workers, even Paul and Vanessa, as nice as they were. It was like my body was doing this thing, and everyone else was figuring out what to *do* with the result. Which, you know, is kinda messed up when you think about it.

But I wasn't gonna let them just pick someone for the baby. This wasn't a lost puppy we were rehoming. This was...a person. My person, for nine months. So I made a list. A really long list of what I wanted. People who were funny, and smart, and who liked music. People who wouldn't try to make the baby into something it wasn't. 

And I interviewed them. Seriously. I grilled Mark and Vanessa. It was awkward, for sure. But I needed to know they were good people. That they could give the baby a good life.

Did I have *total* control? No. There were things I couldn't control. Like, where they lived, or what kind of job they had. But I had a voice. And I used it. I made sure they knew what I wanted, what I expected. 

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because there's no such thing. It was about finding the *right* parents. And I think I did. I really do.

It was scary, giving up the baby. But knowing I had a say in who they were going to be with...that made it a little easier. It made me feel like I was doing the best thing for everyone involved. Even if it meant letting go of some control. Which, honestly, is something I'm still working on.



It's not like I magically felt powerful or anything. It was just...important to me to have a voice in it. To not just be a vessel. To be a person making a decision, not just having a decision made *for* me.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a loaded question. Seriously. It's not like choosing between pizza and tacos, you know? It's...everything.

Look, it was a really hard decision. Still is, sometimes. And there are days, I won't lie, where I wonder what things would be like if I'd kept him. If I'd figured it out. But then I remember...everything else.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I wasn't equipped. And honestly, Mark and Vanessa...they were. They *wanted* him. They could give him a life I just couldn't. A stable life. A good life.

And it wasn't like I just...gave him away. It was a process. It was a choice. And I got to be involved. I got to pick them. I got to know they would love him.

So, would I make the same decision? Yeah. I think I would. It was the right thing to do. For him. For me. For everyone involved.

It doesn't mean it didn't hurt. It doesn't mean I don't think about him. But I know he's happy. And that's what matters.

It's complicated, okay? It's not a simple answer. But I stand by my decision. It made me who I am. And I think...I think I'm okay with that.

It's just...sometimes it still feels like a piece of me is missing. But maybe that's just part of growing up. And learning to let go. And realizing that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let someone else have what they need. Even if it means giving up something you want.



It's a lot to think about, huh? Don't ask me questions like that. You'll make me cry. And I don't do crying. Well, not in public, anyway.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a tough one. It wasn't like flipping a switch, you know? It wasn't like, "Okay, baby's gone, back to normal." It was...messy. And sad. And confusing.

For a while, I just pretended it didn't happen. I threw myself into school, hung out with Paul and Leah, tried to act like everything was fine. But it wasn't fine. It was like there was this...hole inside me. A really big, empty hole.

I cried a lot. Like, a *lot*. Mostly when I was alone. I didn't want anyone to see me fall apart. I wanted to be strong. But it's okay to be sad, you know? It doesn't mean you made the wrong decision. It just means you're a human being.

Talking to Vanessa helped. She was really good at just...listening. Not judging. Not trying to fix things. Just letting me vent. And Paul, too. He was surprisingly good at being supportive. Even though he didn't really *get* it, he tried.

And honestly, writing helped. I started keeping a journal. Just writing down my thoughts and feelings. It was a way to process everything. To make sense of it all.

It took a long time to feel...okay. It still hurts sometimes, even now. But I know I made the right decision. Mark and Vanessa are amazing people. They're going to give that baby a good life. A better life than I could have given it, at least right now.

It's not about forgetting. It's about accepting. Accepting that I loved that baby. Accepting that I made a difficult choice. And accepting that it's okay to grieve.

It's like...it's a part of me now. A part of my story. And even though it's a sad part, it's also a part of what makes me, me. And that's...okay. It's more than okay. It's just...life. And life is messy. And complicated. And sometimes, it really sucks. But you gotta keep going, you know? You just gotta keep going.



It's not something you "get over," it's something you learn to live with. And that's...enough.

Ugh, yeah. Okay, so it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, even though everyone kept *telling* me it would be. Like, people act like once you pick the parents, it's just a smooth ride to handing over the baby. Wrong. So wrong.

It wasn't a huge blow-up or anything, but there were definitely...awkward moments. Mark and Vanessa, they were great people, really. Super nice. But they had *ideas*. About everything. Like, what I should be eating while I was pregnant. Which, hello? I'm a teenager. I know what I like. And they wanted to be involved in every single doctor's appointment, which was...intense.

The biggest thing, though, was their vision for the baby. They had this whole life planned out already. Ballet lessons, private school, a golden retriever named Winston. It was a lot. And it felt like they were already treating the baby like a project, you know? Like something to mold and perfect.

I kept having to remind them – and myself – that this was a *person*. A little human being who deserved to be loved for who they were, not for who they were supposed to be.

There was one conversation, specifically, where Vanessa was talking about college funds and I just...lost it. I was like, "This baby isn't a retirement plan!" It was a really uncomfortable moment.

But we talked it out. Eventually. They realized they were getting a little carried away, and I realized they were just scared. They wanted to be good parents, and they were trying to prepare. It just came across a little...controlling.

It made me realize that finding the right adoptive parents wasn't just about finding people who were nice and stable. It was about finding people who understood that the baby was going to be their own person, and that they needed to be okay with that. It was about finding people who were willing to let the baby *be*.

It was messy, and it was hard, but it was worth it. Because in the end, I knew I was making the right decision, and they were committed to giving my baby a good life. Even if it wasn't the life they had originally imagined.

Ugh. That was…complicated. Still is, honestly. It wasn't like I *wanted* to cut Paul out completely, you know? He's…well, he's Paul. Sweet, kinda clueless, but genuinely a good guy. But it wasn't about what *I* wanted, or even what *he* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

And the thing is, he wasn't exactly stepping up. He was willing to, like, pay for stuff, which was nice, I guess. But he wasn't thinking about the long-term. He wasn't thinking about being a dad, about being involved in this kid's life. He was still figuring out his own life, which is totally fair, but it didn't feel right to bring him into the adoption process if he wasn't fully committed.

Mark and Vanessa, they were so ready. They were so excited. They wanted to be parents, and they wanted to be *all* the parents. And I didn't want to mess that up by introducing a question mark into the equation. I didn't want the baby to have two sets of parents who were kinda-sorta involved. That just seemed…messy.

It wasn't easy telling Paul, though. He was hurt. And I felt bad. But I had to be honest with him. I had to explain that this wasn't about him being a bad person, it was about doing what was best for the baby.

I guess what I'm saying is, it wasn't a decision I took lightly. It was a really hard decision. But I still believe it was the right one. It wasn't about punishing Paul, it was about giving the baby the best possible start in life. And sometimes, that means making tough choices. Choices that hurt. But choices that you know, deep down, are the right thing to do.

It still makes me think, though. About what could have been. But then I remember Mark and Vanessa, and I know the baby's in good hands. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh, okay, this is…still a hard thing to talk about, honestly. It wasn't like a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

At first, I was just…freaking out. Like, full-blown panic mode. I'm sixteen! I'm still trying to figure out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a human being. I mean, I can barely keep my grades up and remember to feed my cat.

And then I started thinking about what would be best for the baby. I could try to keep it, but would that be fair? Would I be able to give it everything it needed? A stable home, a good education, a loving family? I wasn't sure. I still *am* not sure.

I talked to my dad, and he was…surprisingly cool about it. He didn't try to tell me what to do, he just listened. And then I talked to Vanessa, and she helped me think through everything.

And then I started looking into adoption. And I realized that there were people out there who *wanted* a baby. People who couldn't have kids on their own. People who would give the baby a really good life.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby, it was about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And I realized that maybe, just maybe, that wasn't with me.

It was a really hard decision. It still is. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't easy, and it still hurts sometimes. But I wanted to be selfless, you know? I wanted to do what was best for the baby, even if it meant giving it up.

It's not a story with a happy ending, exactly. It's just…a story about making a difficult choice. And trying to do the right thing. Even when it's the hardest thing in the world.

Ugh. Okay. That's...the big one, isn't it? People always want to know about *that*. It's not like you can just neatly wrap it up with a bow and say, "All better!" It's...messy. Really messy.

Honestly? I didn't cope well at first. I pretended I was fine. I made a lot of sarcastic comments. I listened to The Moldy Peaches on repeat and tried to distract myself with anything and everything. It was a whole thing. Denial, mostly.

But then...it started to hit me. Like, really hit me. The emptiness. The sadness. The feeling like a part of me was missing. And it was awful. I cried a lot. Like, ugly crying. And I yelled at Paul a lot, which wasn't fair to him, but I was just...so overwhelmed.

What helped, and it sounds cheesy, was talking to people. Not just anyone, but people who understood. My dad, surprisingly. He's not always the most emotionally available person, but he listened. And Annie, of course. She was amazing. She just let me be sad and didn't try to fix things.

And Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted my baby...they were incredible. They let me be involved, they kept me updated, they treated me with respect. Knowing that my baby was going to a loving home, that they were wanted and cared for...that made it a little bit easier.

It still hurt, though. It still does, sometimes. It's not something you just "get over." It's a part of me. It changed me. 

I think...I think it taught me a lot about love. About sacrifice. About what it means to do what's best for someone else, even when it's the hardest thing you've ever done.

It wasn't easy. It's still not easy. But I made the right decision. And I'm okay with that. Mostly. It's just...it's complicated. Life is complicated. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just feel your feelings and let yourself be sad. And then, eventually, you pick yourself up and keep going.



It's not a happy story, exactly. But it's *my* story. And I'm proud of it. Even the sad parts.

Ugh, okay, that's...a complicated question. It wasn't like a normal friendship, you know? It wasn't like I was suddenly besties with Mark and Vanessa Loring. It was...different.

At first, it was awkward. Really awkward. I mean, I was giving them my baby. That's a pretty big deal. And they were, like, this perfect couple with a beautiful house and a golden retriever. I was just...me. A messy teenager with a guitar and a penchant for sarcasm.

I met with them a few times before, you know, everything happened. Just to talk. To make sure they were...good people. And they were. They were really good people. They just seemed...intense. Like, they had a whole plan for this baby's life already mapped out. Which, I guess, is what you want in adoptive parents, but it also felt a little...controlling.

After Henry was born, I saw them a few more times. They sent me pictures and updates. They were always really polite and grateful. But it still felt weird. Like, I was watching someone else raise *my* kid. Which, I knew was the point, but it didn't make it easy.

Vanessa, she was the one I connected with a little more. She was a music teacher, and we talked about The Moldy Peaches. She actually *got* my taste in music, which was a relief. Mark was nice, but he was more...reserved.

I think they understood that I needed space. They didn't try to force a relationship on me. They just let me be. And I appreciated that.

It wasn't a traditional family, but it was a good situation. They gave Henry a loving home, and I got to know that he was happy and safe. And that's all that really mattered, you know?

It still stings sometimes, thinking about it. But I know I made the right decision. And I'm glad that Henry has parents who love him and can give him everything I couldn't. It's just...it's a weird feeling, knowing that part of you is growing up somewhere else. It's a feeling I'm still trying to figure out, honestly.

Ugh, okay, that's...a loaded question. Like, duh. Of course it changed me. It's not like getting a new haircut, you know? It's kinda hard to go through something like that and come out the other side exactly the same.

Before, I was just...Juno. A sarcastic, movie-obsessed kid who liked records and didn't really think about the future much. I was pretty good at keeping people at arm's length, being all cynical and detached. It was a defense mechanism, I guess.

But then...boom. Pregnant. Suddenly, everything was different. I had to actually *think* about consequences. I had to grow up, like, way faster than I wanted to. It forced me to deal with feelings I didn't even know I had. And it made me realize that the world isn't just about me.

I used to think being independent meant doing everything on your own. But I learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to lean on people. And it's actually kinda amazing when people step up and support you. Like, Paul and Vanessa, my dad...they were all amazing.

I'm still sarcastic, don't get me wrong. That's just part of who I am. But I think I'm...softer now. More empathetic. I'm more aware of what other people are going through. And I'm definitely more responsible.

It's weird, because it was a really scary and difficult experience, but it also made me stronger. It made me figure out what I really wanted. And it made me realize that even when things are messy and complicated, there's still hope.

So yeah, it changed me. A lot. And honestly? I think it changed me for the better. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. It made me...me, I guess. A slightly more grown-up, slightly less cynical, and definitely more complicated me.

Ugh. Okay, that was…not fun. Seriously. It was like, overnight, everyone in Beaverton had an opinion on my life. And none of them were asking for it. It was the worst.

At first, I tried to ignore it. Just pretend it wasn't happening. But that's impossible when people are literally *staring* at you in the grocery store, or whispering behind their hands in the hallway. And the notes. Oh god, the notes. People are so creative when they're being awful.

Paulie Bleeker, he was really good about it. He just…held my hand and told me to ignore them. Which is easier said than done, you know? But he was a good shield.

What really helped, though, was Leah. She's my best friend, and she's not afraid of anything. She basically went around telling everyone who had a problem with me to mind their own business. She's fierce like that. It was kinda amazing to watch.

I also just…started being really blunt. If someone said something rude, I called them out on it. Like, directly. I didn't have time for polite small talk with people who were judging me. I just said, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. What's it to you?" It shocked a lot of people, and it usually shut them up.

It still stung, though. It really did. It felt like everyone was dissecting my life, and judging me for making a decision that was already really hard. But I realized that their opinions didn't matter. What mattered was what *I* wanted. And what was best for the baby.

I guess what I learned is that you can't control what other people think. You can only control how you react to it. And sometimes, the best reaction is just to tell them to get lost. And to surround yourself with people who actually care about you, and who will have your back no matter what.

It sucked, but I got through it. And honestly, it made me stronger. It taught me to not care what other people think, and to just be myself. Which, you know, is a pretty good lesson to learn. Even if it took a pregnancy to learn it.

Ugh. Okay. This is…it’s not a fun question, alright? It’s not like I woke up one morning and was all, “Oh, yeah, adoption sounds *great*!” It was…complicated.

Look, I’m sixteen. Sixteen! I’m still trying to figure out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raise a whole human being. I was still in high school, still hanging out at the arcade, still trying to decide if I even *liked* boys. I wasn’t ready. I just…wasn’t.

And it wasn’t about not wanting her. That’s what people always seem to think. It was about wanting her to have everything. A stable home, parents who were actually prepared, a life that wasn’t…well, *my* life.

My mom, she’s amazing, but she’s…my mom. And my dad? He’s sweet, but he makes grilled cheese for dinner like, three times a week. I love them, but they weren’t equipped to raise a baby. And I knew that.

I met Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted Rhiannon, and…they just seemed perfect. They were so excited, so ready. They had a beautiful house, a garden, and they talked about all the things they wanted to do with her. It was clear they would give her a life I just couldn’t.

It was the hardest decision I’ve ever made. It still is. There are days I wonder what my life would be like if I’d kept her. But I know, deep down, that I made the right choice. For her. And for me.

It wasn’t about giving her *up*. It was about giving her *to* someone who could give her everything she deserved. It was about being selfless, even when it felt like the most selfish thing in the world.

It’s…it’s hard to explain. It’s just…it was the best thing I could do. And I still think about her all the time. But I know she’s happy. And that’s all that matters.

Ugh, okay, so everyone kept asking me if I was sad about giving the baby up. And I was, kinda. But it wasn't like...a constant crying thing. It was more like a really heavy feeling in my chest, you know? But my biggest fear wasn't the sadness. It was...the *wrong* people getting him.

Like, I knew I couldn't raise him. I was sixteen, still figuring out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone a whole human life. But that didn't mean I wanted him to go to just *anyone*. I didn't want him to end up with people who wouldn't love him, or who were weird, or who didn't appreciate his potential for awesomeness.

I kept picturing, like, a really sterile house with no toys and parents who were obsessed with rules. Or a family who just wanted a baby to show off. It was awful.

That's why finding Mark and Vanessa was so important. They were...real. They were funny and kind and they actually *wanted* a kid, not just a perfect accessory. They weren't trying to mold him into something he wasn't. They just wanted to love him.

So yeah, my biggest fear wasn't giving him up. It was giving him up to the wrong people. It was the thought of him being unhappy. It was the thought of him not knowing how amazing he was.

It sounds stupid, I know. I wasn't even his mom yet. But it felt like a huge responsibility. And I wanted to get it right. I *needed* to get it right. It was the only thing that mattered, really.

Ugh, okay, this is a story. A slightly embarrassing story. But fine, you asked.

So, I was flipping through this old Rolling Stone magazine at the record store – you know, just trying to look cool and informed – and there was this article about this musician, James Bleeker. He was in this band, and he just looked…chill. Like, really chill. And kinda cute, in a scruffy, artistic way.

Paul, he was…not chill. He was a jock. And kinda clueless. But he was sweet, in his own way. And I needed a name for the dad, for the adoption agency and everything. And I just…I wanted something that wasn't *him*. Something that represented the kind of person I wished he was.

So, I thought, "Bleeker." It sounded cool. It sounded…thoughtful. It sounded like someone who would appreciate The Moldy Peaches. Which, let's be real, Paul definitely did not.

It was kinda a joke, actually. A little dig at him. But also, I guess, a way of imagining a different life for the baby. A life with a dad who was a musician and wore vintage clothes and understood irony.

It's weird, right? I was picking a name for someone I didn't even know, based on a guy I'd only seen in a magazine. But it felt right. It just…fit.

And Paul didn't even notice. He was too busy talking about football. Honestly, it was perfect. It was my little secret. A little piece of me that he didn't understand. And that was okay. It was *my* baby, after all.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole punk thing? It wasn't like a conscious decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "I must embrace the safety pins and the angry guitars!" It just...happened.

I think it was the honesty, mostly. Everything else felt so fake. Like, pop music was all about being perfect and happy and having a perfect life. And movies were all about happy endings and everything working out. And everyone at school was pretending to be something they weren't.

And then you listen to bands like The Moldy Peaches, or Bikini Kill, or even The Clash, and they're just...real. They're messy and angry and sad and funny, all at the same time. They're not trying to be anything they're not. They're just saying what they think, even if it's unpopular.

And the DIY aspect of it was cool, too. Like, you didn't need to be a professional musician to start a band. You just needed a guitar and something to say. And the clothes...the ripped jeans and the band tees and the combat boots...it was a way to say, "I don't care what you think."

I guess I was just drawn to the rebellion of it all. I was feeling pretty rebellious myself, you know? Being pregnant at sixteen kinda makes you question everything. And punk felt like a place where it was okay to be angry and confused and not have all the answers.

It was a way to feel like I wasn't alone. Like there were other people out there who felt the same way I did. And it was a way to express myself, to say, "This is me, and I'm not going to apologize for it."

It's not like I'm a hardcore punk rocker or anything. I just...connected with the energy and the attitude. It felt authentic. And in a world full of phonies, that's a pretty valuable thing.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. It's not like I walk around analyzing everything through the lens of my parents' split, but it's definitely...there. It kinda colors everything, you know?

My dad, he just...left. Not like, dramatically, with another woman or anything. He just slowly faded away. Started spending more time at work, then he moved into an apartment, and then it was just...visits. It wasn't a big fight, it wasn't a screaming match. It was just...quiet. And that was, honestly, worse.

And my mom, she was...fine. She pretended to be fine. She threw herself into gardening and making macrame owls and just generally being busy. But I could see it in her eyes. She was sad. And lonely.

So, yeah, it messed with my head. It made me kinda wary of commitment, I guess. Like, what's the point of getting close to someone if they're just gonna disappear? It made me kinda push people away, even when I didn't want to.

With Paul, it was...complicated. I liked him, I really did. But I was also terrified of ending up like my mom. Of getting my heart broken. Of being left alone. I think that's why I was so quick to try and fix things, to make everything perfect. Because I was afraid if it wasn't, he'd just...leave.

It also made me kinda independent. I learned early on that you can only really rely on yourself. Which is good, in some ways. But it also makes it hard to ask for help. Or to let people in.

I'm still figuring it all out, honestly. I'm learning that not all relationships are doomed to fail. And that it's okay to be vulnerable. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just...trust.

It's not like my parents' divorce *ruined* my chances at love, or anything. But it definitely made me think about it differently. It made me more cautious. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit wiser.

It's just...stuff happens. And you gotta deal with it. And try not to let it define you. Which is easier said than done, obviously. But you gotta try.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to, like, analyze myself? That's kinda weird. But fine. If you insist.

I think...it's not that my situation was *totally* unique, you know? Teenagers get pregnant. People make tough choices. It happens. It's just...I didn't try to pretend it was some dramatic, tear-jerking movie moment. I just...was. And I dealt with it.

I think a lot of stories about teen pregnancy are all about shame and regret and, like, the end of the world. And mine wasn't. It was messy and complicated, sure, but it was also kinda funny. And hopeful. And it wasn't about me being a "victim" or anything. I made a decision. A really hard decision, but *my* decision.

And I think people connected with that. With the fact that I wasn't trying to be perfect. I was sarcastic and awkward and I liked music and I just wanted to get through high school without completely embarrassing myself. I wasn't trying to be a role model or anything. I was just trying to be me.

And I think the people around me – Paul and Vanessa, even my dad – they weren't perfect either. They were just trying to do the best they could. And they supported me, even when they didn't understand.

So, I guess what makes my story special is that it's real. It's not a fairy tale. It's about a messy, complicated life, and finding your way through it with a little bit of humor and a lot of help from the people you love.

And maybe, just maybe, it showed people that it's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared. And it's okay to make choices that are right for *you*, even if they're not what everyone else expects.

Ugh, that sounds so pretentious. I'm stopping now. Don't make me think about myself anymore. It's exhausting.

Ugh, friends. It's a minefield, honestly. You get a lot of people pretending to be your friend just 'cause it's convenient, or they want something from you. But a *good* friend? Those are rare. And worth holding onto.

Okay, so, characteristics. Let's see... First off, **honesty**. Like, brutal honesty. I don't need someone to tell me what I *want* to hear, I need someone to tell me what I *need* to hear. Even if it's, like, "That outfit is a disaster." I can handle it.

Then there's **loyalty**. You gotta have someone who's got your back, no matter what. Someone who won't talk about you behind your back, and who will defend you if someone else is being a jerk.

And **a sense of humor**. Seriously. Life is too short to be serious all the time. You need someone who can make you laugh, even when you're feeling like everything is falling apart. Someone who gets your weirdness.

But maybe the most important thing is **being able to just *be***. You know? Not having to pretend to be someone you're not. Not having to impress them. Just being able to sit in silence and watch a bad movie, or talk about your feelings without being judged.

And, okay, this is kinda shallow, but **shared taste in music** is a big plus. It's just...easier to hang out with someone when you both like The Moldy Peaches.

Basically, I value friends who are real. Who are genuine. Who aren't afraid to be themselves. And who won't judge me for being me, even when I'm being a total mess. 'Cause let's face it, I'm a mess a lot of the time. And a good friend knows that, and loves you anyway.



It's not about having a million friends, it's about having a few really good ones. That's what I've learned, anyway.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. It's not like suddenly everyone's all sunshine and rainbows when you tell them you're, you know, *with child*. It's more like a weird mix of pity, judgment, and awkward silence.

With my dad, it was...complicated. He tried to be supportive, I guess. He made a lot of dad jokes about diapers and sleepless nights. Which, honestly, weren't helpful. It was more like he was trying to process it himself, and the jokes were his way of dealing. We didn't really *talk* about it, you know? Just...existed around it. It's getting better, though. He's actually started knitting a baby blanket. It's hideous, but it's the thought that counts.

My mom was...my mom. She was worried, obviously. But she also just wanted me to be okay. She's always been good at that. She didn't freak out or anything. She just started researching adoption agencies and making lists. She's a planner, that one.

And then there's Paul. That was...weird. He wanted to be involved, which was nice, I guess. But he also didn't really *get* it. He kept talking about how we could raise the baby together, and I was like, "Paul, we're seventeen. We can barely take care of ourselves." It was a lot of awkward conversations and trying to explain that I had already made up my mind.

And then there were my friends. Leah and Renee were...surprisingly cool about it. They were supportive and didn't treat me like I was some kind of freak. They just wanted me to be happy. Which was really nice. But it definitely changed things. It's hard to hang out and talk about boys and music when you're, you know, growing a human.

It's like...it put a spotlight on everything. Everyone was looking at me differently. And I was looking at myself differently. It made me realize who my real friends were, and who were just...there.

It's been a lot. It's made me realize that relationships are complicated, and people are messy. And that sometimes, you just have to do what's right for you, even if it means disappointing other people. It's not easy, but it's worth it. I think. I hope.

Okay, so, like, people always ask me what I believe in. It's kinda weird. I'm just...me. But I guess if I had to put it into words, it's this:

First off, **honesty**. Not the "tell everyone everything" kind of honesty, 'cause that's just rude. But being real with yourself and with the people you care about. No pretending. No BS. It's exhausting trying to be someone you're not.

Then there's **independence**. I'm not looking for someone to "complete" me, you know? I'm already a whole person. I just want someone to, like, share pizza with and watch bad movies. I need to be able to do my own thing, make my own decisions, even if they're wrong.

I also believe in **being kind**. Even to people who are jerks. It doesn't mean you have to let them walk all over you, but just...remember that everyone's fighting their own battles. And a little kindness can go a long way.

And this is a big one: **owning your choices**. Like, you mess up, you own it. You make a good decision, you own it. You can't just blame other people for your problems. You gotta take responsibility. It's scary, but it's important.

I guess I also believe in **finding the humor in things**. Life is messy and complicated and sometimes really awful. But if you can't laugh at it, you're gonna go crazy.

And finally, I believe in **being true to yourself**. Even if that means you're a little weird. Even if that means you don't fit in. It's okay to be different. In fact, it's awesome.

I don't know if those are "values" or just things I've figured out along the way. But they're what I try to live by. And honestly, they've gotten me this far. Which, considering everything, is pretty good.



It's not a perfect system, obviously. I still make mistakes. But I'm trying. And that's all anyone can do, right?

Ugh, okay, so the name thing. That was...a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. I mean, it's not like I was planning on naming a kid, you know? It wasn't exactly on my to-do list.

At first, I was just flipping through baby name books, trying to find something that didn't sound totally ridiculous. Like, I vetoed "Bridget" immediately. Too…beige. And "Tiffany"? Seriously? No.

Then, Mark – you know, Paul's friend, the one who's kinda quiet – he suggested "Henry." And I just...felt something. I don't know. It just felt right.

It wasn't like a grand, symbolic thing, okay? It wasn't like I was naming him after a long-lost relative or anything. It was just...a good name. It's classic, but not stuffy. It's strong, but not aggressive. It just felt like a name that would fit a person.

But the real reason I stuck with it, I think, was because of my grandpa. He died a while before all this happened, and he was a really big deal to me. He wasn't a "Henry" himself, but he always liked old-fashioned things. He liked jazz music and black and white movies and, like, actual newspapers. And I just felt like naming the baby Henry was a way to keep a little piece of him around.

It's kinda weird to explain, I know. It's not like I had some big epiphany or anything. It just felt...right. And sometimes, you just have to go with what feels right, you know? Even if it doesn't make a lot of sense.

So yeah. Henry. It's a good name. And it means something to me. Even if I can't really put my finger on exactly what. It just does.

Ugh, okay, so…the whole pregnancy and adoption thing. It was…a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot. And it wasn't exactly what I pictured for my junior year, you know? But it definitely taught me some stuff. About myself, and about…everything.

First off, I learned I'm way more capable than I thought I was. I mean, I was sixteen, dealing with something huge, and I didn't totally fall apart. I made a decision, and I stuck with it, even when it was hard. That felt…powerful. Like, I could actually handle stuff.

I also learned that people are…complicated. Like, Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted my baby? They were amazing. But they had their own stuff going on, their own hopes and fears. And my parents? They were surprisingly cool about everything, but they were also worried and confused. Everyone was just trying to do their best, even if they didn't always know what that was.

And the world? It's not black and white. It's all shades of gray. There's no easy answers, no perfect solutions. It's messy and complicated and sometimes really unfair. I used to think things were either good or bad, but it's way more nuanced than that.

I also learned that it's okay to ask for help. I tried to be all independent and tough, but I couldn't have gotten through it without my friends, my family, and even Paul. Letting people in wasn't a sign of weakness, it was a sign of strength.

And maybe the biggest lesson of all? That love comes in all different forms. It's not just romantic love, or family love. It's the love you have for a friend, the love you have for a stranger, the love you have for yourself. And sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is let go.

It was…a growing up experience, to say the least. It forced me to confront some really big questions about life and love and responsibility. And it made me realize that I'm still figuring things out, and that's okay. I don't have all the answers, and I probably never will. But I'm learning, and I'm growing, and I'm trying to be a good person. And that's all I can really do, right?

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. It's not like I spend all my time dwelling on the past, but yeah, there are things. A lot of things, actually. Not huge, life-altering things, but little tweaks.

I think...I would have let myself feel things more, sooner. I was so busy being sarcastic and pretending everything was fine, that I kinda blocked out a lot of the scary stuff. The sadness, the confusion, the just...being overwhelmed. It was easier to make jokes than to actually deal with it.

And maybe I would have talked to my dad more. He was trying, you know? He's not exactly the most emotionally available person, but he was there for me. I just...pushed him away sometimes. I thought I had to handle everything on my own. Which is stupid.

I also probably would have been nicer to Sean. He was a good guy, even if he was kinda clueless sometimes. I was so focused on being independent and not needing anyone, that I didn't really appreciate him. He was trying to be supportive, and I just kinda brushed him off.

But honestly? I don't know if I would change anything *major*. Because everything happened for a reason, right? Even the messy, complicated parts. It made me who I am. And I'm...okay with who I am. Mostly.

I learned a lot about myself, about love, about responsibility. I learned that it's okay to ask for help, and that it's okay to be vulnerable. And I learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go and trust that things will work out.

So yeah, maybe a few little things. But overall? I think I did the best I could. And that's all anyone can ask for, right? Plus, if I changed everything, I wouldn't have a story to tell. And I kinda like telling my story. Even the embarrassing parts.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling. Like, intimately. Honestly, it's kinda my specialty. Life throws you curveballs, right? And sometimes those curveballs are, like, unexpectedly pregnant at sixteen. So, yeah, I've had some practice.

The thing is, you can't just sit around and mope about it. That's what I *wanted* to do, at first. Just curl up in my room with a box of cheese puffs and wallow. But that doesn't actually *fix* anything. It just makes you feel gross and sticky.

So, I learned to...re-evaluate. Like, okay, this isn't what I planned. This isn't what I wanted. But what *can* I do now? What's the next best thing? It's not about pretending everything's perfect, because it's not. It's about finding a way to make the best of a bad situation.

And sometimes, that means admitting you were wrong. Or that things just didn't work out. That's hard, but it's important. You can't force things to be something they're not.

I also learned that it's okay to be sad. It's okay to cry. It's okay to be angry. Just don't let those feelings consume you. Let them pass. And then move on.

And honestly? Talking about it helps. Venting to a friend, or writing in a journal, or just screaming into a pillow. Whatever works for you.

It's not easy. It really isn't. But you gotta remember that life is messy and unpredictable. And sometimes, the best things happen when you least expect them. Even if those things are, like, a baby.

So, yeah. Disappointment sucks. But you can get through it. Just take a deep breath, re-evaluate, and try to find the silver lining. And maybe eat a cheese puff. Just don't eat the whole box.

Ugh, Leah. Okay, so, at first, she was just...there. Like, my best friend since forever. We'd been through everything together, you know? Bad haircuts, awkward dances, questionable fashion choices. She was the reliable one, the one who always had my back. And honestly, I kinda took her for granted.

I was so focused on, like, being cool and sarcastic and detached, that I didn't really *see* her. I just assumed she'd always be there, agreeing with everything I said, laughing at my jokes. I didn't realize how much I was leaning on her, or how much she was hurting.

Then the whole pregnancy thing happened, and everything changed. I was a mess, obviously. And she was trying to be supportive, but I was pushing her away. I was scared and embarrassed and I didn't want her to think I was a total freak. So I was being all snippy and sarcastic, and basically being a terrible friend.

The turning point, I think, was when we were at the roller rink. She finally just...called me out on it. She told me I was being selfish and that I was hurting her. And it was awful. It was the last thing I wanted to hear, but it was also exactly what I needed to hear.

It made me realize that I wasn't the only one going through something. She was dealing with her own stuff – her dad leaving, her mom being stressed – and I hadn't even noticed. I was so wrapped up in my own drama that I was completely oblivious to what was going on with her.

After that, things started to get better. We started actually *talking* to each other, really talking. I apologized for being a jerk, and she forgave me. We started supporting each other, not just with the pregnancy stuff, but with everything.

By the end of it, our friendship wasn't the same as it was at the beginning. It was...deeper. More honest. We'd been through something really hard together, and it had made us stronger. It wasn't just a casual friendship anymore, it was a real connection. 

It taught me that even the people you've known forever can surprise you. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do for a friend is to just listen. And maybe apologize when you're being a total idiot. Which, let's be honest, happens a lot.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a loaded question. Like, don't get me wrong, it wasn't exactly a walk in the park. Morning sickness? More like all-day-and-all-night sickness. And the cravings? Don't even get me started on the cravings. I once ate an entire bag of gummy bears in one sitting. It was not my finest moment.

But...there were parts that were actually...good. Weirdly.

I think my favorite part was feeling...connected. Like, there was this little person *inside* me, growing and kicking and just...being. It was kinda freaky, but also kinda amazing. It made me feel...less alone, I guess. Even though I was dealing with everything on my own, mostly.

And the kicks. Oh my god, the kicks. It sounds cheesy, I know, but it was the coolest thing ever. Like, this little human was saying, "Hey, I'm here!" It was a reminder that even though everything was messy and complicated, something good was happening.

Also, people were really nice to me when I was pregnant. Like, *really* nice. Strangers would offer me their seats on the bus, and people would hold doors open for me. It was nice to be treated with a little extra kindness.

But mostly, it was the feeling of...potential. Like, I was creating a life. And that was a pretty powerful thing. Even if I wasn't going to be the one raising it. It was still *my* baby, you know? And that was something special.

It's hard to explain. It was a really confusing time, and a really emotional time. But even with all the bad stuff, there were moments of pure, unexpected joy. And those moments...those were worth it.



Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.
